Comment: Three weeks out of warranty. The guy charged the full diagnostic and the repair fee. The fault put a message onto the dash 'check number plate light'. Turned out to be a corroded connector. The fault has been fixed now.

Name: cue2
Comment: When my first Giulietta was the same time out of warranty the tailgate wiring failed on one wire. When the dealer told me it’d be £800 I said I didn’t think so. As I’d owned it from new and had a full service history the repair was free on goodwill. Not easy as it was just before the August shutdown so the claim started with Italy and ended with Fiat U.K.

Name: stelviowner
Comment: Latest trick?? Speedo not working. Put the car to bed, it was fine. In the morning we set out and the speedo didn't move, didn't do anything. Over time as we went along it gradually came back to life, creeping higher up the clock until finally after half an hour or so it was reading somewhere near the mark. Probably another electrical connection fault but can I trust it to read anything like true now? Who knows. Never saw that one coming.

Name: cue2
Comment: Your car is a Multiair? The oil used should not be from the drum of sieved stuff known in the trade as the “pot of gold” due to its incredible profitability, My first Giulietta MA got the wrong oil put in by a main dealer but when I checked Alfa customer services told them to collect it and change it for the correct stuff. The handbook gives a mileage that should not be exceeded with the wrong oil.

Name: wictod
Comment: Thanks Cue... my car is 2.0L 280 Specialie ... as far as I'm aware it needs to be the Selenia Digitek 0w 30.. What I can't get my head around even if it's a genuine mistake is why the parts list states the wrong oil on two occasions.. this time I think i've been sold the wrong stuff because of the price... surely they must realise Alfa owners are OCD about this sort of thing? Furthermore, they have advised that front and back discs and pads are needed very soon but quote for that work is £1050.00.. I know nothings cheap these days but seems a bit pricey to me.

Name: wictod
Comment: Deman77 said:Volvo main dealer only recommended and did pads on my xc90 when rears wore off. So it’s not a manufacturer policy - it’s a easy job eager dealer.It is not a given that the pads will always go first and discs will be fine. It depends on the disc and the pad and how brakes are worked too. But on road use car it should probably just be pads.I would expect them to have told you what the wear is - new, current, minimum style measures on both disc and pad. It’s not like they are asking for 30 to change windscreen wipers.I do not like the sound of your dealer. I would stay away from them. Don’t let them do anything else - just go somewhere else and write off the money. If they are pulling those stunts with oil on you they may easily be fitting non oem filters or not changing them. Any remedial work - how can you trust they do it right now. I would name them too. Even if they fix the issue people should be weary and check everything with that one.Click to expand...To be fair to the engineer he did articulate the amount of wear on the front and backs in a health check video... it was the cost of remedial work that I found a bit steep although I might be wrong, maybe it is that expensive.. Regarding the Oil and lack of plugs on the billing I have emailed the service department with my concerns so I can start some official dialogue to see what their response is before I escalate it if it needs that.. sent the email this morning so far no reply from them..

Name: alfaitalia
Comment: That will be the same for any car costing over £40k new and first registered after April 2017. Luxury car tax adds £335 on top of the road tax until it's six years old....then it will drop back to the £155 or whatever it is now.

Name: Deman77
Comment: What are you after in your car? Stelvio is an unusual one as it is driving focused which is not a forte of SUVs. It will still not be the Giulia but if you need the extra space, the height, the awd, the tow, the boot and the roof rails it is a good driver focused compromise.But then going with diesel you take some of that away. When you say running costs, what is your maths? The largest cost is depreciation.is it only Toenail and Stelvio or do you have other cars on your shortlist? By the time you take delivery Tonale should be available so you might want to wait a bit so you do not regret buying Stelvio.

Or when people take it for test drives.Although doing this, recording it and putting it on the internet is not the best idea. Especially when it is a customers car that was ordered and made for you from the factory. It's not a stone cold engine, but it is unlikely to be at peak operating temperature.Once I was given the opportunity to test drive a Porsche Boxster. It was automatic, and the pedals were very close. I had my foot hard on what I thought was the brake when I started the car. However it was the accelerator. I'll never forget...Is it worse to know something, or just to have never known it in the first place?Click to expand...I don’t really think this is a case “to be fair”As for your accidentally abusing a demo Porsche , that’s why Alfa dealer ads for used cars state that a car “has had multiple owners”When I collected my new Stelvio the salesman told me that with the car I’d testdriven they had not been able to resist giving it a good off-road test.

Name: cue2
Comment: Ah, but they’re cheap!

Name: alfaitalia
Comment: LOL.......try and find an actuall mechanic in any main dealer....they diagnose a problem, usually electronically (hopefully!) and fit new parts....hence fitter. A proper mechanic would at least attempt to fix said parts or find a way around the issue using engineering skill....thing of the past Im afraid. I did not own the business....I was sales manager...then acting General manager. I'll ignore that last comment!.....and I was a paid car mechanic once for an indy in Horndean near Portsmouth before I went into sales.....for purely financial reasons!!.

Name: lussoman

Someone I trust and have full respect for.I get that sales people are necessary to hammer out deals, sort finance etc and get vehicles out of the showrooms.

Name: Mathew Rudd
Comment: So I took delivery of my factory order stelvio quad a week ago now.i decided to have a look on YouTube on stelvios because I'm in love with the car and then I come across my actual car being reved to the redline by some c**t having no respect that its brand new and posting it and the registration on theInternet.imso angry .I have emailed beechdale for them to change who they use to wash their cars and to ask them to take down thevideo.itseems someone else's montreal green gulia has been treated the same if you look at his othervideos.whatwould you do in my situation?

Name: alfaitalia
Comment: Video taken down as well......

Name: Mathew Rudd
Comment: Deman77 said:missed out on the video, but I figure what’s there from description. It is totally unacceptable to do things like that by people who are trusted and have no clear need to red line the car and especially in abusive manner (no warm up or idle revving). I’d be gutted. I would insist on their workshop reaching out to the factory techs as they do when they don’t know how to fix smth to advise what should be done in this instance. They should assume it was cold red lined at idle and potentially a few times to get the video right. At the very least oil should be changed if the car was cold revved and not run in yet as oil may now be contaminated. No point asking for freebees - if they want to give smth to create good will - fine, but the important thing is that they support you to do what is necessary.Having said that I do think a mechanic definitely has a need to give these types of cars full beans and drive them how I would. Is it a perk? Yes. But does it also benefit me as a customer? Yes. If they do so regularly, they have a better chance of spotting something odd with one. Now I do expect the car to be warmed up prior to this and it only takes about 5min driving it at 2.5k.When alfaworkshop was doing my run in oil change I checked with them the car would be insured for a test drive by the mechanic and asked him to take it round the block in race mode to see he was happy with everything. He obliged and came back grinning ear to ear - said he encountered a willing f type R and dropped it out of a roundabout on a dual carriageway. He then checked for leaks before sending me on my way. That is completely different from a sales rep, designated driver or a washing contractor doing that as they have zero need that benefits the customer.Click to expand...I totally agree with you im not about the freebies just want to know the car is ok.The video had now been taken down as I emailed alfa beechdale with a very firm Manor and told them to go and see the owner of the car wash and explain whatshappend.imnow waiting on the director of this dealership to give me a call to explain the mess and what they are going to do to rectify my concerns about engine etc.I luckily have a copy of the video.....

Name: sizewell
Comment: Deman77 said:I think that usually just limits the speed and not the revs. Leaves plenty of room to abuse or even to wipe it out off a roundabout.It positive that they get “a pro” and not just paying minimum wage someone to scrape grit with a bucket of dirty water. Though that might still happen for post service wash.But I would just contract a mobile valet guy. Just think of all the petrol moving the cars to the site and back and the drivers and their cars. Seems awfully inefficient.They mobile valet guys carry enough ionised water to properly pressure wash a dozen cars. You get to see what they are doing. Just erect a permanent gazebo for them in your parking lot and sort out a call out system. It will work out cheaper, the quality will be better and they would bite your hand off for that kind of volume business.Click to expand...I am not talking about that particular function, I mean specifically writing a function into the software to enable the engine to be limited/inhibited! Do I care how inefficient it is - the cost will work it's way through to the customer in any case - as always.

Name: jerehada
Comment: Agree a quad at low speeds is a very quiet and smooth engine and fine at motorway speeds. I've liked driving long journeys in it and never felt tired even compared to big lux estates before. It does have a real strong what I call self righting when on badly surfaced uneven roads at low speeds it can jostle you a bit (stiff springs and roll bar combination) apart from that comfort is fine the dampers work beautifully.My plan for interior is to visit an automotive trimmer and leather the door cards, steering column shroud put alcantara on some other surfaces such as the gear lever but car would be out of action for some time and I would miss driving it.

I'm coming from an e-class estate with roof bars for the last 7 years so no worries lifting bikes up top, but quite fancy the convenience of a tow bar mounted carrier. My current thule roof bike carrier is past its best so either way I am starting from scratch.Had a search but all I found were quite specific questions or about the OEM setup. Any thoughts very much appreciated!

Name: Jimbon1973
Comment: I'm sure a few of you have done this but...I've been a happy owner of a giulia veloce for 3.5 years and looking to get a new stelvio.I'm just wondering what people who have done the same move have thought about going from the saloon to an SUV?I've had a 156, 159 then giulia, so kind of used to 4 door saloons.I love the handling of the veloce, the engine is adequate for spirited driving around the South Devon lanes, I'd say the only disappointment has been the exhaust noise (or lack of it) and slightly restricted leg room in the rear for growing kids.So, is the Stelvio any bigger for rear passengers?Is the exhaust even more muted in the new versions andhas anyone upgraded exhaust to sound a little better (without neighbour complaints)?!

Comment: I quite agree, but I personally think a QV is pretty useless on our roads. Okay, they look great (especially the Giulia) but where the heck can you use all that power, let alone find enough petrol to quench its thirst at present.

Name: GVblue
Comment: "it spends a ton of time as a 3cyl."Kinda makes my point, but don't get me wrong, I accept the quad variants are amazing cars and if I lived in a county that did not have a 50 mph and below speed limit on virtually every road, who knows.

Name: Jimbon1973
Comment: Deman77 said:Stelvio qv is very very easily exploitable on public roads at legal speeds. You can see the bend well, you have the confidence it will pull you out if you overcook the throttle or get unbalanced by a poor road surface. Gear ratios are such that 1-5th are all usable within nsl. I enjoy mine even at busy times on good roads just falling behind the traffic on the straits and catching up through the bends.You definitely would not miss giulia and even giulia qv since you cannot drive it as close to the limit as Stelvio including wet and cold.Petrol is different matter, though it seems it’s not much thirstier than 2.0 anyway since it spends a ton of time as a 3cyl. But more importantly if someone handed us a mclaren we would not be ending the praise with “but the petrol”. so we should count our blessings - in 10 years they want us in those 2.5ton EV barges that will probably also not allow driver to take control.If I was op and wanted to make sure I would not regret moving from giulia I’d find a way to stretch to used Stelvio qv - we only live once.Click to expand...It's definitely an option, but dependent upon offer of trade in on my Giulia Veloce (2nd hand prices sky high so it all helps!)The sound is one of the main disappointments that I have, so the QV would certainly tick that box.Thanks for all the replies, interesting reading.

Name: cue2

Name: Muz
Comment: Deman77 said:don’t think about it as 8 gears - the last two are really for saving fuel and are pointless on the B roads since you don’t really spend much time in them. And if you do use them you will be fumbling with counting down gears or watching gear indicator instead of looking at the road when coming to the bend.Lower gear ratios are very sensible for QV - you get to max out 1st and 2nd below NSL (even 3rd on motorway). I think new cayman gt4 max 2nd is 80mph (basically a show or track car). I imagine it’s even better for 2.0 as you probably get to max out 3rd at NSL and 4th on the motorway.I use 6th as my coasting gear on B roads and it becomes a 6 speed gearbox - makes life simpler. Simpler still, 5 is really for no slowdown bends as it has too low an rpm at 60 to offer any sort of throttle control in the bend. 2-3-4 are really the working gears for bends. So it’s one, two or three blips slowing down into bends to get to the right revs to get you around the bend on throttle - hardly ever need brakes esp in Race. 3rd also nicely holds the car at 30 down the hills in town.I find auto is useless in N - it just guns for 8th gear. In D it’s much much better but since even this logic only downshifts when you brake or stab accelerator (as it should) you are still doing a fair bit of braking by foot. In manual esp in Race it’s possible to drive even quite aggressively with hardly any foot braking. I also find even D auto, as good as it is, can sometimes misinterpret temporary lift off for coasting intent and shift up so I don’t trust it for anything more brisk than 6/10 driving. I find I gain quite a bit more control over the car in manual as you get predictable on throttle steering adjustability in the bends and engine braking when slowing down.Using temporary override for engine braking when in auto is infuriating too as instead of just flicking it once and feel the effect you realise she’s good two gears higher when coasting and your revs barely move so you are shifting down in panic to find a gear that will have enough revs to have any meaningful braking and you are already past where you wanted to start slowing down.I would normally just use auto when warming up first few miles (usually in D as that runs coasting revs a little higher) and if it’s a boring motorway or A road journey. Otherwise - manual. The paddles are fantastic. Fixed position makes it harder to use with the turned steering wheel so it encourages discipline to pick the correct gear for the bend/speed combo. Gear selector has fairly cheap action in comparison plus it’s safer holding on to the wheel when pushing.Click to expand...Interesting, thanks for the in depth analysis. Yes it’s the coming down from 8th that has made me bin using the paddles so far. I’ll have a go with how you are suggesting.Motorways and town driving are a no brainer - automatic all the way

Name: Isotope
Comment: I find myself constantly putting the car into the highest gear I can in an effort to improve the MPG. I have a Stelvio 2.0 Veloce and never get more than 22 mpg! I've tried every driving mode for miles and am now trying reverting to E5 fuel. It does seem to be more rewarding over a very short distance so far!

Name: Deman77
Comment: it could still be a heavy foot getting there.To rule it out try running in middle lane on the flat motorway section in 8th at 60 for 2min making sure you are not drafting behind a lorry and having reset thetrip.Takenote of outside temperature and wind speed and direction vs direction of travel. We can ask someone else to do the same and if they get broadly similar mpg (allowing variation for temp and which way the wind blows) you know it’s your driving style and can just relax. If they are massively better you should book your Alfa in.

Name: Muz
Comment: On trips of 5-10 miles on really busy roads around where I live in the SE I get 18-22 mpg. When I travel further afield generally 22-25. On a trip from Calais to SW France I got 28 mpg with some fast acceleration on overtaking and leaving Motorway tolls with most of the trip at 70 mph+ on mostly motorways.Petrol Stelvio Veloces seem to have high fuel consumption, it’s the price for the size of the car and the performance I guess.

Need to check the small print but this would mainly be for brakes, tyres and servicing. Cost over the 4 year term would be £2.5k. That seems a lot to me. Annual mileage is just 6000. Should I just take my chances and pay as I go?

Name: Deman77
Comment: Tyres and brakes you might not need anything with that mileage or just the rear pads. Also 4th service is an expensive one for petrols - auxbelt change and spark plugs. Check if you will have to do it and ask for cost as you leases must do with main dealers or perhaps returning before it’s due (may be can stretch your services by a few weeks past 1y each)

Name: joephoto
Comment: Not sure if this feature is on Stelvios outside of the US, but my '21 Stelvio Ti (US model) has automatic high-beam headlights that are supposed to turn on when driving on dark roads using the camera mounted in front of the rearview mirror. I have had the vehicle since the end of July, and the automatic high-beams have yet to turn on even though I often drive a dark country road at night that has no lights and mostly no other cars. The "auto" high-beam indicator on the dash is on, and the automatic high-beam setting in the Infotainment system settings is enabled. Any thoughts how to 1.) test this function, and 2.) what might be causing the high-beams to not kick on when they are supposed to? As a note, I also have an Acura RDX with the same functionality, and those automatic high-beams work fine on the same road and under the same conditions. #stelvio, #headlights, #high-beams

Name: Isotope
Comment: Tonight I drove the car for the first time in the dark and the beam looked a bit high on the car in front, so I looked for the selector switchand there isn't one? I can't remember if my Giulia had one but I don't have any fancy suspension so how do the headlights not dazzle people when I put an elephant in the back?

Name: GVblue
Comment: 35w Xenon headlights are self levelling and automatically compensate for the load. You may have to lower them manually (adjuster on the lights themselves) if you are dazzling others. I had to as my lights were clearly upsetting oncoming drivers.

Name: Isotope
Comment: Thanks for that so the Giulia probably didn't have one either?

Name: GVblue
Comment: Depends on the bulb wattage. My Giulia (25w) does have an adjuster near the s/s, my Stelvio (35w) doesn't.

Name: Isotope
Comment: Thats what I thought! I had a Giulia Speciale with the 25W lights before the Stelvio!

Name: Isotope
Comment: I ordered this direct from Garmin and on the first page is a disclaimer that they are not responsible for any issues caused to the vehicle warranty by your use of their product. Even mentions vehicle performance could be affected. I've sent it back because I can't bet £40 for a £50k car. How can you get proper parking mode coverage on a dashcam without doing something that could void your warranty? Any advice would be greatly appreciated, the car is just 2 months old!

Name: joephoto
Comment: My dashcam is not hardwired and I use a 36000mAh Power Bank for parking mode. No modifications to the vehicle and no chance of voiding the warranty. Not the best solution, but it works.

Name: Isotope
Comment: I tried something like that but maybe not a big enough power bank then, do you have to switch something on when you get out of the vehicle?

Name: Isotope
Comment: Worst part about this experience is that I have had MSECU for about 15 years and never hesitated to plug in to the car at the time, was I risking as much? No because the cars were a bit cheaper ! But no-one before Garmin mentioned the risk to the vehicles warranty. Why do Garmin or anyone make something that they know could invalidate a car's warranty? My car has the best part of 3 years warranty to go and I can't take the risk, why don't they do something that uses the standard USB port?

Name: joephoto
Comment: The dash cam is plugged into an auxiliary USB port on on the plug from my radar detector, and I just unplug it from there and plug it into the Power Bank. I won’t do it for quick stops as it’s not worth it, but only if I park for an extended period of time.

Name: MultiDoc
Comment: Just follow the instructions on the Bosch blades’ box. If I remember correct you slide and rotate outwards, and yes it does take some force but not too much

Comment: My wifes Stelvio doesnt have Android Auto but I believe she should still be able to listen to music via Spotify on her Samsung Android phone, however it says "no media files found".We are selecting "Media" then "Source "and choose USB with the phone connected into the USB port below the heater controls. At this point the infotainment display recognises the phone is connected so all good.However, when we play music via Spotify on the phone it doesnt come through the cars speakers and we get the "no media files found".Any Ideas ?

Name: joephoto
Comment: Did you try both USB ports; the one under then A/C and the one in the center console bin? Does the car have Bluetooth, and did you try streaming the music that way?

Name: Navlet
Comment: I have tried both USB ports with out success. I havent tried to play via Bluetooth will give that ago.

Name: m&ms
Comment: Input needs to be Bluetooth not USB, your song will then display on both screens and you can control via the steering wheel

Name: Deman77
Comment: This.With usb you need files to play. For streaming it will just be Bluetooth audio. I use this on my precarplay i3. you can even talk to Siri (or whatever is on Android) via car mic but you still have to squeeze the phone to trigger it. Haven’t found a way to trigger via car buttons.

Name: Deman77
Comment: Just the sensors. Below certain speed they are engaged. If you are too close to things - they beep. Had that in my Volvo too - it would get excited about buses passing by rolling down the high street. That’s why there is p/off button.Never had this in a bmw but their sensor implementation is way ahead, it generates a live colour coded obstacle map on a dash and is very responsive - and that’s a 6yo car.

Name: Isotope
Comment: I have noticed that the p/off button auto disengages when you put the car into Park in my car, but it can be very annoying if just sat on the brake in a queue. Can I ask what brought you over to Alfa? Was it the steering and chassis feedback?

Name: cue2
Comment: Deman77 said:Stelvio QV did.I was intrigued by the reviews seriously suggesting it might just be hardcore enough to get the sports car thrills without having to own one or more importantly having to find the time to drive one all in a reasonably usable family suv package. As it turns out it was. I had to take the sports car bit on trust - I just tested that it was not too compromised as a family car. You can’t really get the confidence to appreciate what this thing can do on a B road in a test drive - took me good 700 miles.I ended up getting the Elise deposit back and trading in the Volvo family suv (my kids were well out of prams so I could downsize). I don’t regret it one bit on the sports car bit as there is just no way I would get this much fun out of two cars combo in the last 9 months even if Elise is truly special when you do get to drive it. I’d have to wait for good weather for the semi slicks and have the time for it too. Plus I would not have the confidence to push it to max because it would be rarely driven and had no 4wd crutch to balance my limited talents. With qv even the passengers don’t mind 7/10 driving and on my own I am confident pushing to 9/10 in any weather incl freezing. All you need is a decent stretch of road and you are already in the right car.The external Alfa image is so badly managed though, that unless an existing alfisti you really would only consider Alfa after you ruled out everything else.I imagine mainly people who are fed up with how badly modern family cars drive or want smth a bit different and don’t like the Porsche image would end up considering an Alfa Stelvio.When you do realise that objectively Giorgio platform cars are the best family drivers’ cars by a margin you start looking into owning one. The reliability surveys were fine, the cars are 3-4 model years in which is well past the early niggles stage so I figured reliability odds were in my favour. There was a 5y warranty deal about this time last year which was a sign of confidence from the manufacturer. I also could survive if my car did end up having to spend as much time at the dealer as my Volvo did.As for dealers bad rep, Thames Ancaster, where I test drove, looked respectable enough and had positive feedback on here. I also think some people are a bit snobbish about getting their “premium” vehicle serviced with jeep and Fiat riff raff and that puts them off. I am the opposite - can’t stand pretentious aftersales.Click to expand...“Thames Ancaster”?They are two completely different dealerships. Thames , where I bought my Stelvio, is in Tunbridge Wells and Ancaster are in Dartford. The former is ok at sales and the other is better for service.

Name: manc350
Comment: Isotope said:I've been sat in an Alfa every day now for 17 years and have never had a bad experience! UK dealers of other marques knock the brand every time they can but know how much enthusiasts will pay for a good low mileage car. The 147 JTD had a few antiroll bar and drop link noises that took a bit of work to cure, egr valve etc but the balance of that car was great, then the Giulietta 2.0jtdm a very capable car, both the 147 and JTD had amazing chassis response, if my 10 year old kid wiggled his arse on the back seats of both cars I could feel the balance change in the car! Then I think ten years ago most cars became very much the same. They became more reliable and seem to last a bit longer. 2 years ago I went with the Giulia, loved it a 2.2 diesel really good car but always had a longing for the Stelvio. First drive was in a diesel but after the Giulia I knew I wanted the performance of a Veloce. Luckily life has been fortunate to me and I now have a MY2021 Stelvio Veloce. I dealt with Beechdale in Derby and it was an absolute delight to deal with people who like cars like me! There was no hard sell or pressure, after the sale a very relaxed follow up call, but no desperation tactics that I have experienced from sales people from other dealerships. Our other car is a Fiat 500x and I don't care who does the work as long as they are honest and credible. I know what you mean about the dealers and I have dealt with a dealership in Norfolk that I would never go to again if there was no-one else left on the planet. Put simply they lied to me to try and generate more business.Click to expand...Snap regarding Beechdale, chaps i dealt with were car enthusiats and a real pleasure to deal with. Snap on the 2021 Veloce.. Previously back in 2012 i had a Giulietta 2.0jtdm (172bhp) with TCT and loved the way it drove and it neverlet me down in 4 years.. The Stelvio Veloce just makes me smile, i am smitten again with this car whereas mylast car, A Jeep Grand Cherokee was great, but never really held my attention like the Stelvio.

Name: Maximus84
Comment: Hi guys,I've had 3 instances of the CEL coming on with similar codes in the past 3 months or so on my '18 Speciale (petrol 280).The codes are 'P0302 cylinder 2 misfire detected', 'P0300 random/multiple cylinder misfire detected' and 'P1062 Manufacturer control'.Once a restart of the engine solved the problem, on 2 occasions clearing the codes sorted it. I previously dismissed it as an anomaly but now it's happened 3 times I'm more concerned. Especially as a bit of research shows possible multi-air unit failures on other engines (Mito/Giulietta).Has anyone seen these codes on a Stelvio/Giulia? Possible fixes? My nearest dealer is over an hour away and its not easy to get over there if/when the codes flash up again.

Name: Muz
Comment: I know this will vary depending on driving styles and surfaces but I’m interested to know what I’m likely to get as I budget for another set of these expensive tyres!i am currently on 10500 miles with what looks like quite a bit of tread left.Being 4 wheel drive should I expect to have to replace all four at the same time?i am more interested in the 2 litre versions as that’s what I have but it would also be interesting to know what the QVs get too

Name: wictod
Comment: Muz, not a good comparison but my Pirelli Scorpions went to 25K on the 280 Specialie before they were knackered.. coming from a GTV 3.0 which was eating the tyres I was amazed how long they were lasting on the Stelvio.. I went for Michellin Pilot 4 SUV on the replacements.

Name: Muz
Comment: I‘d love to think I could get that many miles! Fingers crossedMy TS GTV does so few miles, maybe 1k a year so I replace by age rather than wear! Just replaced the front tyres on my 2.4 159 Sportwagon and got 16000 from the last set, wear was all on the inside, the rest of the tyre had plenty of tread. Rears replaced at the same time as the fronts last time still have plenty of threadI was lucky to get 7k on my 3 litre 164 fronts, maybe my driving style has been reigned in over the years

Name: Rossorichie
Comment: I got 30k on the backs and 40k on the fronts on my Stelvio 2l Milano - I’ve just replaced the fronts with the same - the fitter who worked on the car remarked that I probably wouldn’t get the same mileage as the factory original ones. I didn’t quiz him why - very happy with the Michelin’s - good grip and excellent wear. I used to get around 12-15k with my 159 - I reckoned it cost me 10p a mile in tyres.

Name: mikesalfa
Comment: Really 2wd or 4wd should not make too much of a difference. Ideally the tyres are rotated around enough so that they all wear evenly. That includes using the spare wheel in the rotation if a car comes with a full size spare wheel. Then you will have all 5 to replace at the same time!Lots of smooth highway driving and you will get better mileage from tyres. Keeping them at the correct pressures, axle geometry correct will all help in ensuring even wear.But it's always a good idea to start saving. Some of those large SUV tyres are quite a significant sum.

Name: Lioni
Comment: Do the carpet mats provided with the vehicle come with any stain protection?

Name: mikesalfa
Comment: Unlikely. But often dealerships will offer various protections for a car. Ranging from exterior ceramic coatings to interior protection for fabric and leather. These are often done by a third party, so even if you are not buying from a dealership you will be able to get these done.You could always buy some extra fitted mats to have in the vehicle if you want to keep the originals in new condition. Or fit rubber mats if you often have dirty shoes. Or have a spray can and cloth of automotive upholstery cleaner handy in the car for emergencies.

Name: Lioni
Comment: Thanks. I guess I’ll just apply a stain protector (Scotchgard, etc).

Name: alfaitalia
Comment: The stain protection people that do our caravans wont do the carpets. They say that despite what anybody claims if you tread oil, dog poo, chewing gum etc etc into your carpets, no treatment in the world will protect them and prevent stains. So to avoid unreasonable claims the only do the exterior paintwork and upholstery.

Name: cue2
Comment: Having two sets works out best as you can alternate them and when one is in use the other can be thoroughly washed and dried.

Name: alfaitalia

Name: Skilaree
Comment: I have a MY 2021 Stelvio Veloce which has the phone charging thingy in the centre console. I was advised that the system uses the QI software to charge the phone and so, as I was overdue an upgrade, I got myself a Samsung Galaxy S20FE which supports QI charging. Over the weekend I went on a fairly long drive and thought I’d see how well the charging facility worked. So, as per the handbook advice, I put my phone screen down in the charging slot. An icon appeared on the screen which looked like a mobile phone with a red lightning strike inside and red radiation lines radiating from it. However, while driving the message ‘Foreign body in charging area’ (or words to that effect) appeared periodically on the display and when I arrived I found that the phone had not been charged at all.Any ideas where I’m going wrong?

Name: joephoto
Comment: The phone needs to have the screen face up, as the Qi charger needs to be in contact with the back of the phone, with the screen facing towards the storage box.

Name: Skilaree
Comment: Thanks for the response. However, and I quote from my handbook page 42:’WARNING Make sure you place the mobile correctly (display facing downwards) ……charging may not be enabled if it is in the wrong position.’So either the handbook is wrong or I have a fault.

Name: joephoto
Comment: The handbook (not surprisingly) is wrong. I have a 2021 Stelvio Ti with wireless charging, and while I have an iPhone 12 Pro Max and not a Samsung, wireless charging works perfectly when I place the phone in the wireless charger sceen side up.

Name: jwq
Comment: with my wireless charging pad, I also place my phone (samsung) face up, which works well and makes sense as you can then also see the percentage charged ....

Name: Skilaree
Comment: OK I will give it a go screen upwards and, if that works, I will tell Alfa their handbook is misleading. Thanks for the response.

Name: Skilaree
Comment: Ha ha, just tried it screen up as advised above. The lightning icon and radiation lines on the mobile phone icon are blue (not red as previously seen) and the advice that the mobile phone is being charged appears at the bottom of the screen. So thanks joephoto and jwq you’re absolutely correct and the handbook is wrong/misleading.

Name: joephoto
Comment: @Skilareeyou're welcome. Maybe a "translation" issue when the manual was translated from Italian to English. Cheers, mate.

Name: epsonix
Comment: thats not enough,europe maps won't go in until car is reprogrammed to europe market, and this will cause other issues like with driver side locks/fuel flap which require tweaks of looms otherwise never openning. NAFTA car is also other legality issues like rear stop lights with indicators (modifiy lamps or replace to european and reprogram behaviour), and issues with headlights legality (Assymetry, washers&leveling for 35W or manual leveling for 25W (not applicable to Stelvio which in US is only 35W as far as I know))

Name: mdowler8091
Comment: So, I am almost to the point of hooking my amps up to my 2019 Stelvio Sport. Before I finish up, what are some best practices I need to put in place for disconnecting and reconnecting the battery? I will have to do it to install the amps, but I know disconnecting and reconnecting can throw codes up. Do you hook a battery charger up to the posts under the hood so you aren't actually "disconnecting" power to the car? Just want to make sure I have my research done before I dig in.Thanks!

Name: wictod
Comment: Others may chip in but I wouldn't hook a battery charger up then disconnect the battery.. in my uneducated opinion, with all the IBS systems and other ECUs / CPUs you've more chance of it throwing up errors doing it that way. I have disconnected the battery from the detachable earth connector a couple of times for various reasons and haven't had any problems. Some warning lights have come up afterwards but they soon clear after a number of ignition start cycles. The only thing I do which I think is standard practice is to connected the positive terminal first then the earth..Cheers

Name: jwq
Comment: If you connect a battery charger to the connection points under the hood, then disconnect battery, you're kind of defeating the objective, i.e. making the car powerless whilst you work on it......Just disconnect the battery. Yes you will get errors on reconnecting, but that's no big deal. Most will disappear ater simple recalibraton of steering (car horizontal, contact on, turn steering end to end, then center). Any remaining ones are reset after 5 or so restarts.

Name: mdowler8091
Comment: Thanks for the info. I think I used the incorrect terminology. They make a "memory saver" that you can hook up that keeps your settings from getting lost when the battery is disconnected. Battery charger I think was the wrong word to say. As long as I will be ok to disconnect and reconnect without messing something up or having to take it to a dealer, then I can deal with working through the steering reset to fix the codes. With newer cars, never hurts to ask questions before digging in.

Name: alfaitalia
Comment: I used to have a little gadget with a 9v (smoke alarm size) battery in it. You plugged it into the ciggy lighter and it supplied just enough volts to keep the memory in the radio alive (useful if you dont know the code) and the ECU learned settings....which often needed to relearn on older cars after battery disconnection.....Not used it in years....still got it somewhere though!!

Name: jwq
Comment: On modern cars, it's almost all non-volatile memory though..... (and cigarette lighter is switched)

Name: Harvo
Comment: The sealant or tyre weld are going to do the same job and neither would have helped you in your situation as they only work for hole punctures on the contact surface of a tyre.Or put another way..... I think you were unlucky with the type and position of your puncture.

Name: GVblue
Comment: I know all that thanks, but I now have to replace the used sealant and I am just asking for views on whether to replace with the same or trust in a couple of pressurised cans instead, which should at least inflate the tyre much more quickly.It's been interesting reading all of the posts, well most of them anyway, but does any have any views, or better still, experience on goo versus pressurised goo.

Name: GVblue
Comment: Deman77 said:space saver spare is under 50mph max in straight line in the dry and you have to corner at very slow speeds especially in an suv. Your trip is almost certainly ruined and you have to go home and order a new tyre and wait for days to be back up and running. Car would be barely functional in the meantime. So all it does is saves you waiting for a tow.On non-qv where wheels are the same and if you don’t change to winters I would just buy a fifth wheel and rotate it through regularly (2k or so) to keep even wear on all 5. If you get a puncture you get a tow home (waiting in the rain under an umbrella or changing a wheel in the rain is about the same pain) and replace to the fifth one and order a new one. You are back on the road fully functional immediately and all your tyre are similar wear levels. When the new one arrives you rotate it in onto the corner that wears fastest and keep it in rotation until thread equalises with others.Gunk only works on thread puncture and not on tyre wall (tyre wall is always new tyre). If you do use it there is no repairing the tyre even if it does work. So that would be my last option. I would get a tow in first instance and try to see if tyre can get fixed.Click to expand...("Get a tow", a bit tricky with an all wheel drive automatic. Don't use the gunk. You can only do 50 mph with a space-saver.) - I think you may have just made the case for a space-saver wheel, one of which I would be delighted to have but I don't see how that would work as an after market option, but I haven't really investigated that option yet..

Name: Deman77
Comment: Lol. I guess I did.I don’t think this is the first awd auto they would be recovering so I wouldn’t worry.I would worry driving on a space saver though and I would only do it if you can get an Alfa own because you lay invalidate your insurance with anything else.I also would not like to have mismatched wear wheels on the car.

Name: MultiDoc
Comment: So out of interest, can we get a space saver wheel for the QV as an accessory through the dealer ? And it will fit in the boot fine? I guess it would also need a new “tub” under there to accommodate it. Anyone done it? Maybe a part number or a price ? 🤔

Name: Deman77
Comment: Don’t think anyone does space savers for high performance cars. You need to specifically develop, test and approve smth that can cope with staggered set up, high torque and weight. You then need to sell enough to recoup the development cost. You start with the few cars sold of which very few would want to pay extra and accept the extra weight penalty of wheel and Jack all the time to avoid recovery once in a blue moon.i carry electric pump in mine in case I get a screw or a nail with a slow puncture - the most common kind. Topping that up usually allows you to drive to nearest kwik fit for repair. It saved me with my big volvo last year when I picked up a screw driving around farm lanes in north Wales in between lockdowns.

Name: RJS463
Comment: MikeyRules said:Why is It always the same narrative on a lot of these threads either here or book of face? PSA will be the death of Alfa, All Alfa's will be bland re-boxed Peugeot's, Alfa electrics are sheet, electrification will kill the brand, nothing beats a Busso, Alfa shouldn't make SUV's blah blah blah. 9 times out of 10 comments made by people with a ''little'' bit of knowledge of everything, but all masters of non, all regurgitating each other like some pat on the back for having the same beliefs!Alfa are certainly no worse than any other brand... fact. No rose tinted glasses here, just over 30 years of Alfa ownership, with many miles driven as a lot of them have been used for business use too, regularly exceeding 30k annually... and no I'm not blinkered either, so also like other brands tooYes model choice has been stark for at least the last decade, and some of the driving dynamics could have been better, certainly on 939 series cars onwards, but certainly nothing terrible. (Obviously now fixed with the Giorgio platform granted).Like it or not survival for many brands has been consolidation with others giving them access to economy of scale, platform and technology share. Everything will be electric as we're all rapidly taxed out of fossil fuels, and fuel stations as we know them today close everywhere.I'm not sure if it's just a British thing to always see the glass half empty, and run things into the ground at every opportunity? But for me I'm excited that there's a future for Alfa. I'm intrigued and full of anticipation to see what cars come in the next decade given that COO have time-stamped the brands turnaround and created a whole new UK and European team to make things happen.Click to expand...Good to get it off your chest 😄

Name: Deman77
Comment: Always cash or zero % finance if available after I agreed cash price. if extra discount without finance I treat it as interest and will take the discount. If I can’t afford it for cash I adjust my appetite. I can’t get my head around paying interest on top of depreciation. When I look at the numbers, the structure of car finance vs what secured finance costs in the wholesale market and the fact that it does not discriminate by quality of the borrower I just have no interest for that - it’s a robbery.

Name: cue2
Comment: 0% interest is a marketing expenditure by the car company. Discounts reduce to cover it. If you get a deal with a pcp you can pay off lump sums until the monthly payment is around £100 and save money. That’s what I’ve done with my Stelvio.

Name: Deman77
Comment: I also took fca finance because it was giving me an extra cash credit after Beechdale maxed out and said only pre-reg would be cheaper and I could get finance to 0% by pushing the sliders to extremes. Someone pays me to sit on my cash for a couple of years? Sure.

Name: Moonraker21
Comment: All,I am a long time lurker but joined formally now.I am on my second Stelvio. My first was a 18 plate Misano Blue Milano Diesel and I now have an Anodised Blue Veloce Petrol (280) 21 plate so count me hooked.I was hoping to use the Send & GO feature in the My Alfa Connect app to set up the navigation on my iPhone and then send it to the car sat nav like I did with BMW X3 (before the first Stelvio) but it looks like it is coming soon - unless I have missed something?

Name: Deman77
Comment: Don’t think I came across it in mine. But it’s academic - no car sat nav will come close to google maps or Waze. I guess in other cars there may be upside of seeing directions from integrated satnav on HUD but otherwise I don’t see the point. Just set up your journey on your iPhone plug it into the usb and it will be navigating.Let’s see some pictures of the old and the new.

Name: jwq
Comment: The advantage of car nav is that it also uses the inbuilt sensors for distance traveled, speed, direction and map matching, so not fully dependant on GPS(and bigger screen of course)

Name: jwq
Comment: It's actually a missed opportunity by Alfa. The navigation part of the infotainment is actually from TomTom and TomTom was one of the first to use the wireless info from other TomTom units via inbuilt mobile for realtime traffic info.Alfa however did not implement this. Of course initially the giulia/stelvio did not have wireless connectivity, however, they could have used connected mobiles, as TomTom does in some of their stand-alone units. However, Alfa opted for the lesser system using RDS-TMC, which works, but gives less info.

Name: jwq
Comment: afaik, it uses best guess. With loss of GPS It just uses avarage speed and direction over last period to predict where the car currently is.... It goes wrong if f.i. there's a turn-off in the tunnel, or a sharp corner. Granted doesn't happen very often

Name: Deman77
Comment: Fair enough. For me to get real quality of routing I go to calimoto but they are not on carplay yet. I find the gui is good enough in just about any nav solution but the real differentiation is traffic info quality and accuracy of ETA. I don’t see how anyone can compete with google/Waze there (it updates in real time - I saw my wait time in long temp traffic light queue changing as I was waiting as it must have been releasing cars in front and calculating when I will pass it). They are also give you very accurate “usual traffic” based predictions for future journeys for when you want to set departure reminders. It works very well around London where traffic is very directional and is highly time of the day dependant.

Name: mikesalfa
Comment: I think phones can pair with a lot of things. It's the things they pair with are the limiting factor. A car might only be able to pair with 5 devices, a soundbar or portable speaker might be able to pair with 3 devices for instance.If it is a used car, there might be the previous owners phones still paired. Although usually when pairing a new device the oldest, or least used existing device is unpaired automatically.Is your wives phone paired to both the Stelvio and Giulia?

Name: alfaitalia
Comment: Since the Android 11 update my car wont stay connected to my ALFA at all. A problem which had generated literally thousands of internet threads in multiple forums. Name: Fedz
Comment: Hi everyone, just become a proud owner of an Alfa Stelvio 2019 and my first impressions of the vehicle during the first 3 months were fantastic but they are now becoming more of a disappointment due to a number of annoying issues. Firstly, after about two weeks of ownership the stop/start ceased to operate and has not worked since even though the parameters for the system to work appear to be met which I am now going to pursue with the dealership as I believe it is a battery issue which requires replacement and the vehicle is still under warranty. Anyone faced a similar problem and had success under warranty? Secondly, and most frustrating is trying to update the maps via the Mopar website and even after following their guidelines for the download when placing the usb flash drive into any of the usb front ports in the car I receive the same message " The usb device has no valid map updates" even though map updates have been stored on the device. I have downloaded in all the suggested formats NTFS and exFAT and opened zip folders as recommended on Mopar site but still get the same message. Can anyone help please as this now becoming a real pain in the backside.

Name: cue2
Comment: Start Stop issues? Did you buy the car used? The thing could‘ve sat in stock for quite a while over lockdowns etc and a battery never recovers after it’s discharged a couple of times.

Name: stevemacqueen
Comment: Make sure you have an AGM battery fitted and not an EFB. You should be able swing this under warranty.

Name: jwq
Comment: during some time shortly ago, there was a problem with the offered maps on the Mopar website. However, be aware there is a whole load of parameters that can stop the system activating, see :

Name: stevemacqueen

The AA sorted it and I've no problem since then. Messing about with the Stelvio infotainment system is not for me!

Name: cue2

Name: alfaitalia
Comment: I think "Volume Related Bonus" is almost a thing of the past anyway. Even when I was selling cars it had almost gone with any bonuses being based around operating standards......so showroom presentation, mystery shoppers (phone and visit), car handover procedure etc etc. When VRB was used (if we were a couple of units short of target) it would often mean selling one or two cars at the end of the quarter for less than cost....worth doing to get the extra percentage on every car sold in that quarter. That could be worth many thousands. I don't know about Alfa but my friend works at Middleton FIAT.....and most of the bonus is based on quality not quantity. The only exception being promotional models or Limited Editions that they try to get pushed through fast.

Name: photoman

Name: Deman77
Comment: If june21 and a well known issue nothing to do with wear I’d expect good will for free. If dealer pushes back escalate to Alfa CS.

Name: JTD_Liam
Comment: Happened to one or two people with Giulia's too. I recently suggested someone contact Alfa Customer Service, which he did and they suggested they'd offer goodwill. Others have had replacement units under warranty.Here's the thread (ignore the slightly misleading title)8.8" display failure | Alfa Romeo Forum (alfaowner.com)

Name: JTD_Liam
Comment: Sounds dodgy that it came back on when you pressed the brake, could just be coincidental as you say, but I'd monitor it over the next week or two and if it happens again I'd not try to fix it myself (even by disconnecting the battery) - I'd just phone Alfa CS & the nearest decent dealer and let them look at it. Some people have had the fault never re-appear for others it's been the start of a permanent failure, so just see how you go, but the younger the car when the fault is reported, the better chance you have of goodwill I imagine.

Name: Andre F-G
Comment: Hi everyone I'm new to this site and AAlfa Romeos a bit of advice I have just got myself a 2017 (sep) Stelvio 2.2 Q4 and it was running 002.009.43 and although everything seemed ok when I installed/connected my iphone 8 I keeped losing my contacts and predialled were coming up as mumbers only so I aked my local dealer and they said they will upgrade it but it may or may not fix it and it would cost £ 250.00 to do it, so looking on your site Alfaowner I came across some updates one being 002.009.55 so I bit the bullet and tried it,so after downloading it on a stick I then installed it ....Great everything seems to work but I then notice that there seems to be a more recent update 002.009.59 what do I do , 1. leave it a lone or 2. download that and install.Alfa Romeo's support said only download anything if there's a problem in other words you don't need to up date your car!!! Advice from those of you out there that have more expertise than me cheers AndrePS love the car.

Name: Jambo
Comment: if its not broken for you any more - leave it alone - it may be a completely harmless installation, but perhaps something goes wrong - if it is working for what you want now, then there is no reason to update it again....just my humble opinion

Name: jwq
Comment: See:infotainment updateslatest version for your old hardware is 002.010.043, which fixes some bugs.....

Name: Andre F-G
Comment: Thank you both Jambo & jwq now I see theres even a later update 002.010.043 , maybe it's safe to leave well alone although I would like too know what other bugs need sorting!

Name: jwq
Comment: With the update files you also find the pdf files describing the cummulative issues adressed by the relevant update, example for 002.010.043 :Relevant description File(s):description_002_010_043.pdfService news Italian 002_010_043.pdfNote: according to Italian service news above not for Australia and New Zealand

Name: Andre F-G
Comment: thank you so in general is it better just to update as they are released

Name: jwq
Comment: Comes down to personal preferance.....My take is that these updates are introduced for a reason, so for myself I usually go for the latest.....In this case it's been out for a while, and proven to work

Name: Andre F-G
Comment: once again I appreciate your thoughts and I'll follow your lead

Name: stevemacqueen
Comment: Have a second hand Dec 2018 Milano 20k miles. Love it and everything works perfectly.Have read of battery problems with the Stelvio.Service record shows battery was replaced in Oct 2020. I wonder why?It's marked AF and Varta 666052 RA HDVarta won't answer any queries and their customer service is zeroCan anyone tell me whether this is an AGM or EFB battery please?It was supplied by an independent dealer so I don't know if it was a warranty job or not.

Name: cue2
Comment: It’s a shame when cars get out of the brand network as there are things that they would know about them. Our Toyota IQ was fitted with a new battery before we collected it and when there was a paint issue at 8 years old the car was fully repainted like new. I’m sure had we bought one from a non Toyota dealer neither of these things would have happened.whether an Alfa dealer would replace the battery of a car that had been in stock a while, I’m not sure. I suppose if people refer to them as “stealers” I would not blame them if they waited instead of doing anything preemptive!

Name: jwq
Comment: very roughly, with Varta start/stop batteries, if it has a blue top it's EFB, Silver top is AGMAs standard the cars came from the factory with an EFB battery. When replacement was/is necessary, most people go for AGM as they take charge better, and are more resistant to deep discharge etcseeVarta car batteries

Name: Deman77
Comment: I wouldn’t worry about battery having been replaced. It’s one of the more common issues that affects many modern cars. If it was used in stop start traffic a lot with ss npt disabled the battery would have had a pretty hard life so it’s good to have a new one. There is a small chance you have a current leak that knackered it but if you do you will find out pretty soon.fit a Bluetooth monitor on it to catch it before it discharges if the car has a current leak problem and have a peace of mind. It’s a 5min job on a Stelvio and a £20.

Name: stevemacqueen
Comment: Thanks to all for your comments. I am just curious as to whether it's AGM of EFB . It starts ok even after a month unused in the winter and holds it's charge.Do a lot of short journeys so I switch off the stop start, which I dislike anyway.Had a Guiletta a few years ago and AF replaced the battery under warranty because the stop start hardly ever worked so it's got me thinking.

Name: stevemacqueen
Comment: Right, if ain't broke don't fix it. However I am 91 and neurotic.. If it is AGM I'll sleep better and definately won't bother. To be or EFB, that is the question. If it is EFB, I'll mull it over and probably won't bother. I used to be indecisive now I just can't make up my mind!

Name: cue2
Comment: My battery went flat a couple of months ago from lack of use and a customer services van arrived very rapidly, charged it up and it’s been ok since. The mechanic said that as long as the same doesn’t happen three times a battery is fine. I don’t use the car enough for Start/Stop to function but all seems fine. He said he’d been called out to a Stelvio where the owner thought that the car was going to break on their first drive as they hadn’t had the Ackerman effect explained to them.

Name: jwq
Comment: Alfie155 said:Took my Milano for its year 2 service yesterday, mentioning that the stop/start hasn't worked for a year even after driving 1400 miles in 10 days, so could I have a new battery please?In short, No! They wanted to keep it overnight for a full charge to see what's going on.I asked them to show me exactly how to offer up my battery charger as I know there's issues about disconnecting leads from the car and the ibs etc.Basically, I was told to disconnect the ibs sensor and connect the charger to the battery, no need to disconnect any terminals or find an earthing point.So far so good. However the manual says to leave the ibs connected. The dealer says that can generate all the usual warning light issues but that is avoided by disconnecting the ibs although it can take 4 hours to reset itself. As it turned out I couldn't disconnect the ibs - I was fearful of being too brutal with it.I don't particularly miss the stop start although it can be useful, but I have to present the car with a full charge in order to get the DNA software update.Anyone else tried that suggested approach?Click to expand...Hardly anybody (no one?) disconnects IBS to charge battery, far too much chance of damaging something.You can simply charge the battery without disconnecting anything, won't give any problems. Just make sure negative current goes through the IBS, there are many threads on here showing how. Basically connecting negative charge lead to chassis will suffice.Another easy way is to simply connect the charge leads to the jumpstart terminals under the hood/bonnet

Name: Isotope
Comment: I had an Ackermann Giulia but I thought Alfa had given up on that last year due to so many complaints, will my MY2021 Stelvio still have that geometry because I've not noticed it yet but only had the car 10 days!

Comment: If you do it will still be tyre and temperature dependant. Mine only does it on pz4 sub 10C. Winters don’t scrub. If you have more of a touring tyre on veloce it may not show up even with sporty geometry.

Name: Deman77
Comment: Don’t bother with that. IBS sensor is inside the loop if you fit it to the most obvious negative fitting point on Stelvio battery so you will have no issues. Just clip it to the battery.

Name: Deman77
Comment: Mine lights up when it estimates 50mi (that’s consumption based - once it was one tick below half, sometimes it’s a couple of ticks from the bottom) and then beeps again and possibly different light colour below 20. Below 10 it stops estimating remaining range - just a dash. If your 50 or 20 or 10 is based on some spirited driving - say low teens in QV or low 20s in 2.0 you can actually stretch that range to 2 or even 3 times that by going into A, babying accelerator, staying in high gears and anticipating slowing down so you are not using brakes - obviously cold start would bite hard into that. I recall seeing some bars in 50s looking at my consumption chart the other day - think 8th gear steady at 40 on a flat road.

Name: kgb
Comment: little late night thinkingProblem with manual trans. is that the car can not stop itself... 6th gear driving at 130km at 2000rpm...the radar detects a car a front of you...slows down...the car a front comes to a stop...at around 1000rpm your engine ecu will try to prevent the engine from stalling so injection more fuel...but ACC will try to stop the car...most probably the ABS ecu will prevail.... :titanic:

Name: niegowic
Comment: kgb said:A little guide of how to install it:DO IT AT YOUR OWN RISK.Well first you need the steering wheel buttons with ACC button EPER part number is: 156130459also you need to have the front radar and camera, the procedure is the same for the Giulia0. If you don't want to remove the battery power it is best to leave your key away from the car so it doesn't go into standby mode. Also if you car has SGW you will need a few additional steps.1. You need to remove your steering wheel airbag. There is a clip accessible from the bottom of the airbag with a flat screw driver..you press it with the screw driver and then the airbag should come off. They are cables attached to the airbag so be careful and you also should remove them.2. Disconnect all cables.3. Remove steering wheel from the car, will be much easier to work this way. Then unscrew the 3 screws on the back...one behind each buttons panel and one in the bottom of the steering wheel. Then working on the bottom part of the steering wheel you need to detach the plastic cover that looks like aluminum using a a plastic screw driver for clips or something similar BUT becareful not to damage the leather on the steering wheel. They are two big plastic clips almost in the middle of the steering wheel located below the airbag. Carefully detach them.4. Once you have the plastic cover removed you can remove the buttons. Maybe it is a good idea to install the red start stop button if you want, at this time. Buttons have their own wiring so be careful with that as well. Take your time and don't rush ,it is not a very hard job.5. Replace buttons with the new ones. Then put everything back together.6. Connect Multiecuscan to your ABS and check that you have your steering wheel at 0.00degrees7. Turn on the car without starting the engine, connect Multiecuscan (MES) and go to Proxi alignment.8. In the part where you see that you have the cruise control enabled...disable it. Go to to adaptive cruise control and enable it.9. Do the proxi alignment. It is best to use Wifi Cantier interface (meaning latest version of the interface that has both wifi and BT) with MES as ELM327 or other interfaces might fail at some modules.10. When the proxi alignment finishes you will have error codes in some ECUs and you need adaptation of the ABS ecu. At this point the car is in safety mode and you won't be able to move it!!! Don't freak out. BUT for just in case everything goes to ****, park the car somewhere where it can stay until the tow truck comes.11. Go to ABS ecu and go to parameters. Check that steering wheel is at 0.00 degress meaning 100% in the center not turn left or right...then go to adjustments and do steering wheel reset.12. After that do a brake pressure reset.13. Also do YAW sensors reset.14. Delete DTCs erros in the ABS unit15. Switch off the car and wait a few mins.16. Turn on the car again and go to engine ecu delete DTCs there as well. After the proxi alignment is finished you will have erros in many ecus. (your engine might start to shake a little....don't freak outin most cases it doesn't. Thing is that engine is loosing connection to ABS unit, to say it short and some other stuff.17. After deleting dtc in engine ecu go to all other ecu and delete errors as well.18. Switch off the car and wait.19. Turn on the car press the cruise control and acc buttons and look at the display to see if the icons do appear.20. Find a nice road and with a friend of front of you try the ACC and learn how it works... also read the owners manual before that.21. Always look at the road ahead and be prepared to brake.22. Enjoy your rides an be safep.s: for pictures go tohttps://www.stelvioforum.com/forum/...uise-control-acc-installation.html#post116975Click to expand...I got a spare steering wheel with the proper module installed but I have noticed it doesn't have 3rd cable for heating.. do you think it will throw errors if I connect the steering wheel and don't connect this additional cable? I would prefer quick option just replace the steering wheel and for now just ignore the heating

Name: kgb
Comment: Not sure, but I think it won't give any errors. Especially if you don't turn the steering wheel heating on

Name: paulryan1234
Comment: epsonix said:giuliavpart number would differ as buttons do not have hill descent. go tokeyeper.pekidi.comand find right one for acc opion.on polish forum one of my colleagues has activated acc in giulia super 2016, all works ok.now the issue bit. first, if you have car manufactured 31.01.2018 or newer you have security gateway so with MES currently you cant activate ACC. you can buy bypass, soon i open internet shop and i will have such at decent price - a few minutes install.then other issue is that in march 2019 there was service recall for safety reasons related to misbehaviour of acc. it is BSM module update to firmware version 8541(probably only very recent cars have this version out of factory), unfortunatell from my recent experience older cars without acc option in FCA database (sales code for ACC) do not get update (Im on ver 8401 still).the way to get update is to have good relation with dealer and ask him to add acc sales code against your vin. if you have this, then you should get update and dealer also should be able to activate acc with their witech2 tool (possibly reset car config and do proxi i guess), and then you do not need SGW bypass and MES.Click to expand...HiThanks for your reply. Greatly appreciated.I've got a price of £80.76 for the Giulia specific buttons.My car is Jan 2017 build so thankfully no security gateway.Thanks for the heads up on the BSM module. I might take a chance on the retrofit and then try and persuade the dealer to apply the updated sales code

Name: epsonix
Comment: paulryan1234 said:HiThanks for your reply. Greatly appreciated.I've got a price of £80.76 for the Giulia specific buttons.My car is Jan 2017 build so thankfully no security gateway.Thanks for the heads up on the BSM module. I might take a chance on the retrofit and then try and persuade the dealer to apply the updated sales codeClick to expand...Jan 2017 may have some very old BSM firmware. There is much more complicated procedure to update old firmwares for BSM, Witech shows some older update, then reset of car config is needed, then Witech see newer car update (to 8401), and only after this newest 8541 can by uploaded. There are some other more minor things to do on the way (including calibrations/resets of sensors). It is all described in service news for the recall, though I have limited trust to guys in services, so woudl be worth to make sure they are aware of the procedure, follow it up and you see as end result firmware version 8541 (it is displayed on first tab in BSM when you access via Witech (or MES) as well as while they do update, it is also visible in some comments or maybe update number (as part of it).

Name: epsonix
Comment: not aware except that e.g. 2.2d can go up to ECU rev 1091, 2.0s (without GPF, as these has different sofware stream) to SW number G543xxxxx rev 0000 ABS/BSM is upgradable to rev 8401 (but with proxi restor in the middle and rev 8B0B), BCM to 724 (on Q maybe 718 only) IPC to 203C or 2038 depends on hardware etc. Some updates may be tied with newest infotainment firmare (seems like the case on MV051 - MV059 after upgrading to at least MV072; maybe on 1st gen radios after upgrading to MV002.010.041), so get it updated first and open more updates of other ECUs.

Comment: Yes I have 2.2l diesel 110kw. As I plan to remap ECU with Sedox software so this one will be rewritten once it is done ?epsonix said:nope - I just checked mid 2017 ePer list 7 but you have repeats for various set of options and so really 3 types of windshields only there:50555500 WINDSCREEN !57J + !NH3 + 55B + LA1 150555500 WINDSCREEN !57J + 55B + LA1 + NH3 150555500 WINDSCREEN !57J + !LA1 + !NH3 + 55B 150555501 WINDSCREEN 55B + 57J + LA1 + NH3 150555501 WINDSCREEN !LA1 + !NH3 + 55B + 57J 150555501 WINDSCREEN !NH3 + 55B + 57J + LA1 150555502 WINDSCREEN !55B + !57J + !LA1 + !NH3 1Option 57J is IR filter, NH3 is ACC, 55B is over-run protection and LA1 is Lane departure warning; of course !xxx means without such option.As you see option NH3 may be with 50555500 or 50555501 windshields and the difference between both is first without IR filter, 2nd with. 3rd part number is base model likely for non EU (as we always have LDW).Dealer servicemans are not the source of reliable information usually, especially if you start talking about non-standard things like retrofits. Also, likely just lack of proper time spending on this from him, he noticed that depends on ACC option, but didn't check that the same number is for with and without ACC.Click to expand...

Name: Deman77

I think the cheap way would be to get an elasticated load net, hook two hooks under that plastic that is covering the latch (the boot floor cover should hold them there nicely. twist it a bit to create tension and hook the other two hooks into the handle of the load cover once it’s loaded and closes. Name: Deman77
Comment: I’ll rephrAse - Significantly less ugly than other SUVs. I found loading heavy stuff into higher SUV floor to be easier than with an estate where you have to be more bent over whilst holding heavy items. So not easier. Better dynamics and ride quality are the advantages of an estate. With all the same 4wd and equipment there will be no weight saving just lower down. You would still have no wading capability which means higher chance of hydrolocked engines especially with heavy turbocharging. I get regular flash floods around here - suv is not totally useless.

Name: Deman77
Comment: I think they give harsher ride which is weird seeing as part of the reason Suv has harsher ride than an estate is because it has to stabilise weight higher up.as unsporty as it may feel that high driving position definitely makes the car more usable for non-track spirited driving as you get to see a lot more road imperfections well in advance.

Name: cue2
Comment: Chippex process is good. The Stelvio is no different to other cars except alloy doors , wings and tailgate.

Name: RJS463
Comment: Thanks cue2, I must just be unlucky with this car. I’ve also had 2 punctures in this short time too. I’d previously only had 3 punctures in circa 500,000 miles of driving over the previous 25 years.

Name: RJS463
Comment: tiffersno2 said:I use Chipex, and as long as you have realistic expectations, it is easy and quick to use, and was a good colour match for Alfa Rosso Red. It is particularly good for a rash of small chips, that you can dab paint on, and blend and polish all together, moving quickly. Large chips or scratches are more difficult to get a good result on.There are plenty of videos of people using/reviewing Chipex on YouTube, and this is a good example:Touching up will never be as good as sanding and respraying, but if I don't wear my glasses or look too closely, the front of my 10 year old Giulietta is still pleasing to the eye.Click to expand...thanks, I’ve seen that video, wasn’t impressed with his results but I think with more care and a few application, I will get the results. I was interested if there is any other product apart from ChipEx that people are using. I’ve watched a couple of USA videos that include wet sanding but I don’t really want to go down that road for stone chips.

Name: savannahsister
Comment: My rear discs looked blue so my husbands had a look. Seems the parking brake won't come off. We've only had it since November, it has been driving fine so I wonder if it's been like that all along? Can this be right?

Name: Deman77
Comment: If both of them are discoloured and it’s rears parking brake seems like a good suspect. At the same time, I can’t imagine you wouldn’t notice your car grinding through stuck parking brake.also I think parking brake doesn’t cover the whole disc. If discolouration is the whole disc then brake pads more likely.Can you post a photo?

Name: savannahsister
Comment: Exactly, thats what I kept saying. Anyway we spent a while testing and it looks like the parking brake is indeed working ok. We are changing pads and discs today, and yes it's the whole disc. Thanks for the reply.

Name: metalgod23
Comment: I presume the discs and pads are being covered under warranty but the fact that the discs looked overheated means a seized brake caliper most likely. What is being done to address the root cause of the problem and investigate why it stuck on and if it is not the caliper what caused the issues? These are the questions I would ask the dealership/garage.

Name: GVblue
Comment: Isn't that just the QV?

Name: GVblue
Comment: As I read it, both discs are discoloured, so both calipers must be siezed?Brake by wire issue?I am asking that question on the basis that I have absolutely no understanding whatsoever of how that system operates.

Name: Deman77
Comment: Exactly my point. If it was just seized calliper it would be one side only unless some firmware problem. I would imagine smth on software side overusing rear brakes.

Name: alfaitalia
Comment: More than one husband?!....between them they should be able to fix it!!

Name: Deman77
Comment: Are you surprised? She drives an Alfa.

Name: metalgod23
Comment: I speed read and hadn't flagged that it was both rear discs. The ESC system uses the rear brake calipers for what you could call as a cheap pseudo differential, perhaps it is over using the brakes wrongly but either way you should feel something off when driving due to simple fact that friction causes you to slow down or affects braking. They need to investigate what causes it. It could still be a slightly sticky parking brake which also uses the rear caliper in the standard Giulia and Stelvio. Only the Quadrifoglio models have a separate parking brake caliper. The fact that it is both rear discs makes me suspect a parking brake issue as the command for both is from the same switch.

Name: welshboyo
Comment: I acquired my Stelvio 20 plate in November 2020 but didn't get an activation e-mail from the main dealer. Eventually I got round to contacting Alfa Service via e-mail to ask how to do this. I received a call from Italy within 24 hours which gave me all the information I needed to activate, together with a confirmation e-mail to confirm my details. once I sent this back I got another call from Anna in Milan and now it is all connected. Just thought I would post this because we are all good at complaining but I thought this service was really good.

Name: Muz
Comment: I’ve found them very good with general queries but a bit rubbish with problems

Name: cue2
Comment: The only cause to call Alfa Service was when the battery went flat from lack of use followed by opening tailgate. Help arrived very rapidly.

Name: Muz
Comment: A question to those that also have oneI guess my car does about 20-25 mins mixed driving every couple of days. When I get back from a run the battery shows anything between 60 and 75 % charged and around 12.5 to 12.6V and all is blue. The following morning it always goes red and says low power with around 12.2 to 12.3 and around 37 to 54% Is this normal or do I have a dodgy battery?

Name: Muz
Comment: Deman77 said:Have you tried ctek on yours just to see what voltage it will show on maxes out?Mine is 95ah battery so may be slightly different from yours. After ctek or very long drive it would be 13.02v. After mid drive like yours mine shows 12.75-12.85 depending if it used “the strategy” or not. Next day this drops 0.25, then 0.15, then 0.08then 0.05 then stabilises at 0.03-0.04 per day.so yours doesn’t look unreasonable.I wouldn’t rely on the gadget interpretation of SoC. it is one for all. It simply converts voltages. Just rely on raw voltages data. If you see it drop into low 12s or below 12 in less than a week then you have trouble.Click to expand...Thanks, very helpful. I used the Ctek about a week before I bought the battery monitor and haven’t used it since. It was the slipping into low battery and red that concerned me but all looks good from the chart Alfaitalia posted. The voltage monitor has never dropped below 12

Name: alfaboeing
Comment: Any Quad owners had an issue with the gearbox. No battery issues at all with car but this morning unexpectedly juddered followed by numerous faults on dash this morning on a busy junction. Pulled over. Turned off then went to restart no power to shift lever. Had to get roadside to manually release park mode on zf gearbox from under the car using a pin to put it into neutral to get onto flatbed then get it towed. Engine won’t start due to fault, many errors. Very random as has been faultless for two years, stop start works and heated rear window so not a battery problem. Calling Alfa breakdown they have no idea about Alfa Topcare which comes with the Guilia/ stelvio quads which guarantees a replacement vehicle at the roadside when broken down.
