Stuck it in car and pointed the Milano down the A3 and the update worked first time after about 40 mins.To be honest I can't actually see any difference but obviously haven't done much mileage to put it to the test.Click to expand...Worked fine for me using Edge...Always to a full reformat of the card before copying overWorks first time every time following this.

Name: Muz
Comment: I have looked online and there are guides but not clear and obvious enough for me to risk screwing something up on the electrics.Does anyone have simple to read photos/diagrams as to where the leads bolt on. The last car it was on was a 97 model car and it was very simple. I have a feeling it’s not quite as simple on the Stelvio as it has so many cables connected to the battery.I have a feeling that I may need pigtails with bigger connectors too?Thanks in advance!

Name: Muz
Comment: Brilliant, thank you

Name: Muz
Comment: Thanks, that looks much more like my battery area than the previous photo on this thread.So definitely ok to use positive and negative on the battery as the fixing points? I’m sure I saw something online about not connecting direct to the negative as it will interfere with battery monitoring.What you have posted looks very simple and what I would have done but for the worry of interfering with the battery monitoring.Apologies if the above is all a bit thick

Name: jwq
Comment: Muz said:Thanks, that looks much more like my battery area than the previous photo on this thread.So definitely ok to use positive and negative on the battery as the fixing points? I’m sure I saw something online about not connecting direct to the negative as it will interfere with battery monitoring.What you have posted looks very simple and what I would have done but for the worry of interfering with the battery monitoring.Apologies if the above is all a bit thickClick to expand...The first (my) pictures refer to giulia, however, battery connections are the same.You need to be carefull NOT to directly connect to negative of the battery, as this would bypass the IBS sensor, hence my suggestion to just connect negative to chassis/ground, that way you can't go wrong.Note the positive connection in both pictures is actually the sameThe ground post in 2nd picture should also be ok, however, the nut can be very hard to loosen, and I believe you would need a bigger eyelett as standard supplied

Name: Muz
Comment: Thanks, there is nowhere obvious to connect the negative to the bodywork on the Stelvio, as you have done on the Giulia, the whole area is covered in what I assume is polystyrene

Name: Muz
Comment: Connected and working, thanks both 🤙

Name: Deman77

Name: Deman77
Comment: Stop start thing is worth it too if just for the comfort of driving.It does not disable it, it just changes button behaviour so it starts in off position every time. If you are in a slow stop start queue and you know you have good 20min of drive afterwards to recharge the battery it makes sense to enable it so you just press the button. You can also reverse that default button behaviour through the predefined series of button presses.

Comment: I have just discovered that I can change the wipers without constantly banging the arm against the bonnet below the wiper arms.For any of you who don’t know about this rather nifty inbuilt function:Start the car, turn it off, set the windscreen wipers to off. Name: Navlet
Comment: The battery is certainly flat which will cause all sorts of error codes to be thrown up.As has been said before the charging logic of the car (and many others) is aimed more at keeping emissions low rather than maintaining a healthy state of charge.Thats why many of us have SS always off and do a period charge with a CTek battery charger to top it upto 100% which will be virtually impossible to do by driving alone.It could be that the immobilser is drawing too much quiescent current and making the situation even worse.Hopefully a fully charged battery will resolve your issue.

Name: wictod
Comment: yeah I think the handbook says 32 Front 34 Back , only reason I'm querying it is because these are XL versions (extra load). some say to get the benefit of the reinforced sidewall they need to be inflated higher? if at normal pressure you get no benefit from the sidewall and apparently the tyre squishes moreif it's all BS then no worries I'll drop the pressure down a bit more. Cheers

Name: duemila
Comment: You could be right on the pressures, its not just the sidewall thats reinforced, could be under the tread too, does the manual reference xl pressures?

Name: duemila
Comment: I would go with the full load pressures if it were me

Name: wictod
Comment: Yep cheers,,, think that's a good idea..

Name: duemila
Comment: ok you got me thinking as I have extra load too on my Giulietta, so I phoned Michelin and they said you can run the same pressure, extra load just means they can take more than the rating on the tyre, how much more not sure, but I guess that means if you're fully loaded the tyres will handle the weight better than a regular tyre,

Name: wictod
Comment: duemila, Thanks for that info... reassuring coming from the horse mouth so to speak.. I think I'll back them off a bit as they feel ok running the pressures I mentioned, only when going over a speed bump you notice it's a bit firm. Name: Isotope
Comment: The recent snow falls in the Giulia, made in for some interesting driving. At one point I couldn't even get the car backed up on my drive and it's just a lowered kerb, so an incline of about 4 inches. I'm looking at a Stelvio and wonder how you guys find the Q4 system? My problem is I am very old and back in the day all my cars were RWD, so I thought I was a pretty good adopter of them hence the Giulia, 30 years later after every car being FWD I'm in an RWD car and I can't believe how much more confident a FWD car feels, I love smashing down the ridge in the road and even overtaking other cars in the snow in an FWD car. Does the Stelvio Q4 system inspire that sort of confidence? I would be very interested in anyone that may have had a similar experience, maybe going from FWD to Q4 without the RWD experience?

Name: cue2
Comment: It comes into use in a tiny fraction of a second and seemed to straighten things up pretty well in the snow a couple of times for me.

Name: wictod
Comment: I have that experience and it's not that good.. drove a GTV for 18 years before the Stelvio...ok it's not a problem going forwards in drive, holds a good line and you can make it step out a bit as well but the real hassle is trying to stop the car.... in packed snow crawling along in queue of traffic I found as soon as you touch the brake .. the ABS starts juddering and then you get this weird little slide forward when the brakes engage..

Name: Isotope
Comment: Wictod, So does the Stelvio still feel like a RWD in the slippy conditions? We have another FWD car and it just ripped along the road, smashing down the ridge in the road for other drivers to not worry about! I'm hoping a Stelvio Q4 can do the same when not in RWD only mode?

Name: wictod
Comment: Isotope, having driven the 916 GTV for ever as mentioned I have no experience of a 100% rear wheel drive... you can get the back to twitch but it transfers the drive to the front I believe.. I haven't pushed my luck in testing it to be honest but I felt very comfortable going forwards..

Name: cue2
Comment: Going down hill is going to be difficult without the ability to regain control of the cars direction. The same with braking as the Q4 is only of use when power is being put down.The Stelvio is still way lighter than a Porsche Macan or Caynine. The Cayenne Coupe weighs 25% more than a Stelvio Quadrifoglio.

Name: Isotope
Comment: Deman77 said:From what you described you should just be getting a set of winter tyres.q4 will only give you better traction on the limit and only where it comes to power application (not with braking). Winter tyre will extend that limit very significantly.another consideration with Stelvio is what you are compromising by going with Stelvio. Firmer springs to control heavier car that is also sat higher means less flowing and more fidgety ride. More body movement too. Heavier car means lower power to weight ratio on same engine so 90% of times where you do not struggle for grip it will accelerate slower. Heavier car can carry less speed through the corner when they are both balanced (q4 will only be faster where you are powering through on limit of grip which is either very aggressive or more often you are not cornering correctly). Heavier car wears tyres, brakes, suspension more ands stops slower.I’d say for qv it is worth it to extend car usability into winter as 500 on rear axle with 1.5 ton giulia you just won’t be able to enjoy it in the wet and cold unless you race cars for a living if you have fully developed frontal lobe and understand that on normal roads there are a lot of things outside your control so pushing limits is taking chances. For sub 300bhp power you will really need to try to provoke it for that power to be a problem. More often it is be too much speed into the corner which q4 will not help you with.Click to expand...Your quote about winter tyres is probably valid, just not a mindset I've considered having no issues with FWD cars for so long and the last couple of winters have been very mild in the UK and certainly cheaper than a new car! What would anyone reccomend, Michelin cross climates, or a proper dedicated set of wheels?

Name: wictod
Comment: Maximus84, Through my own experience, if the battery is duff then it doesn't matter whether the CTEK has completed it charge or not. Best thing to do once it's finished charging is to measure the charge in the battery with a meter. my duff battery wouldn't charge above 12.4v with a CTEK. Re start/stop once fully charged (if the battery is ok) I have found it takes several trips before whatever computer / sensor resets the function and the start / stop works. Even when I had the battery swapped at the Alfa garage it took a few trips before it all reset..

I had no issues but tell them you know it's a common fault, read loads of reports about it and is standard practise to swap them out etc.. just in case they try it on.. garage procedure is they will try and charge it up for you and then they'll put some battery tester on which shows whether a cell is bad or not.. In my case the mechanic came out and said .. yeah it's got a dead cell we'll swap it out..

Name: Muz
Comment: Deman77 said:Q you are rightfully confused.lots of people both here and on Stelvioforums talk about asking dealer for AGM without really appreciating what it is like from dealer perspective.They need to fall over themselves to convince Alfa to allow them to install non-OEM part.By default Alfa will not compensate them for AGM battery upgrade as they have not even switched to those on recent model years. So dealer has to be so keen to make the customer happy that they would fall over themselves to make arrangements with Alfa for battery replacement or pay for it themselves - not the difference - the whole thing. The flip side is they need to make no extra effort just put the new battery in and get paid for the job. Plus if it breaks under warranty again, they will get paid again.The only thing they may consent to is installing customer own battery (not a given) but I have a feeling they will also be warning of possible warranty issues in case future issues are attributed to non-OEM battery. I think that risk is low so I would still try it and at least get the install on them and pay for the battery out of my own pocket.Click to expand...I have been amazed over the last two years to be told by the garage I have used for 15 years, and a couple of others too when I checked, that they cannot fit parts supplied by me anymore. Something to do with insurance and them becoming liable for any failing parts that you supplied for them to fit. Take it to the Nth degree and an Alfa dealer could potentially (and almost certainly would) refuse to fit a battery you supplied.

Name: cue2
Comment: I understand why the dealer cannot provide betterment or fit an improved part which the owner supplies. The replacement part is often provided at the suppliers expense depending on the contract with the manufacturer along with labour at a reduced rate.

Name: Deman77

Name: SteveeGee
Comment: From memory the oil change can be reset in the infotainment system, but the service light needs the dealer computer to reset. Neither are smart, just time or miles. My Alfa main dealer didn’t do mine, had to go back.

Name: alfacool
Comment: My Giulia had an oil change after buying it and before i picked it up.The oil reset light had not been reset.I took it to my trusted mech who reset it for £24, think i was there 10 minutes.When it was cleared the time (days) were zeroed.Told me its just like the 159 to do.

Name: j20eyk
Comment: Evening AllAfter a short a time in a Macan GTS it looks like I am coming back to Alfa. 12 months ago sold my Giulia Quad due to my first child arriving, wanted something sporty for when I was on my own but a little more practical for the new family. Ordered a GTS, (I did debate on a Stelvio at the time) waited six months for it. Just a nice car, feels solid, etc etc all the german cliché talk. Just a car really. I absolutely loved my Giulia and maybe I expected too much from the GTS but it just did not come close. I never felt like I wanted to drive it just for the sake of it, didn't look at it in admiration, didn't have the noise or sense of occasion when I got in it. Sold the GTS today and the bonus is, it cost me all of about 2k to have it for 6 months. Not many cars you could say that about!So a Stelvio is on the cards. I don't see what else will come close to the Giulia and I know the Stelvio isn't a Giulia but it's the closest I can get at the minute with the young one. In the future maybe back to a GiuliaThink I am going to buy used this time to ensure I like it first and see how it goes.

Name: cue2
Comment: Congratulations on the Stelvio.You’re probably right that the questions are for the dealer to answer. It’s a used car...Ive had a Speciale for two years now from new and luckily it doesn’t have the keyless nonsense that causes new cars to have krooklocks!

Name: Maximus84

Name: cue2

Name: Maximus84

Name: cue2
Comment: Sadly, part of the training to sell cars appears to be avoiding any emotional connection with stock.

Name: Stingwray
Comment: I am not sure you can expect a Lexus dealer to know the specifications of an Alfa inside out. It’s possibly the first one the salesman has ever sat in let alone sold.Interestingly, one of the worst used car purchases I have ever made was a landrover through a Lexus maindealer.

Name: GlasgowMito
Comment: The fact that the car does not appear to have been serviced correctly, the missing owners manual and the inconsistent story re repairs which raises serious questions S over potentially undisclosed damage.

Name: cue2
Comment: Looking at the website it’s the direct nature and the savings that are their main selling points.Forces Cars Direct, Military Discounts, New Cars, Eligibility - Forces Cars DirectThe non-Lexus car was possibly a trade-in and they got a better price for it than webuyanycar.If you can find the servicing dealer of a car they should be able to find the records on their computer database.

Name: Maximus84
Comment: My gripe is not with the spec, it is the condition it which it has been delivered to me. If not, I may have to discuss giving it back and cancelling the finance.

Name: Maximus84
Comment: Oh and just to add, the car had an RAC inspection prior to me committing to anything and all came back clear, which gave me the initial confidence to proceed.

Name: cue2
Comment: Just be clear as you have been that it’s a used car from a non-Alfa dealer!

Name: cue2
Comment: A dealer will not spend any money on stock in case it doesn’t shift in the month before they send it on to auction. That would benefit the person who buys it at auction. I think the word Direct is a clue in this case?

Name: Stingwray
Comment: Forces Cars Direct have a 14 day money back guarantee if you are not happy.

Name: Maximus84
Comment: @metalgod23- I think you're probably right, to an extent. It was supposedly serviced again in August last year but that's what I need clarity on. The car currently has 25650 miles. Without the service book it's hard to know not only when the last service was, but what is required on the next one.

Name: metalgod23
Comment: The diesel is every year or 12k miles. Here is what's required. If you have 25k miles then it could only be the time based flag that has triggered the warning. Is the car older than 3 years? It would have been due last August and if they did the service they forgot to reset the service counter or else they didn't do the service at all.Alfa Romeo Giulia Service ScheduleAlfa Giulia service schedule showing the operations performed and the parts used.www.alfaworkshop.co.uk

Name: cue2
Comment: I traded my wife’s Kuga for a Toyota at a main dealer and gave them all of the paperwork from new and a month or two later the salesman phoned me because he’d lost it all! He wanted to know where it’d been serviced so he could piece it together. I think there’s an issue with GDPR so they were probably not interested in the invoices but the service book went missing too. It should all be in the computer records at the Alfa dealer with yours.

Name: Maximus84
Comment: Yeah I have questions regarding the RAC inspection - I didn't pay for it, it's part of the FCD service. Name: cue2
Comment: All that aluminium being hit by 100mph grit. Oh no!

Name: Deman77
Comment: It’s back above freezing on Tuesday. I might give her a wash. See if ceramic stopped it.

Name: cue2
Comment: That figure for the Macan is telling. The Germans like their numbers for top speed etc but not for wading. The funniest figure to compare is overall weight. The Porsche is the same as a Stelvio with an extra two fat occupants. Perhaps it prevents it floating away..

Name: Harry_p
Comment: It doesn’t matter if water is above the tailpipe, the air would force it out as soon as you start up. As long as it’s not higher than the exhaust ports on the cylinder head I wouldn’t worry too much. By the time it gets that high you’ll have other things on your mind!

Name: allandwf

Name: Bob123
Comment: After much research and help on sites like this (thank you) I‘ve decided on an Alfa red Lusso. Was originally going with the Vesuvio Super but quite a bit more kit that I’ll use on the Lusso plus AWD and the chrome window surrounds suit the Alfa red paint to my eyes (Vesuvio is very nice though).Final piece of the jigsaw is do I go with a diesel or petrol engine? I’m a low mileage city driver (7k per year). Cost difference is pretty negligible over a 4 year lease period, saving around £400 with the former. I’ve read that the diesel has more torque. But in terms of real world driving usually under 40mph in built up areas is there much difference when it comes driving experience, reliability and noise (assuming the diesel is refined and doesn’t rattle like a London taxi). Any thoughts?

Name: Bob123
Comment: Thanks for that (was probably more concerned about the potential “rattle” than anything else). I need to do a little more research on DPF. Hoped that was a case of just a weekly blast on the motorway for half an hour or so (not a problem) and the odd adblue top up?

Name: VeloceRosso
Comment: Yes that’s all it takes. Don’t know about AdBlue yet - I’ve only had mine for 3 months and not been very far in it so not had to top it up yet.Certainly no rattle to worry about and a really smooth drive with loads of torque.

Name: cue2
Comment: You just need to turn the seat and steering wheel heaters on if you feel cold.

Name: Muz
Comment: Deman77 said:can’t speak for Alfa but these are the things that annoyed me about my previous diesel. So get people to opine.heating.Diesels are mega thermally efficient and take forever to warm up. Heating will be cold for good 5-7min on a diesels especially if you are stop starting. On petrol things warm up much quicker 2-3min.noiseDon’t know how Alfa diesel sounds but only VW 4pot disels didn’t bother me for noise. Need to try at idle and at different speeds, cold and warm. There are some rattly 4pot petrols to be fair.FunWhat is your definition of fun? I found very narrow Rev range in diesel took away from the fun factor. Unless you are driving fully laden or towing there is enough torque in any engine in the range.Click to expand...One thing I have really appreciated on my petrol Stelvio over my diesel 159 is that on a frosty morning I can start the car and leave it running for 5 mins and go back to a toasty interior and clear windscreen. I think I could leave the 159 running for half an hour and it wouldn’t warm up.Is it something to do with the turbo having to be working on diesel cars? Whatever, it did annoy me during winter that the car had to be driven for a few miles before it warmed up

Name: Deman77
Comment: Or wear mittens and a hat. Remember you need to run fan to demist so no avoiding cold blowing at you.Same you can wear ear plugs for noise and squeeze every last rpm out of a narrow rev range to make it more fun. But my point is you do not have to do these things on a petrol.

Name: Deman77
Comment: Also my car is blowing warm air by the time steering wheel heating can be felt or the seat heating - they are far from instant. In a diesel I would absolutely want an aux heater installed. Had it in my last car, that was good to preheat but in terms of cold start it was not as quick as petrol to blow warm air still.

Waiting for a plus temperature day to break out my new pressure washer. Under pressure - Pressure washers can damage your tyres.

Would only go to more comfort from here.

Name: wictod
Comment: Will do, the Pirellis have lasted well, i'll give them that..nearly 25K and there;s still some meat left on them..Found this review when i was looking around at options..

Name: paultrim
Comment: I reckon any pressure washer, capable of damaging a tyre in 5 seconds is probably going to do damage elsewhere as well e.g top coat, plastic trims etc. Most degreasers, fallout removers are well capable of doing the job of removing stubborn grime along with a gentle (normal) power washer and a bit of elbow grease (detailing brushes etc).

Name: Muz
Comment: No, I haven’t got any at the moment but I have been reading quite a few posts on the US Stelvio forum about people getting problems with the OEM Varta battery. Just a watched Neil from AlfaItalia video (if you love Alfas I recommend you check out his many really interesting videos) and the woes he has had on his Giulia Quadrifoglio (assume Stelvios use the same battery). Seems if the cars have been standing unused without a CTEK or equivalent this is quite a common problem.It also appears that unsold cars that have stood for months are affected, so even brand new (in theory) cars are equally at risk.Mine was a demonstrator registered in Jan 20 and came with 6500 miles on the clock so hopefully I am not going to get this problem as the colder nights draw in. In fact I have already started disabling the stop/start just in case.So, who on here has had battery problems? As an aside is this something that is covered under warranty?

Name: cue2
Comment: I bought my Stelvio two years ago and it’s covered 8000 miles and not used every day. The Start/Stop is often not detecting enough charge to operate/too many electric things switched on. It was not a pre-reg or demo like yours but it seems fine. I know I shouldn’t say that but it’s in for its second service tomorrow which will probably include a battery check.

Name: wictod
Comment: Muz, Mine was 2018 demonstrator with 9000miles purchased June 2019... Battery went duff shortly afterwards, replaced under warranty with a like for like (no quibble) and has been ok since.. Name: jwq
Comment: Yes, It's exactly the same as the OEM EFB varta in 95 Ah :Varta EFB 95 AhThe standard battery is the 80 Ah, part of the cold weather package is the 95 Ah battery (that actually also uses a larger altenator)The QV has the cold weather package as standard I believe.There is a second screw location in the battery well, covered by a sticker, for the larger battery.When installing the new battery, don't forget the vent hose

Name: Top Down
Comment: Remember, fitting a bigger battery will only work as long as the bigger battery gets charged properly. If the cars charging system, including alternator, is not charging an 80ah battery why would it fully charge a 95ah one? You will still need to keep it topped up with a Ctek. If you rely on the cars charging system, which cannot fully charge even the 80ah one, then overtime the battery will 'learn' its new capacity, that might only be 80ah at most..

Name: Mash1138
Comment: jwq said:Yes, It's exactly the same as the OEM EFB varta in 95 Ah :Varta EFB 95 AhThe standard battery is the 80 Ah, part of the cold weather package is the 95 Ah battery (that actually also uses a larger altenator)The QV has the cold weather package as standard I believe.There is a second screw location in the battery well, covered by a sticker, for the larger battery.When installing the new battery, don't forget the vent hoseClick to expand...Got the cold weather pack, not measured the battery yet. Alfa coming out to take a look today...Hope they just replace with a decent AGM as requested.Cheers for all the help.

Name: Top Down
Comment: Agreed and that is why I said charging system. But the main consideration is, keep charging a battery to 75% capacity and eventually you have a battery 25% smaller than you think you have.

Name: jwq
Comment: But that would, if true, apply to any size battery, including the smaller one...... You would still end up with higher capacity with bigger batteryRegardless, it also depends on the algorithms the IBS uses to determine battery capacity....

Name: Andy Bowden
Comment: If the battery capacity does indeed reduce over time due to the charging logic and the IBS learns the battery's effective capacity, there would be a never ending spiral of battery capacity reduction.ie IBS initially maintains the battery at 75% of 80Ah, battery thinks it is a 60Ah battery, IBS charges battery to 75% of 60Ah ad infinitum.I remain sceptical.

Name: jwq
Comment: I also still have my original battery from august 2017, without problems......I do cheat by regularly using a charger though, specially these days where I don't drive much....

Name: jwq
Comment: re generator, it's not a massive difference. I agree it's mostly to compensate for the higher current drain in cold countries due to heated accessories.......battery specs:• 12v 80AH 680A - non cold countries• 12v 95AH 800A - cold countriesalternator 150 vs 180 amps, see :

Name: Top Down
Comment: Andy Bowden said:My understanding of the IBS is that it will initially establish the SoC of a new battery by reference to the standard theoretical curve of SoC v Voltage which is independent of battery capacity.Then over time it will integrate the current in and out of the battery over time to update its SoC estimate. Though I would expect it will compare Voltage with the standard curve at times of nil or low battery current to ensure its SoC estimate is not wildly out.i don't believe that the IBS or BCM need to know the battery capacity or that they would be affected by fitment of a higher capacity battery.Nor do I see any problems fitting a 95Ah battery to a car with an alternator originally associated with an 80Ah battery. I'd see AR's decision to fit a higher capacity alternator as part of the winter pack being based on greater current demand for heated rear window and seats etc in cold climates and unrelated to battery size.I do have a degree in electrical engineering.Click to expand...Andy, if the IBS was that clever, why do we have any battery that is not fully charged? If the IBS could monitor charging properly then these problems would not exist. The first few paragraphs of this article are interesting:Charging Information For Lead Acid Batteries – Battery UniversityReview various Lead Acid charging methods and examine why some systems work better than others. Find also simple guidelines for charging Lead Acid batteries.batteryuniversity.com70% of charge in the first phase of charging? If the cars on board electrics are taking a chunk of alternator output, then is it possible that stage two and three of the charging process does not complete.I think that the IBS is not as smart as it should be.

Name: jwq
Comment: I doubt the IBS is the problem, I would sooner question the charging logic that is implemented in the bodycomputer for one, using the values passed on by the IBS.The IBS does not control anything, it just measures.

Name: Top Down
Comment: Yes, my bad, the body ECU

In fact I have already started disabling the stop/start just in case.So, who on here has had battery problems? As an aside is this something that is covered under warranty?

Comment: USA "drive by" sound regulations are different to EU (and other regions) USA can have louder cars. I wasn't aware of this until watching a vid about Mclaren Senna, the EU spec ones have 3 exhaust outlets to dampen down the resonance and meet the EU limits, even in Race mode. The USA and other regions get a full Titantium system with 2 outlets which is much louder as standard.I'm guessing Alfa may employ different parts, or different SW to meet the variations across the globe.

Name: wictod
Comment: Found myself Friday on an early run up to Newmarket from Essex (M11 /A11) for work caught in some early snow... I have been interested to see how the car handles it.. I stuck it in the green mode "A" and found a bit of space to play and the drive is really steady with some minor twitching but the real handfull comes when you brake.. the ABS starts juddering away and there's not much control... now I have to say the tyres are originals and do need changing but I'd be careful in the snow .. the false sense of security in the drive is negated by the trouble you have braking.. maybe I'm expecting too much or have misunderstood what the AWD is all about ??? It's the same in stop / start traffic creeping up behind a car, apply the brake then the juddering starts and there's this strange slipping forward sensation as the brakes finally grab as the torque from the engine tries to propel you forward slightly before it grips the road. I definitely think my tyres are past usefulness and can now see why some folks swap out to winter ones.. As we don't get much snow down South we probably don't appreciate the skills needed even with all the traction features of this car..Cheers

Name: HFStuart
Comment: All cars a rubbish braking in snow on summer tyres. The heavier they are and the wider the tyres generally the worse they are. Sadly the first time most people realise this (me included in my Integrale) is when they're piloting a 1500kg sledge that's given up on steering. Newer tyres will help a bit but honestly not much.4WD will sometimes give better engine braking in snow but you're spot on to say the 4wd, traction control etc gives a false sense of security.

Name: Harry_p
Comment: Yes, for all the extra traction you get from 4wd, it makes little difference to the braking.It doesn’t help that general everyday tyre are now very summer weather orientated, far better for 10 months of the year but pretty terrible in the snow.the snow on Friday was unusual too, it had been raining non stop all night, then dumped a load of wet slushy snow on top ( we’re about 5 miles from Newmarket ) which made it very slippery.

Name: Deman77
Comment: Not even a sniff here - the proximity to m25 must be melting it all. I saw some cars with snow in the bumpers mind so can’t have been far.My winters are for the hills around me. When I moved here I skidded at 5mph out of my cul de sac downhill to a blind t onto main road where I normally inch out - just slotted between two cars - free lesson. Then kids came and heavier car - I’ve been wearing winters religiously ever since November-Easter - but for me it’s the black ice on a cold morning and having one extra thing to worry about. I just go for whichever winters do best in dry and wet.

Name: Mpetrou
Comment: kgb said:For those of you who want to install the dual USB hub needed for the activation of Android Auto/Apple Carplay1. Check the software version of your ETM (aka the Nav system) to be at least 056 and up. 056 is update for older Nav systems up to 2018... usually the MY2018 start with 059. I have somewhere the 056 software so if someone needs it, send me a pm so I can upload it somewhere.2. Install the new dual usb hub. EPER part number 0156143958 for the USA market it is a different number if I am not mistaken.3. Well you have to dismantle your center tunnel (arm rest)...4. Move both front seats at maximum front position5. Seat in back seat and pull away carefully the plastic around the rear air vents.6. Using your tools unscrew the 3 bolts that hold the arm rest on the top of the glove box. (see the pic)7. Now unscrew the 4 bolts that hold the air tubes going to the rear air vents as you need to move them a little in order to get your hand in the tight place under the glove box. (see the pic)8. Now with the arm rest removed you need to go to the front seat and pull the plastic cover around the center glove box on which you have also the parking brake button. So be careful not to pull like crazy and snap the cable for the P brake. Pull from the front near P brake button, as in the rear you will see that they are no clips...DO NOT pull from the back as you will brake the cover. You have to do it from the front and then remove the connection for the P brake and then carefully remove slide it from the back... Look at the back and you will see.9. Now carefully disconnect the led light for the glove box...don't look for a bulb type, use a fine flat screw driver and remove it from the box.10. Remove the air tube to the box11. Get your special tool as you need to get it below the box in the center of the box. USE fine gloves to protect your hands as you might scratch them... First blood to your Stelvio can happen here and hopefully the only.12. Undo the two "bolts" that are in the center of the bottom in the box...no the two middle ones as they hold the antenna for keyless go. (see few pics)13. Take your time or use someone with smaller hands...it is very tight there...push down the rear air vent tubes to get more space.14. Once you manage to remove the two screws...go have a drink and feel like a winner...you can skip that part15. Pull from the top...the box is now being hold by 4 clips...into the four corners...you will be able to see them...but careful with the plastic box.16. Now you see the cables for the USB hub...disconnect them.17. Change the single USB with the double one...check if it works for charging18. Put everything back together19. At this point you will be thinking of not putting the two screws under the box...BUT do them20. When everything is put together you need to go to someone having the factory diagnostics called Witech. Basically you might need to go to the dealer (good to talk to them before as they might refuse to do the job for unknown reason). Hopefully soon MES or ALFAOBD will be able to active the AA/Carplay The time needed for the dealer is like 10mins.21. So while at the dealer connect Witech go to ETM menu and in misc. tab there is a function called Android Auto/Carplay offline activation. Press it after about 10sec it will say complete.22. Shut down the car and take away the key as the car needs to get into standby mode...the ETM needs to reboot.23. Turn your Stelvio and connect your Android or Iphone...for Android you need to have Android Auto installed on your phone!!! Connected your phone via BT and also via GOOD USB cable. bad USB cable will prevent it from working...price of the cable has nothing to do with the quality. I bought 10 euro cable and it doesn't work... a 2 euro cable works perfectly. BEST is to use original cable.24. You can check if Android Auto was activated without connecting it to a phone by going in the option menu in your ETM...press option and scroll down till you see Android Auto, it is the last one25. Enjoy your Android Auto and Apple Carplay26. Have a safe trip:angel:for pictures go to:installation/activation of DUAL USB hub for AA/AppleCarplayClick to expand...Do i need to make any value changes on a 2018 stelvio?

Comment: Just reigniting this post, did you go for any of the options and did it work out?mrpbailey said:This seems to be a bit of a quiet forum compared to others.I too am looking into the same thing for the Nero edition. I am looking at a tuning box type so that I can have more flexibility, maybe forfeiting maximum gains for the ability to remove & re-flash as required.Seems to be a few more with the Giulia 200hp petrol engines that have had re-maps / tuning boxes.So far my research has thrown up the below options:-TDI-Tuning - approx. £370 but regularly discountedhave discounted this now for a few reasons, firstly they don't monitor fuelling, secondly they only get to 250hp, and thirdly when I spoke to them they told me that the turbo is different from the 280hp model, which is why they cannot reach the 280hp, I believe this is not correct information so doesn't give me faith.TDI Tuning | Alfa Romeo Stelvio 2.0 MultiAir Turbo CRTD4 MULTI Channel Petrol Tuning Box Chipdescriptiontdi-tuning.com-Novitec powerjet 4 fromAlfisti.net- approx. €479 + shippingBelieve these are from Squadra tuning in Holland? Both have good reps, and does monitor fuelling. Believe gains are up to Veloce 280hp.Novitec Powerjet sSs für Giulia und Stelvio 2.0 TBNovitec Powerjet sSs für Giulia und Stelvio 2.0 TBshop.alfisti.net-Squadra tuning, chiptuning - €590 - 690 & OBD programmer, SGW bridge & shippingGood reputation but price reflects this. Seems to have good safety limits written in. Gains look to be 280-310hp.Novitec Powerjet sSs für Giulia und Stelvio 2.0 TBNovitec Powerjet sSs für Giulia und Stelvio 2.0 TBshop.alfisti.net-Emotion/Celtic tuning eMotion2+ - £425This is probably my most likely route at the minute. Basically a remap done remotely, not an extra box/ecu plugged into the engine sensors. They offer a stage 1 (280hp) or stage 2 (324hp).Vehicle Info - Celtic Tuning | eMotion 2+A standard remap by a reputable company will probably be cheaper and possibly achieve slightly improved results, but for me the flexibility of the above options is a big plus.Click to expand...

I don't believe the figures they give but the difference between driving a mapped car Vs standard is like night and day, my fuel economy is up and it's a lot faster....think of it less as "mapping the 200bhp engine to make it the 280bhp engine" and more as "making it the best version of your engine".I'm not sure I'd want a standard map, I'd rather go to a good tuner and let them read my ECU and see what they can do, plus I'd much rather have a map than a chip, although I understand there are two camps on that argument...

Comment: Maybe you should contact Italo ECU. The guy who runs it is André. He has done most of the remappings for the members of a german forum, also the remapping of my Brera. He has an outstanding reputation and really is a nice guy. My Stelvio will also get his workout as soon as the warranty expires.For the later models temperature management is part of the remap, as far as I understood.André owns a Stelvio himself, so he knows what he's talking about, he is literally the walking workshop manual. For sure you don't want to go to Berlin for the remap, but if you contact him he will give you the respective information on turbo, radiators and so on.

Name: Tremolo Arm
Comment: i am wondering if others have noticed an excessive road noise with their Stelvio.In mine it's almost as if the window is slightly open. granted I have 20" wheels, it feels excessive even compared to my previous 159 TI TBI.I am wondering if the door seals can be improved / upgraded?

Name: wictod
Comment: I haven't noticed any adverse road noise on the 19 inch wheels with the Pirelli Scorpion tyres.. obviously get some pitch change on different surfaces but nothing I would consider excessive..The only thing that has puzzled me is when i'm coming off my drive slowly on almost full lock I do get a weird skipping sensation like the tryes are running over marbles and not gripping?

Name: jwq
Comment: Re noise, check if the doorseal is seated properly, they sometimes work looseRe skipping, that's normal, do a search on the forum for Ackerman angle / tire scrubbing .....It gets worse when it gets colder and the tire rubber gets harder...See also:

Name: wictod
Comment: Thanks jwq, good to understand what that skipping sensation was... I'll do some further reading on Ackerman angle.. cheers

Name: cue2
Comment: The front suspension geometry articulates the wheel and tyre to be in full contact with the road.Also, on the seals;https://www.alfaowner.com/Forum/alfa-giulia/1065081-external-noise.html

Name: Tremolo Arm
Comment: Thanks. Some good info there, though not an easy fix it seems

Name: metalgod23
Comment: The road noise to me is both a combination of light weight materials AR have used on the Giulia and Stelvio as well as the crap design of the door seals which have poor gap sealing and consequentially let wind noise around the seals into the cabin. Strangely some cars seem to have better door seal compression compared to others which suggests this is a variable affected by panel alignments perhaps. We have thinner acoustic glass, very light sound insulation etc. all to improve weight and handling. So that is the trade off you are noticing.

Name: Tremolo Arm
Comment: Thanks for your replySo it sounds like it's a "standard feature"... That's what I wanted to know. I was a bit paranoid it was just my car.

Name: cue2
Comment: The seals are quite soft, probably in an attempt to get it to seal. I imagine the 20” alloys will make more road noise than 19”s. The Stelvio has a seal in the vertical bit door shut below the a-pillar. Does the Giulia also have this, I wonder?

Name: Jchan11hk
Comment: Tremolo Arm said:Resurrecting this thread as I believe I may have located where the noise is coming from...When the window is lowered, and the door trim pulled towards the driver, I can see a soft and sticky foam strip, which I assume serves as insulation between the B-pillar and the door frame.I can see that on the driver side this strip is somewhat torn and does not provide good coverage. On the passenger side it is much neater and covers the metal frame. I have attached a photo. The photo was taken from above looking into the window cavity.I did an experiment yesterday where I stuck a generous strip of general purpose window insulation around that area. Granted the strip is much thicker, it did seemingly cure that sensation of open window noise. When I removed the strip, the noise was back.I am wondering if this is something I can get Alfa to replace. The car is still under warranty.On a side note, is it normal that the door trim pulls off so easily? I mean I didn't need any tools or any excessive force. I just pulled it gently near the B-pillar side and it moved easily by a good 5 Cm. The photo is taken with it pulled.URL=My Library][/URL]Click to expand...I got the same road noise on the driver side and also have a 20 inch wheels. Can you resend the pics? Comment: The aircon dehumidifies the interior and prevents the windows fogging up too.

Name: SteveeGee
Comment: Around town it’s more efficient to open the windows, but at motorway speed it’s more efficient to run the air con. Given the brick like design and proportions of the Stelvio and most SUV’s the amount the air con contributes or saps in efficiency terms is probably less than 1%, so I just leave it on all the time, with benefits that Cue has stated that generally it will require less potential maintenance cost.Speed is the biggest contribution to efficiency, 10mph less on the motorway can up the mpg by more than 10%, with only a few minutes difference to travel time.

Name: cue2
Comment: Basic marketing. Because they couldn’t put the price up £300 on every car if all of them had bars. Just like there has to be a model with reflector headlamps to get extra revenue for xenon, and so on.

Name: GVblue
Comment: Can't imagine it would cost them £300 to fit to every car, more like 50 euros and they can't make many £300 as optional extras as hardly any Stelvios seem to have them.Taking your logic (which I don't necessarily disagree with) to the extreme, why do they fit those slightly over the top chrome tailpipes? They could leave them off to keep the accountants happy and charge them as a £200 optional extra.After all Ford managed to spec them as standard on your Kuga.

Name: cue2
Comment: It’s called “opportunity cost” in economics. The potential revenue is £300 and cost is less than that, obviously. I had it explained to me when I worked at Ford. It’s not my logic. Sometimes items will be in packs of say 3 features of which one is more expensive to do than you’d think and one may be cheaper than perceived. I can’t think of a pack that it could be in.As far as exhaust pipes go it’s a “performance” thing that fits Alfa DNA. It’s a bit of a dated thing to feature where the pollution emanates from though. The black ones on the Nero are possibly more tactful and cheaper to do, the idea of that spec perhaps.

Name: SickStu
Comment: Just updated toMV-090.000.061 TV-090.000.061using jwq's instructions (thanks jwq) and have noticed it now doesn't remember the 'easy entry' setting (where it slides the seat back a bit when you get out of the car & forward when you start it up).I set it to 'ON' and it works OK on exit but is always set to 'OFF' next time I start the car & I have to move the seat forward manually. Is this a bug in090.000.061? - or nothing to do with the update and I've got another quirk ?

Name: jwq
Comment: Not heard about this problem before.... Lot of the older cars didn't have the option to set easy access on/off, but apparently you did. Tempting to think it's the software version, but as said, not read about this problem anywhere else .....I don't suppose you have the dreaded blinking odometer ? .... That would indicate a CAN bus error, requiring a proxy alignmentWhich firmware version did you have before this update ? If it was lower then 072.xxx.xxx, it could mean you need an update of additional modules, as stated in the update info ..... That would be dealer only .....

Name: SickStu
Comment: No blinking odometer thankfully and it was on 085.000.046 before.I tried to revert to the previous version to test as it's an option on the menu but it wouldn't let me do it

Name: jwq
Comment: No, don't think anybody ever got that working.....As you came from 085.x.x. it shouldn't be a problem with updates for other modules.....If you realy want, I guess you could re-install 085.x.x. .....I doubt that's the problem, but you never know.....

Name: SickStu
Comment: I think I'll just live with it then although it is handy for getting in & out of the car in my rather snug garage.I could see if my dealership has got any ideas

Name: SickStu
Comment: I now think you're right and it was just a coincidence that it started doing this after the software update.I measured the battery voltage yesterday with one of those cigarette lighter socket jobs - it was 11.7v & sure enough the Easy entry setting had changed again to 'OFF'.Stuck it on a charger overnight and today it's retaining 'ON' and working as it should.Now slightly worried that I've got a failing battery in a less than a year old car.

Name: jwq
Comment: Glad you've probably found the source of your problem....Not so good that it might be a battery problem.... I think a lot of people are currently having problems, as cars get driven less due to Corona.....Maybe hooking it up to a trickle charger might be an idea.....If you do (have to) go for a new battery, a lot of people have found replacing it with an AGM type battery in stead of the factory EFB is a good idea

Name: SickStu
Comment: Battery is being replaced under warranty (without a quibble - wow!) and I don't get to specify which sort but will bear this in mind for next time

Name: SickStu
Comment: ...so, the plot thickens. Replacement battery hasn't fixed my problem.I'm thinking the new one wasn't very fresh or I've got a parasitic drain somewhere (although car is 100% stock)... or it IS something to do with the infotainment firmware updateVoltmeter is showing 12.2 with ignition on / engine running & 14.2 when braking - is that what would be expected with IBS & a brand new battery ?(apologies for thread hijack)

Name: Andy Bowden
Comment: The so-called 'intelligent' battery charging system of the Giulia and Stelvio, at least the pre-20MY ones, is that if the battery state of charge is above a threshold then the alternator only charges whilst braking. Threads in the Giulia section go into some detail.Your voltage measurements are consistent with that 'logic'.

Comment: The difference may be the way dealers deal with issues. Toyota customers benefit from preemptive fixes and a certain way of customer service that some Alfa dealers don’t provide. My Stelvio armrest lost one of its tiny rubber bits that it rests on when closed. I asked if they could replace the tiny rubber bit but the dealer replaced the entire armrest which came to £400 if I remember correctly. No quibbles and no uncertain wait to see if Fist were going to OK it.

Name: Adrian1980uk
Comment: I've already got a lexus Is, 100000 miles, tbh I'm realistic that no car is perfect but everyone you speak to gives the 80s alfa rusting in the drive, while I know that's not the case, I'm looking more for the opinion that it's more of a surprise if it breaks down than not

Name: cue2
Comment: It’s unlikely the aluminium bonnet, tailgate or doors will rust. What do you want us to say? I’d be very surprised if a Stelvio let you down. Giulia owners seem to have issues with the battery going flat because of something like being able to leave the audio on. My Stelvio has covered 7000 miles since mid December 2018 and occasionally doesn’t always switch off at junctions.

Name: cue2
Comment: it's more of a surprise if it breaks down than not.There.

Name: SteveeGee
Comment: Agreed. 15000miles in 18mths couple of issues, didn’t let me down though. And nothing broke or fell off.

Name: leraunch
Comment: Yep 15000 miles in nothing broke just a few niggles such as a sensitive alarm going off in the middle of the night and over sensitive crash sensors.

Name: cue2
Comment: The proximity sensors should be set by the dealer at handover.

Name: Adrian1980uk
Comment: Was looking at the lexus nx but then come accross a stelvio and quite keen on that. Obviously Lexus has a reputation for reliability and Alfa let's say has not, just wondering if its fair or really a historic reputation that can't be shaken off.What are peoples experiences

Name: Stewart1
Comment: I'm 18 months in to Giulia Veloce ownership. No problems other than an intermittent fault on the passenger seat adjust which was replaced under warranty.Before that I had a 159 2.4 diesel for 11 years and it was very reliable.The only bad thing about owning an Alfa is people asking if it breaks down. But more people compliment it, and I bet small boys don't point excitedly at a passing Lexus.

Name: Adrian1980uk
Comment: That's probably exactly what I wanted to hear

Name: Stewart1
Comment: I've even been complimented at a drive-through Coronavirus test.Young lady doctor: "OK, please tilt your head back. Hey, nice car, by the way".

Name: cue2
Comment: I’ve had the same from the man at the entrance to the waste disposal tip!

Name: GVblue
Comment: Our doctor said the same as he helped carry my wife, with her trapped sciatic nerve, to our two day old Stelvio.Adoration is just something you have to get used to when you own an Alfa.

Name: punkatron1
Comment: I’ve got a 9 month old stelvio quad and I’ve now replaced 3 of the Pirelli corsas due to 2 punctures and 1 sidewall cut. They’re the softest tyre I’ve ever had.Has anybody swapped tyres and if so to what?I’m prepared to trade off some performance for durability.Sent from my iPhone using Tapatalk

Name: punkatron1
Comment: Deman77 said:Corsas? I thought those were on Giulia. Stelvio should be on plain p zero. That’s the stock with Alfa codes.Speaking from research - no personal experience - still waiting for build date for mine. Mine will get switched straight into winters but I am considering switching summers as well if road noise is too much.The top alternative (lower noise and better ride and probably better handling) is Michelin Pilot sport 4s - you can get an SUV version with harder tyre walls if you are worried about punctures and failure but you will pay with ride quality. Stelvio is not as heavy your typical suv more like a heavy estate - 540 touring and tyre rating is same as for estates so standard one should be fine - load ratings match the homologated Pirellis. You can get Porsche (taycan) homologated rear ps4s to get exact size and fronts are generic - our size is available. Now taycan is way heavier so I think it should be fine.Click to expand...Thanks for that. I was thinking PS4s but will only swap if they’re a bit more robust. I get it’s a performance tyre, but replacing 3 tyres in 9 months is annoying.Sent from my iPhone using Tapatalk

Name: Deman77
Comment: go for SUV with higher load ratings stiffer side walls then. You could go for contis - they are bulletproof but they are mega noisy.have you considered that you perhaps had unlucky streak or you happen to drive through some high puncture risk areas (farmyards some heavy machinery yards)It’s unusual to blame tyres on punctures. If you stick a nail in I do not think a tyre will matter - same with cut sidewall.Sidewall failure in a pothole is a different matter.how come they were not repairable after punctures?

Name: punkatron1
Comment: One was an M8 bolt so too big to plug. It was bizarre to be be honest. Another plugged but it was questionable if it could be fixed so played it safe. Last week was a sidewall cut that exposed the cords. I haven’t had a puncture for 10 years easy and I’m not going anywhere unusual. I’ve only done 4500 miles as well.Sent from my iPhone using Tapatalk

Name: punkatron1
Comment: The ride as a driver is fine, but I was a passenger in it for the first time the other week and it wasn’t great. I now understand why my wife and kids prefer to take my wife’s car! Also, I realised on the same journey that wind noise on the passenger side is terrible. I’m going to get the door seals checked when it’s serviced. I went for the sunroof (always go for that option in my cars) and it’s open all the time so I get the full quad experience.Sent from my iPhone using Tapatalk

Name: SteveeGee
Comment: My 2019 built car had the Break-in event detected message this morning when I got in. No alarm heard, no issues seen, parked on level ground, no weather events. 1st time I’ve seen it. Will monitor it for now.

Name: GVblue
Comment: We've had our Stelvio two weeks today and it clearly wanted to celebrate that anniversary with us.At three o'clock this morning, pandemonium. Alarm screaming, headlights flashing, wipers wiping, doors locking and unlocking and the rest.No real panic as I had the same with my Giulia six months ago, just a question of stopping it by opening the boot and disconnecting the battery.Except, the electric tailgate would not open so I had the fun of climbing over the back seats to release the tailgate manually, whilst wearing nothing more than a bathrobe.Fortunately, none of the neighbours took a blind bit of notice of the alarm so were spared such an horrific sight.Awaiting Alfa Assist.

Name: cue2
Comment: Yours is the first account of a Stelvio with a low battery Giulia-style, as far as I can recall. Was your car in stock for a long time? Mine has only covered 6700 miles in 18 months and no issues other than SS not operating when it’s been unused for weeks during lockdown.

Name: GVblue
Comment: Fresh off the boat.

Name: Alfie155
Comment: Trundling back from Sussex yesterday on the M23 (on the damned 50 Average Speed section) I wondered why everyone was being so law-abiding, ie on cruise control set to 50 I was gliding by many cars. With a stab of fear it occured that maybe the speedo was drastically under-reading so got the passenger to open my gps-based speedo app on my phone.Assuming that is accurate (you have to have some sort of benchmark!) I was surprised to see the Stelvio speedo is almost spot on. Later on, at indicated speeds of 50, 60 and 70 on the Alfa's digital screen, the phone app reading was just 1mph less in every case.I'm sure that in years gone by it was generally assumed the speedos were over-reading by at least 3/4mph particularly at higher speeds.

Name: SteveeGee
Comment: By law your Speedo isn’t allowed to under read. Most over read and the margin was higher as it was a simplistic sometimes mechanical solution but as electronics have improved it has gotten ever more accurate, with the ECU’s accounting for different sized wheels etc now on cars. Usually accurate to within 2-5mph. The stelvio is very accurate I’ve noticed that too.

Name: cue2
Comment: Of course.

Name: stelvio2018stoon
Comment: Hey guys,I have at 2018 Stelvio Ti, just hit 10,000km. Recently I noticed that after leaving the vehicle turned off (after letting properly cool down in driveway after driving), the vehicle begins making sounds. From the outside, it sounds like a faint beeping sound under the hood. Upon opening the hood, it sounds more like a valve releasing or grinding sound. It occurs at irregular intervals every 5ish seconds, and lasts approx 1 second, sometimes longer. It sounds like it is coming from the upper driver side of the engine block. The sound will persist for up to an hour or so after driving, sometimes longer.My local Alfa service team is trying to also determine the cause as I sent them the video. They recommended I try locking the doors to see if it stops the sound, which it does not.Anyone have any ideas?

Name: epsonix
Comment: These cars do a lot of funny noises from brand new when you turn of your ignition after rode (DC-DC converters whistling, IC coolant electric pump trying to cool down a bit your turbo etc). I can't recollect exactly this one, but after next ride (in a few days, I drive a little nowadays) I will open bonet and see if it happens on mine as well. I will let you know.

Name: cue2
Comment: 5000 k is a million! That’s a lot of hills. We usually drive to Italy but the time window between our son finishing scout camp and daughters date to be back for GCSE results meant we rented a car from the airport. This year we should get to do the Stelvio Pass. This should be a good recce for cycling it some time.

Name: stelviowner
Comment: Been up the Stelvio pass a couple of times. Have to say it is a bit commercialised at the summit. As to cycling up, you will have plenty of company but my personal advice is 'don't even start' it looks a right bugger, goes up and up and on and on and is way beyond me even thinking about. If you want to go up the absolute highest paved road in the Alps, slightly higher than the Stelvio look up the Col d'liseran 2770 metres. Both passes are swarming with motorbikes during the day, you need to have you patience turned way up. My 5000k is of course kilometres which is not so far after all.

Name: Andy Bowden
Comment: I've done the Bormio side of the Stelvio a few of times, but not yet in my Giulia Quadrifoglio.My biggest problem once was following a camper van which was a tight fit in the narrow tunnels.Best avoided at weekends and in August when all of Italy is on holiday.The Col d'Iseran is boring when compared with the Stelvio.

Name: smarty156
Comment: Despite lack of towbar for the Quadrifoglio and having looked at the alternatives, we'd really like to stick with Alfa Romeo and the Stelvio. However, I'd be looking at a year old Quadrifoglio on a PCP and finance rates aren't great. This is making it look very expensive next to the Competition (you can get 6 to 18 month old BMW X3M Competitions with 2.9% APR at the moment which means the monthly payments are very cheap, more than £150 a month less on a 48 month 10k miles deal. Maybe nearer £200 a month).I don't want to get into any debate on PCP versus any other finance. What I do want to know is if anyone has managed to get or find a low rate PCP deal for a Stelvio Quadrifoglio? If not then it may well be goodbye to Alfa unfortunately.

Name: cue2
Comment: Have you spoken to Ancaster , as I think they’ve got a Stelvio Q?I’m sure you could persuade them to knock a percent off the rate if you’re sitting there ready to buy.I just paid a thousand into my PCP with 17 payments to go and it’ll save me £142 in interest.Perhaps Thames has a Stelvio Q as well to pitch against Ancaster.

Name: SteveeGee
Comment: 2.9% on a 6-18mth old approved used car is a great deal and woudl indicate it is a dealer demonstrator or ex-fleet car of some sort and still able to attract manufacturer support on finance like a new car. BMW AUC's usually are priced at 9-12% APR. You might struggle on other brands as they all have different practices. Guess depends on what you class as low APR - I can find a dellivery mileage Quad MY20, with 12k off list which would also attract new finance support, currently 3.8% on the Alfa website, depending on how desperate the dealer is to sell, might be able to swing a bigger discount or slight APR drop.

Name: smarty156
Comment: I asked Ancaster earlier this year (pre COVID) and they could get FCA finance to come down to 4.9% as I was an existing customer but that was it. Don't know if they'd do the same now. Their rates that they advertise seem to have gone up.I'm going to try the BMW anyway before deciding.Ancaster are showing 11.9% representative on their website. With a £6k deposit this equates to £915pm. A similarly priced X3M Comp (same age, if not slightly newer) with same deposit is £500pm! That's a combination of 2.9% APR and higher final payment.

Name: smarty156
Comment: Just to add the 2.9% is a BMW special offer on all 6 to 18 month old M cars.APR quoted on all other Approved used cars is 10.9%. I was looking at an X3 M40i but due to the finance an X3M is actually a couple of hundred pounds a month cheaper like for like.Just depends if I could put up with the harsh ride (from reviews) although maybe a smaller set of wheels would help (they come on ridiculous 21s).

I refilled the tank to full (approx 16ltrs) and now at 8.5k miles it says it is low and needs refilling again.now I assumed that maybe the tank wasn't filled full as a new car, thus 4k could be explained away. Also the warning came with a 500 miles to Armageddon warning, so It seemed and was proved to be pretty low.I do mostly motorway mileage, which would seem to be low consumption for the stuff, but 4-5k miles between tanks seems excessively high. Other thought is that the low warning is another Alfa nanny, overly pessimistic warning, like the fuel gauge...

Name: Andy Bowden
Comment: I guess from your use of 'expensive' you haven't a service plan and money comes out of your pocket, but if that's so you are not tied to a main dealer for servicing.My trustworthy independent tests the water content of the brake fluid and will only bill for changing the fluid if a water content threshold is exceeded.Main dealers don't think that way.It's rare that brake fluid actually needs changing every 2nd year.Where are you located? Do you know of a good independent local to you?

Name: Martini Racing
Comment: No service plan and when spending my own money i checked several prices on line. Not sure why second service is 3 times more thanfirst.Moreshockingly is the variation in quotes when booking online with Alfa Romeo UK. Main Dealers cost Varied from £350 - £1250 for second service and £80-£250 for brake fluidchange.Oneeven emailed to insist cam belt replacement needed after 2 years!!!.I have always used trusted Independents after second service as they tend todo a much better job and do not damage the car, and mechanics have names & faces unhidden by service reception.Located in Kent.

Name: Andy Bowden
Comment: On the Quadrifoglio, at least on the Giulia, it is the fourth service at 36,000 miles which is so expensive, Typically £1,200 plus because the labour involved in changing the auxiliary belt is huge.The AR plans for 2 or 3 services, which is the subject of another thread, covers that service. I reckon I saved £1k+ by buying the 3 service plan.Earlier this year the Quadrifoglio was not excluded from the plan. If the beancounters at Slough have latched on, things may have changed.

Name: Andy Bowden
Comment: See:metalgod23 said:Strange methods of FCA at play me thinks but one that might ultimately benefit the customer especially if you own a Qf. I specifically queried with my dealer (Lipscomb Ayelsford) for Qf service plans for 3rd,4th years and they confirmed the price is the same forallGiulias now inc. Diesel and Qf. £349 for BOTH 4th and 5th services. I can't understand how it would cover the costs of the 4th major service of the Aux belt on a Qf which is about 5 hours min labour but they said it covers everything on the service schedule. Go figure. I was sent the below info. It does not appear to make any exceptions for engine size. It may be worth actually trying to buy it over the phone. Speak to Dawn.For all owners, you can either buy up to 3 services from new to maximum 5 years old for £499. If you only have 2 years left until the car is 5 years old then £349.=================Hi,It is definitely £349.00 to be exact. The prices aren’t differentService Care Scheduled Maintenance ProductAs is the case today, each Service Care product will contain all of the scheduled maintenances required throughout the length of the contract, in most cases this will be an annual service. The two key changes introduced for the new product will be the ability to sell this Service Plan on bothnew and used vehiclesup to the 5th year (passenger cars) as well as the ability tosell the Service Plan more than once! (Earliest 1 year before the expiration of the active contract)For vehicles that are serviced every other year (Fiat Professional), the all new Service Care can be sold up to the vehicle is5 years old.(Maximum 5 services covered)If additional items are required outside of the service scheduled, such as brake pads, discs or wiper blades, as an example, these will not be included and be subject to additional cost at the customer’s expense.The 3 year retail price remains at £399 for all FIAT models despite offering a more flexible product.The table below gives the breakdown of the costs associated with each plan:Brand2 Services3 ServicesFiat£299£399Alfa Romeo£349£499Abarth£399£549Jeep£499£699Fiat Professional£649£899View attachment 932066Click to expand...

Name: metalgod23
Comment: The above service plans can be purchased for Stelvio as well. The petrol engines have a cam chain that does not need replacement. Diesels have a cam belt.

Name: Martini Racing

Name: metalgod23
Comment: With reference to the above highlighted in bold. The 2.0 Petrol DOES NOT have a cam belt. It has a cam chain which does not need changing ever. If yours is indeed a petrol and a dealer said the cambelt needs changing on the Stelvio 2.0 they need to be shot.

Name: Mash1138
Comment: SteveeGee said:I've not really had a problem, but I miss the side mirrors dropping down on reverse, which I had on my previous Lexus. have got round it by programming one of the seat switches. My previous Lexus IS was a real pain for low speed positioning and I eventually came to think it was because of the design of the bodywork. The exterior glass line didn't really indicate where the wheels were, bodywork swept out not once (for the door and mirror), but twice, second time it flaired out to the wheelarch and then the wheel, so really the wheels were about 3-4" further out than your mind/eye thought they were by the glass/bonnet line from sitting in the car. Stelvio is less like that and the bigger sidewalls on the tyres mean I'm less worried about kerbing and make less mistakes, I do find it quite easy to judge using the camera and the mirrors.Click to expand...Did the same - programmed one of the seat switches to point the mirrors down. Name: SteveeGee
Comment: Starting to get pretty annoyed with water running out the bottom of the tailgate and landing on my head/back of my neck on the Stelvio when i put things in the boot.Was looking at it yesterday between storms and I think I can see the issue. The black strip that surrounds the bottom only has 3 outlets (each end and middle) which exit on the inside of strip for water, so the water only leaves when the tailgate lifts up. This bit is attached to the lower plastic panel which makes up the entire lower part of the outer tailgate, secured with screws through to the inside.I'm considering drilling a few small holes on the flat area beside the existing holes on the inside of the strip, which I think would allow the water to drain out when the tailgate is shut. The strip doesn't appear to seal to anything or sit tight to the bumper.Anyone else tried this, or has any other ideas on how to stop raindrops falling on one's head !

Name: cue2
Comment: I’m just trying to visualise what you mean. I tend to get to the boot after the tailgate has opened, using the remote on the key.

Name: SteveeGee
Comment: Water pours out of mine when it has been raining, running out of each corner and the middle as it lifts up and continues for a good while afterwards........

Name: cue2
Comment: I’m not aware mine does that but my first Giulietta had a tailgate that “ filled “ with water and the bungs were removed and then at the next service all were replaced. Where is the ingress? Wiper spindle?

Name: SteveeGee
Comment: No, it doesn't fill into the boot, i think it is running down the back of the panel, where the number plate fits, that whole part full width is plastic and secured to the tailgate, I think water is getting in the back, it seems by design, but the water outlets are poorly designed, so it doesn't drain when it is closed, only on opening. I'll try and get a pic/video, if it will ever stop raining here.

Name: SteveeGee
Comment: Starting to get pretty annoyed with water running out the bottom of the tailgate and landing on my head/back of my neck on the Stelvio when i put things in the boot.Was looking at it yesterday between storms and I think I can see the issue. The black strip that surrounds the bottom only has 3 outlets (each end and middle) which exit on the inside of strip for water, so the water only leaves when the tailgate lifts up. This bit is attached to the lower plastic panel which makes up the entire lower part of the outer tailgate, secured with screws through to the inside.I'm considering drilling a few small holes on the flat area beside the existing holes on the inside of the strip, which I think would allow the water to drain out when the tailgate is shut. The strip doesn't appear to seal to anything or sit tight to the bumper.Anyone else tried this, or has any other ideas on how to stop raindrops falling on one's head !

Name: cue2
Comment: I’ve experienced this once with the Stelvio and my first Giulietta had the water in tailgate issue. I just Googled “water in tailgate” and it seems a common occurrence!

Name: cue2
Comment: Poor quality suggests the car may not be built to correct tolerances. If the issue hasn’t been diagnosed until real users suffer from it , rather than any simulated tests on prototype car , then the solution can’t yet be incorporated. Hence my 2017 Giulietta didn’t have the issue whereas my 2011 was taking in water in 2011 after I bought it. You’d think a simulation would exist during early testing but the list of cars on my google search suggests even “quality” Audi’s suffer.

Name: Barrat
Comment: Yes don't get me wrong. All cars have problems and I love my Alfa's which is why I keep going for them. Just wondering if one of the lights was not installed properly and what is causing the leak. Going to re book it into the garage to get it looked over again so hopefully find a fix.

Name: cue2
Comment: The leadtimes for production lamps may mean that verification prototypes are too late to be tested for leaks in real conditions. A surrogate is often used.https://www.stelvioforum.com/threads/stelvio-stop-sale.6145/

Name: cue2
Comment: Is it around the side or on the main area on the back of the car?

Name: cue2
Comment: That’s an area where condensation typically happens because the gap is not that deep between the lens and housing so moisture condenses and will not clear very easily.

Name: GlasgowMito
Comment: I would expect the casings to be designed to be watertight or to have appropriate ventilation/measures to stop condensation. I have a 2008 Brera which has been very reliable and wearing very well, however fogging rear lights are the bane of my life. It seems to be common Brera problem as seals crack over time and allow water in. A pair of new rear lights for the Brera cost around £900 so if I were you I'd harass the dealer until you get a replacement under warranty before the issue has a chance to get worse.

Name: cue2
Comment: Certainly worth raising on warranty. I had two new headlights on my first Giulietta because there was dusty discolouration around the top vents on the silver bezel inside.

Name: cue2
Comment: When the Ford Ka was first launched it had big grey/blue bumpers and despite this being the theme the Germans didn’t like them. They got the dealers to paint them bodycolour. The trouble is polypropylene is a great release agent and the paint peeled off. Everybody said Ford were making a bad car but it was the dealers. There’s a risk , if you don’t heat the surface to get a better keying the paint will fall off Stelvio parts too. You can get filler primer to fill the grain if the 2020 parts are just painted. Personally I think the colour break is to disguise the added depth of the body compared to the Giulia.

Name: bnr
Comment: That does look a lot better. Also considering using gloss black plasti dip.

Name: cue2
Comment: I used glycerine based tyre stuff in the FCA Heritage case. Works well but is a bit water-soluble.

Name: DanM_2018Stelvio
Comment: I have a 2018 Stelvio ti Sport with 102K miles ( suoer commuter 300 miles/day) and recently I got the electronic throttle warning that has come and gone 3 times in the last month. I read through the forum and found most of the threads indicate that a software reset should clear the problem. I finally got the car to the dealer and they told me the diagnostics indicate a bad solenoid associated with the turbo was the possible problem and if that did not fix it the turbo would need replacing at $4k cost. That seems extreme to me, i am admittedly not a mechanic so i really have no clue and am at the mercy of the honesty of the dealership. The car runs perfect and performs as it always has when the light is not on. so it seems like the turbo is fine other than the warning light and they said the software update would not be the fix. Any feedback would be greatly appreciated.

Name: markiet
Comment: My 280 Milano will be 12 months old this month and its going in for its first service.This is my first Alfa and I've hadzero problems, which is a relief, as Alfa was a new brand for me and I was a little worried.My other car is a Lotus Evora 400 (both in green) and I get stopped in car parks and petrol stations as much with the Stelvio as I do with the Lotus.Petrol consumption is a little worse than I was expecting, even careful local driving we barely get 25 mpg, which is less than the Evora!!On longer runs on the motorway it obviously rises, but it's a little odd that my 400bhp V6 supercharged Lotus gets better petrol mileage!!
