Name: Michael_360_Mod
Comment: Okay, the handbook and the screen in the car says idle engine for 5 mins and then check. I know I'm being stupid but do I turn the engine off and then check? My MD says I shouldn't as the sensor measures pressure in the engine and figures out the level. Sounds a bit far fetched to me. Thank you.

Name: GVblue
Comment: No, you leave the engine running and trust in technology.

Name: wictod
Comment: If you're going to top it up, do it in small increments, like half a pint a time... the gauge doesn't react instantly.. my level was at the halfway but that doesn't mean half full, I think it's half of upper limit if that makes sense.. anyway I added some it didn't move after waiting 5 minutes, added a bit more , it didn't move so took it for a half hour drive and pulled into a garage.. sat there with the engine running and suddenly it went to the limit line.... I thinks it's a daft idea personally, would rather prefer a dipstick but as long as you go easy on the top up should be fine.. if you overfill it i think it stops the engine firing up from what I've read..

Name: Alfie155
Comment: I overfilled my 33TI Veloce many moons ago and was alarmed to see clouds of white smoke issuing from the exhaust on a fast stretch of the A31. Fortunately Alfa dealers were thicker on the ground in those days and i found one in Southampton who was able to syphon some oil out while i waited.Not helpful I know but...

Name: Michael_360_Mod
Comment: epsonix said:I heard that if you read Engine ECU with MES, this parameter is not delayed in oppose to the dash display (Which is very significantly delayed, don't believe a few minutes). But it is electronic sensor, so again do we trust it in 99.9% or just 95%? You know, if it fails (and I know one case it started showing excessive oil level during ride, but after draining all to container QTY was correct, so sensor was replaced), then you base your decisions on wrong level.There is small slot on 2.0 engines for service bayonet, but access is not great as far as one guy who looked at it confirmed. You need also this special bayonet.I try to increase confidence to reading by making sure with dealer serviceman how much oil he put in (5.2L), then rechecking with MES what it displays and with more or less observing the level displayed on ignition on (not too often, just every a few weeks), I have a clue that readins make still sense. I loose a lot of oil (driving short distances and have heavy foot on gas pedal), so I expect that over my oil change interval (I half the recommended due to driving style and distances, in practice change every half year/every 7.5kkm) I loose say 30% of max-min range. On some cases say at 2-3 months before next service I top up a bit like 200ml, so I'm closer to max levelClick to expand...Thanks you everyone - very useful.

Name: Jambo
Comment: Interesting to hear about the IBS issues. I've struggled with our Milano with the alarm system draining the battery (the module in the headlining was replaced as a known fault). Also recently noticed the rear heated screen not working which turned out to be since the battery was not charged enough. A charge at home seemed to fix that though ok.Is there not recall for a miss leading petrol gauge?

Name: SteveeGee
Comment: The recent recall about fuel gauge levels is for a specific set of circumstances where if you parked the car the car on an incline it might think you ahve refilled it and then report you had more fuel than you had. Otherwise, the gauge is a bit odd (mine does the same as OP), probably to do with the tank design, which is a saddle bag type, sitting over the prop shaft with 2 sender units and 2 pumps - really complex. There are threads on here explaining both areas in more detail.

Name: Andy Bowden
Comment: I really don't know, but I would expect the logic of the BCM to be similar between the Giulia and the Stelvio, if not identical.If your Stelvio's HRW has always worked, I'd expect that it's because it's quite new with later software than my early 2017 Giulia. I'd gone for almost 2 years without any software updates until the recent update which does seem to have sorted the HRW.Andy

Name: cue2

Name: Andy Bowden
Comment: If your dealer didn't tell you and you didn't do before and after checks with MES there's no way of knowing,

Name: Jetronic77
Comment: Have you tried disconnecting the IBS sensor? without information on state of charge or state of health the alternator should be charging the battery to full capacity and start/stop shut off.Tried it on my Giulietta today for a minute and theres no warning on the dash that the sensor is diconnected. The alternator however was putting out 13.9V before and after the disconnect so it probably was on full charge anyway

Name: jwq
Comment: It's actually the opposite.... with ibs sensor disconnected, it goes into failsafe mode and only charges up to a (very) low battery level .....There is a (very) long thread on IBS problems here:the mess that is start-stopanddisconnect ibsmany, many threads on this

Name: epsonix
Comment: yes, I did experiments for number of days and described it on this and other forums. basically there is permanent S&S error displayed on IPC, and charging is unloaded around 13.8V loaded 13.5V, so not good to keep battery charged and recovered. we need proper solution, and I will build one - this is 2nd project in development queue now.

Name: NEURALRACING
Comment: Anyone tow with their Stelvio? The US Version states that the towing capacity is 3000lbs. Wondering if having a Eurocode Tune (added torque) will help achieve that. Im looking to tow a trailer that is about 2800lbs, but when you add gear and two adults in the car, we are looking at about 3600lbs all in. Wondering is this will be an issue.

Name: Jetronic77
Comment: It's been a few months so I guess you found out already. This is for the next guy then.Engine wise 3000 pounds is nothing, the smallest engine can do that. But the US versions have reduced tow capacity because trailers run with much higher weight on the hitch, pressing the rear axle down and lifting the front. So I guess the vertical static load on the hitch will be limited to about 300 pounds. In Europe we run about 5% vertical load, and all trailers above 1650 pounds are braked.

Name: Bobbybear
Comment: Hinot quite sure what your rattling sound is but I had a screeching/rattling sound coming through my centre speaker for ages last year every time I accelerated . Comment: Ok So I rang the dealer and he assures me the Red Tin Selenia DigiteK went into the engine and not the Green Tin and has said it was an administration error booked out through the parts depts but the engineer apparently knows the difference and what he put into the car. Guess there's no way of checking and I'll have to roll with it.. Cheers

Name: SteveeGee
Comment: The only difference will be some additives different between petrol and Diesel engines due to different compression ratios and leadings. The guide numbers control the viscosity at differing temps and are the same. I doubt there will be any noticeable difference.Just googled and learned it is all made by Petronas, always a school day!

Name: wictod
Comment: Thanks for that.. I assumed there wouldn't be too much difference but I know these oils are specially developed for the specific engines, apparently you can't just lob any old oil in even with the same basic numbers 0/30 etc... Gotta keep an eye on the dealers... i'm not that mad but I've read about some peeps on here actually watching the oil being poured in so they're double sure the right stuff is being used... Cheers

Name: Top Down
Comment: If in the unlikely event something goes wrong, you have the dealers invoice listing the wrong oil IF it was in fact used.

Name: wictod
Comment: Good point Top Down.. the paper trail.. cheers

Name: Tickets
Comment: I don’t think they could blame you for asking for the oil to be changed again. At least that way you would know for sure what has gone into the engine. I’ve worked in the motor trade for over 30 years and technicians do put the wrong fluids in and they do lie about it. In fact I have known people not just technicians say black was white if backed into a corner.

Name: cue2
Comment: I questioned the oil used for my Giulietta MA in 2012 and the dealer sent a driver from Maidstone to collect my car from my work in Essex , leaving a car with me to use. We then swapped cars back the following day in my work car park.

Name: sb1957
Comment: Ti replaced Milano and.."New for the Stelvio Ti is the addition of carbon fibre exterior trim accents, sports suspension and extra tech. The carbon fibre V-shaped grille and door mirrors are complemented by dark Stelvio and Q4 badging, while red brake calipers and new 20-inch alloy wheels are specific to the Ti.Inside the car there’s a leather dashboard and the Ti also gets soundproofing laminated glass, a hands-free tailgate, adaptive cruise control and frequency selective damping (FSD)."But not the new touch screen stuff and new gearshift.

Name: PoxiLoxi
Comment: I recently had some fun and games with my Stelvio. The parking brake reported a fault just before I went on an errand. When I came back to the car I couldn't release the auto parking brake. In the end I had to call out Alfa Assist who managed to release it and followed me to Mangos in Knutsford for them to take a look. The Alfa Assist guy suggested I did not stop en-route as the brake might lock the wheels and then the car would be unrecoverable without a lift.I got it to Mangos, who had it for 2 weeks (I wasn't pressuring them into fixing quickly so this was no problem) and they finally found a faulty brake caliper sensor. They had to go through a lot of diagnostics and get in touch with Alfa to diagnose this which took quite a while. Just wanted to let you know if you have this problem with your car get it to a dealers pronto.Jo_______________________________________________________2018 Trufeo White STELVIO2.2 Turbo Diesel 210hp Milano Edizione

Name: cue2
Comment: I drove a Giulia 180 diesel for a couple of days and at 23000 it seemed quite good. Being closer to the ground probably made it feel faster than in a Stelvio. A petrol of the same horsepower and lower torque might not work so well. Also, the lack of flappy paddles made driving a bit more ponderous.

Name: Tidmarm
Comment: Don’t discount the 210 diesel if you are doing the miles, I’ve driven both and have to admit the diesel engine suits the Stelvio better, it feels more planted with all that torque on offer.The 280 petrol was good but not sure its worth the extra fuel cost, it also felt more skittish. The lack of torque on the 200 petrol might not be enough to give you what you need out and about on the road.I suppose you need to consider if your going to keep it for a while or not, any trade in on a diesel might be painful ?

Name: cue2
Comment: I’d recommend the 210, with the trade-in proviso , as it suits the Stelvio. Sitting a bit higher makes the character more suitable than in a Giulia I found. Tons of torque and a great auto box make the 210 Stelvio good to drive.

Name: cue2
Comment: The seats are heated. If that’s not enough just gather round the heated steering wheel!Incidentally, if you want to see where the elements are on the wheel, just get a slightly damp cloth and get the rim damp. Switch the thing on and see where it dries!

Name: wictod
Comment: Good luck mrpbailey, hope you enjoy the Stelvio.. I've got the 280 Specialie .. been paying attention to the mileage over the last few months, although mine is 280 it should give you some idea. Around town I'm getting around 25mpg average.. a mix of round town and some long stretches i'm getting about 30mpg but I am using the cruise control on long stretches where we have these average speed limits zones.. I done a long 500 mile round trip on our motorways and managed to get 35mpg but I was using cruise control again on long stretches of controlled speed limit.. I reckon with the adaptive cruise control it would be more consistent... can't help with the service costs but am due one soon so i'll find out...

Name: SteveeGee
Comment: As an aside, my 210hp diesel Milano seems to have averaged out at about 38mpg per tank, so low 30’s on petrol is very good.

Name: wictod
Comment: SteveGee, I've had to alter my driving style to get that though, I just leave it in the N position and am real light on the gas unless I need to flick it to D and blast away. Been driving 40 years and never really understood the obvious that hard acceleration and braking reduce the mpg significantly until I watched that slider bar on the dash which shows current mpg..

Name: Tjalle
Comment: I had discarded Stelvio as a replacement for my X4 35i - until I stumbled over the QF. Not in person -they are all sold out due to environmental taxes 5 folded as of Aug.1 in Sweden.The QF is like a dream come true - it has the looks and performance/attributes, that I could just dream about - without testdrive - just reading automotive tests.Unfortunately it is also slightly above my budget - I have to await pre-owned vehicles to come to the market.To my mind it is so heavily modified/improved, that it is a different vehicle compared to "STD" Stelvio, and hence should have its own thread.I have tried to suggest this to the site, but I have a problem to get through with the proposal.

Name: PapaSmurf
Comment: Apart from the cosmetic differences & the engine is the QF really that different from the other trim levels. The number of "unique" problems you will get is unlikely to be that many and I'm sure reading the problems of us lesser mortals might actually be of benefit.None of the other model lounges split out trim levels I don't see we this one should be different.

Name: Tjalle
Comment: Another thought: SAAB 900 was regarded as a sedate vehicle, until we introduced: the Turbo, the Rucksack (rear spoiler) and AERO wheels. Then it took off as a performance vehicle - especially in the US.Luckily, we also made some upgrades to already good chassis, so we had a good package - apart from the gearbox :rotate:

Name: Tjalle
Comment: I have been reading "all" tests/evaluations, I could find, and they have a common note: all smiles- and:"this is not the typical weird italian car - but almost normal - apart from the outstanding engine/chassis/sound.I have not before read this kind of remarks from "all" testers- not even JLR products from UK testers.:blabla:"My" dealer right now has no DEMO, but wiil in about two months time. I will come back with my two cents worth of input.

Name: Tjalle
Comment: I have read all tests/evaluations I have managed to come about, but I have not seen any evaluation of:-windsensitivity-steering precision - although "quick steering" - also indicates good steering precision.-"steer into a curve" - how well you can position a vehicle into a curve - without over/understeer.- tramling - sensitivity for ruts- chassis comfort/noiseand - of course - driving on ice and snow.

Name: Tjalle
Comment: It already has.....:rotate:As said before - I am trained to read pictures, specs and evaluations. Further more, I have worked with Alfa engineers, and they are good - especially their chassis people.Yes, part of the handling performance is, very likely, torque vectoring through clutches at rear axles. I, however, have seen a possibel slight glitch - coming out of a bend, when rear "steps out" somewhat unnecessary. That can also be a driver error.

Comment: I should - of course - have looked at Google/You Tube first.Yes - PTV is Porsche Torque Vectoring. Plus indicates PDK!?They obtain this by applying - moderate - brake pressure on one rear brake only. This is a "negative" way of obtaining rotational torque on the vehicle - but might work perfectly. I, however, prefer the Alfa way, where one rear axle is partially or completely disengaged - I have not been able to get a description.

Name: Kannassee
Comment: Tjalle said:I struck GOLD or "Pay Dirt", as they say in the gold fields.I, finally, found an in-detail description of Alfa Torque Vectoring - at Giulia threads - page 3 (4 weeks ago) - no 6 - "Elektro hydraulic braking"- "quad trainingmanual.pdf".Short:-operates only on rear wheels-includes fully controllable clutches left/right.-includes lh/rh planetary gears-can send 0-100% torque to either wheel.-controlled by Integrated Chassis Control, which monitors; steering angel, yaw velocity, X/Y acceleration and vehicle speed.One of situations described is accelerating out of a turn, where torque is directed to outer wheel, which is consistent with "lead footed" journalists hanging out rear end when exciting curve on a track.I forgot: there is also an in-depth description of the engine and all its systems/details: I would never own a QF without proper warranty or insurance!!Click to expand...Lol....I agree with you 100 percent!!!.....here in the US Alfa has a bad reputation regarding mech breakdowns so an extended warranty is almost a MUST!!!....just joking....by the way the extended warranty costs almost half as the Porsche’s one

Name: Tilum
Comment: I'm not sure about LHD Euro variants, but the RHD variants (e.g. for the UK market) that I saw/drove at Goodwood had the sports exhaust 'active' throughout the rev range. I'm pretty sure it's the same for LHD U.S. variants (looking at YouTube videos). I'd be surprised if it's restricted to 3.5k rpm and above only though - my Maserati GranCabrio MC's sports exhaust is always 'active' throughout the rev range when 'Sport' mode is selected. Some variants of the GranTurismo and GranCabrio have the sports exhaust 'deactivated' below 3.5k rpm to avoid a monotone droning sound when cruising at low revs.

Name: Tjalle
Comment: I only have dealer telling me about "3500 rpm" limit, but at the same time, I have a hard time believing that vehicle with open valves can pass EU exterior noise test.Whatever - time will tell.I have a - supposedly - M Performance exhaust system - but in reality developed and manufactured by Red Arch Manufacturing in the UK. It has two modes - operated by remote control: Sport and Track. Operates two valves. Track is not legal for road use and I doubt that system, with a possibility for illegal soundlevel, is at all legal.

Name: Tjalle
Comment: I will gladly share any experience, which I believe is worth wile:-I will not put any spacers - unless "needed". My "gut feeling" limit is 20 mm.-sorry, but your limited slip differential - although a good feature - is not near the Torque Vectoring System on QF, which consists of a devise integrated in rear axle, which has two planetary gears and two electronically operated clutches (0-100% torque). Controlled by an ICC system (Integrated Chassis Control)measuring: steering wheel angle, lateral acceleration, speed, rotational speed (yaw). Based on this, system sends - through clutches - more or less torque to either of rear wheels.

Name: hbv
Comment: Your are absolutely right, the limited slip system of the QF is more sofisticated. This is the reason why I would stick to the original wheels (exception: you will get others with exactly the same measures). The Nürburgring Record was also done with the OE - but perhaps with other tires?

Name: Tjalle
Comment: Torque Vectoring is not a limited slip design. My reading of the system is that equal spacers, will not cause havoc with system/handling. "Just" additional load on bearings.I believe record is supposed to be set with original tyres, but people has been cheating before, and I don´t think there is an organisation checking - only video as proof. I know one company, that for some time had the official endurance speed record in it`s class. Although there was an independent organisation checking, they got away with wrong tyre size - to reduce drag.

Name: Kannassee
Comment: Tjalle said:This must be against the law - at least in Sweden :blabla:We have had a few days with above-zero temperatures and no rain/snow, which means road to golfcourse, and west side of island was 80% dry - 20% ice.I could push - especially when going home, when I knew where slippery parts were.Design and tuning of chassis, engine and gearbox is perfect - at least as I want it. There is no need for using paddles/manual. In dynamic, vehicle does it at least as good as use of manual mode. Always instant respons from engine - and what power!With X4, I had to go to manual, for best joy of driving - now Alfa does it for me.I could not feel any impact from TV - but I am sure it was working behind the scen. :rotate:Fairly bad surface means a bit harsh ride. I tried softer setting, but no fun.One valve was ticking at start up. Vehicle parked in heated garage for 5 days - trips to village in "bad" weather in 9000. No noise at end of trip. A bit too much clearence or tappet stuck?.Click to expand...When my car was less than 500 miles and after not driving it for a week I also got that ticking sound once, it was coming from the car right side and I sort of freaked out, but after a few minutes it stopped. It only happened once.

Name: Kannassee
Comment: Tjalle said:Flaw?Brakes are visually and also at hard braking imposing, but…I have very little margin in/out of garage, and hence need - sometimes- to reposition car backing out. I have noted a delay of about 2s, after releasing brakes before engine at idle starts to move vehicle. I had same gearbox in X4 - no delay.Also, braking softly - I am a gentle braker :rotate: - I start with gentle braking, which after a couple of seconds turn into more braking, than I intended.Possibel cause?: it takes a couple of seconds - at gentle braking - to "fill up" all 6 brake cylinders in front brakes? Also it takes a couple of seconds to drain cylinders when releasing?Comments?Click to expand...You are right, its difficult to modulate the braking when parking, its either too much or too little!!

Name: Kannassee
Comment: Tjalle said:I have slept on it - yes, it`s even smarter/more useful than I had anticipated!Already att moderate driving, system is helping to turn in and accelerate out of a corner. See page 280 - and previous pages.This explains why vehicle effortlessly takes corner without "normal" leaning or swaying - system helps front wheels to take corners - hence less leaning.I do believe chassis is very good, but body would - without system - lean more in a curve. Somehow I will do a testdrive with a STD Stelvio, to feel difference.Click to expand...I rented for a week a Stelvio (TI I think) some time before buying the Quadri.....and driving in the city, cornering etc.....the handling was excellent, more nimble/agile/lighter than the Quadri when cornering at intersections...(do all the Stelvios have that differential vectoring thing?)..I think that was also due to the fact that there was less weight in the front....smaller engine....I had to use more the shift paddles (less torque/HP) but I remember the car did not feel as stable as the Quadrifoglio at highway speeds, higher than 130 km/h, maybe that was due to it being a lighter car, the air/wind deflectors below the car in the front (I dont know if all the Stelvios have them) or maybe the tyre pressures or alignement were not ok.

Name: hbv
Comment: I drive my Stelvio Q4 280HP in summer and in winter with 20''. In summer Michelin and in winter Pirelli Scorpion. Both tyre are excellent. As in winter most of the roads are clean I prefer the 20'' as they are far smoother to drive and better on the road than 19'' ore even worse 18''. In snow my experience is that 'N' might be the most adequate selection. The only disadvantage on my car is that you can not switch off the assistances as ESP and ASD. The consequence is that you can not slide / strong accelerate in narrow corners as the systems will slow down the car. Recommend that you arrange a demo car to try it out and to compare with your QF. In addition I reported earlier that I still think that my limited slip differential (not TV) is in addition a sensible feature.

And RACE/TV is unique for QF.I have a set of OE 20" tyres AND a set of 20" Michelin PS4 - originally intended for my X4 - in my garage. Name: Tjalle
Comment: hbv, it is very simple - you just poor the material - in my case glass crush/powder in each tyre. For me 300g/tyre. Powder is resting in tyre, but will be dispersed during travel.It works!! Typical cost for material is about 3$ a tyre - tyre shop will- probably- charge much more.You can get INFO on Google. It seems that it was first used for truck tyres.

Name: alfaitalia
Comment: I assume they would make it.....if they thought there was enough market for it. I guess there isn't.

Name: TI-ger boz
Comment: Sadly I think it's all to do with fudging the emissions. An auto box can be tweaked to give good, consistent results. With a manual the results can be as random as the driver. I'm very disappointed with the gearbox options in the current range (no option), I bought a 1.4 Giulietta with manual box and this will probably stay with me until it, or I, fall to pieces.

Name: alfaitalia
Comment: Also or course we are one of the few nations in the world where manuals outsell autos so they tend to think of the global market rather than just one small country. They are also making an effort with the States...were manuals are very much a thing of the past. That's the reason you have not been able to buy a manual proper Range Rover for years....the US market …. Here we roughly sell about 80% manuals (slowly going down every year) compared to 20% auto....in most other major markets is roughly the other way around!!

Name: cue2
Comment: It’s down to emissions as mentioned, plus it’s a lot easier to package all the asymmetric bits of gearbox only LHD. The Giorgio cars come as manual or auto in LHD markets.The Giulietta is a good example of a compromised RHD pedal layout. The HVAC and gearbox tend to be a bit interwoven and LHD-centric and there’s a lot of stuff to position. The french cars where the master cylinder is left hand drive and the front passenger applies the brakes by pressing on the floor in front of them show a lot of the compromise. Obviously, the Stelvio and Giulia have a different braking system but this still takes up space.

Name: stelviowner
Comment: I'm still smiling at the picture of the passenger in a French car being responsible for the braking. Mind you I have applied the brake as a passenger before, pressing on the carpet when the driver didn't seem to be on top of the situation. I can understand what you say about the interchangability of components being a pain between the driving sides but surely when you are making cars for a global market you factor this into your costings and design. If Alfa want to achieve world domination they need to offer what the customer wants rather than trying to convince the customer that they really would prefer the product on offer, however much it falls short of their aspirations.

Name: cue2
Comment: Manual gearboxes are so yesterday?!

Name: PapaSmurf
Comment: Why don't you try using the Manual mode?

Name: alfaitalia
Comment: Most manual cars still give better mpg than the auto equivalent....so if autos burn more fuel I doubt that overall they give out less emissions. I quickly looked at the mpg of a few poplar models with both transmissions....even the best autos were only equalling the manuals on fuel consumption...not beating them. Logic would say that any transmission slip such as you get in an auto in both the gears and the torque converter is waisted fuel?? Maybe I just looked at the wrong cars!

Name: SteveeGee
Comment: But the manufacturers get more consistent results with a computer controlled rather than human controlled transmission. Plus they can have more gears (8,9,10 speed) in autos to better suit and further tune efficiency and emissions at any speed point. The latest autos perform coast modes, or lockup torque converter to reduce slippage and further improve on losses. More consistently and with more sophistication than 99% of typical drivers.

Name: stelviowner
Comment: SteveeGee said:I don’t get any gearbox hesitation in auto. If it is put in manual mode, stick left, then the car will hold a selected gear as you accelerate and will not change up, it will bounce off the Rev limiter. It will only change down in manual mode if you decrease speed so much it would stall, so it changes down to prevent it. if you leave it in auto mode and just grab a paddle to change up/down, then it will quickly revert and/or decide on its own. The software learns your driving style and adjusts the shift points and speed to blend economy or sportiness.Did you know if you pull the down paddle and hold it, it will change down, 1,2, or even 3 gears at once to the highest possible rev point to aide acceleration or engine braking.It’s an extremely sophisticated box the Zeppelin ZF8 and is used in virtually all premium manufacturers cars in a variety of different configurations.Manual cars are becoming a rarity and it’s all down to emissions control.Click to expand...Sounds as though I need to look at my auto box more thoroughly. Thanks for the tips. Still be a pain though working the car around the hairpin bends though. Too much brain dedicated to working out the gearbox whereas in a manual it all comes so much more naturally, the car becomes an extension of your thought process. The hesitation annoys me, half a heartbeat before the car reacts to the pedal, suprising how much can happen in that time.

Name: Bobbybear
Comment: I purchased a madness go-pedal to help with the lag. Was told by my insurance company under no circumstances would they insure me if I installed it. Insurance up in March so will wait and look for more understanding insurer if that’s possible.

Name: Andy Bowden
Comment: Partly for the emissions reasons others have mentioned, there will never be a manual Stelvio or Giulia.I drove both a manual and an auto Giulia before I placed an order. The auto was by far the better car.The manual Giulia Quadrifoglio was made in LHD form, but its production was terminated in recognition of the merits of the auto.Andy

Name: SteveeGee
Comment: I agree - in Dynamic mode, I couldn't change gear with stick and clutch as quick as it bangs in the shifts in auto! One things i have found with my diesel model is that of the 8 gears, 1st is very short, not needed really, 2nd is easy to pull away on, 3rd follows close behind 2nd, bigger rev drop to 4th which isn't much different to 5th, bigger drop to 6th, then 7th is close and 8th is very overdriven. This makes choosing manually a more difficult job than a 5 or even 6 speed stick, as you have more to choose from and you typically need a higher gear than you thought.

Name: Hugh Myles
Comment: You need to learn how to use the box properly. If it is kicking down a gear, or two, after you have selected a gear to accelerate out of a bend, then quite simply you have selected the wrong gear. If you select dynamic on the DNA controller for those occasions and leave it in Auto it will never put you in that situation as it selects the appropriate gear as you slow for the bend. Also, by pushing the accelerator pedal beyond the first stop you are activating the kickdown. The box is only following your inputs. Its not the problem, you are. Sorry to be blunt, but there you are.

Name: Andy Bowden
Comment: I don't fully agree with that, at least as far as the Quadrifoglio is concerned. I often find that if the auto is left entirely to itself I'll enter the bend one or two gears higher than I'd like.Simple solution is a quick click or two of the left paddle.Though, always if I'm on a mountain road with hairpins, or on a windy country road and I'm looking to make good progress, I'll be in manual.I'm very rarely driving in anything other than D.

Name: stelviowner
Comment: I'm with Andy Bowden here. I don't want to blast into the bends too fast or with a screaming engine, but I do want to be able to have the correct gear in place to power out of the bend. The auto box always seems to be a gear or two High if left to its own devices and has to change down for the exit. Also, being a time served manual box fan I find instinctively outwitting the auto box into my choice of gear tiresome and distracting. Foot down whilst in the bend, means gear changes down, turbolag clears, too much power in the bend. Getting it right is a definite knack.

Name: stelviowner
Comment: If I hustle the car throught the bends and the gear box needs to adapt for the exit from the bend by changing down it gets tiresome. I assure you I will be in dynamic.

Name: SteveeGee
Comment: What are others experiences here?I brimmed the tank local to the dealer on collection with 15m on the clock, it took 30 odd litres of diesel from its indicated 1/2 full reading, which seemed about right.I've done 386m since and today with 45m left on the range, its boinging at me to refuel and the red indicator is on. Trip shows about 40mpg, so that didn't seem right.I've brimmed the tank again and it took 44ltrs.Manual says it has a 58ltr tank including an 8ltr reserve and that refuel indicator comes on when the reserve is being used.386m @ 40mpg is 9.68gallons or 43.85 litres, so consumption is about right, but then the tank/gauge is way out? Whats going on??

Name: cue2
Comment: The estimated mileage to refuel is quite sensitive/accurate so when you’re urban driving it looks like you’re going to need stop. But then you drive on the motorway and after a while the range is greater than you started out with.

Name: SteveeGee
Comment: i'd been on fast A roads for previous 100m running at between 40 and 70 whilst the range seemingly ticked ever downwards, quite fast, yet the trip mpg was climbing, through 42mpg. I was also in the eco mode, should that make a difference.Does it a take a few tanks to "calibrate"?

Name: cue2
Comment: Too early to tell for me. I’ve got 1500 miles on the odometer so only a couple of refuels so far.

Name: Rossorichie
Comment: I’ve done around 10000 miles in my diesel Stelio and averaged around 42-43, occasionally 45 mpg - the trip calculator seems pretty accurate. I run usually in “N” mode - sometimes in “S” if I’m feeling frisky. Recently I ran the tank down into the “red” and squeezed 60 litres into the tank - I’ll need to check but isn’t the tank capacity 68 litres?

Name: SteveeGee
Comment: handbook claims 2 different capacities, larger 64ltr tank is "for markets where provided", but offers no info on which markets they are! UK website shows 58ltr capacity. Low 40's mpg is good and what I'd be hoping for. Is that off the trip comp? does actual consumption match? Is it mixed road, or motorway?

Name: Rossorichie
Comment: The tank capacities are strange, having put 60l into the tank a few days ago I can only think the tank as fitted to my 2017 Stelio has a 64 l tank. The mpg relates to the trip computer figure although I’ve cross calibrated it against a full to full tank figure and the trip computers seems to reasonably accurate. I’m getting 42-43 mpg on a mixed run of motorway, cross country A & B roads. Ive not found that using “ECO” setting makes much difference to the mpg although it does damp down the throttle response for icy roads. Running in “S” mode does seem to use more fuel although I’ve not carried out a decent mpg test - my next little test

Name: SteveeGee
Comment: I did about 4500 miles from new before I was informed by the car it needed more adblue. Another similar mileage and another tank needed. It won’t do any damage to run out, but eventually the car won’t restart until it’s refilled.I do mostly motorway mileage and I think the consumption is high. It’s my first diesel car with Adblu.

Name: Alfie155
Comment: That's helpful to know, many thanks.I agree, the consumption seems abnormally high.

Name: SteveeGee

Name: cue2
Comment: Obviously battery related. They should have charged it up but if the “company chairman” hadn’t used it enough for a while the thing will not hold its charge for long. Mines done 5300 miles since I collected it new a year and a day ago and it’s been fine. They should budget for a new battery if it’s been in stock for long enough to go flat. Good luck getting them to send you the load cover. It’ll be really expensive if they don’t I’m sure. Mine just had first service and a new fuel flap is on order. I’d call AR customer services as these characters in York should not be treating a customer so badly.

Name: TonyIles
Comment: Never known a battery to go down so quickly, I suspect the problem happened whilst it was on the lot, as the plastic cap was never replaced, but I thought once a battery goes, its gone, it did have a good run from York to Droitwich, hence the HRW started working, I agree they should have put a new battery in, it was brought on-line, so I am considering to see if I can reject the car under distance selling

Name: TonyIles
Comment: Broken Stelvio - update!!!, rescue arrived at 24:00, after putting through enough juice to start a truck, the operator said "the car has some electrical issues", lights were flashing, all sorts of error messages coming through, so clearly not just battery issues, now arranged for car to be recovered to Johnsons of Solihull, all of this is not good for a car that has done less than 200 miles in my ownership. He did say leaving the battery cover off was not good, could have potentially allowed a short.

Name: cue2

Name: jwq
Comment: yes, but you never know how old the batteries areEasy to try fresh one(s), just in case.Must say I simply disabled the keyless entry on my car, as I find it easier to just push the button on the fob, and because of security concerns.....

Name: PapaSmurf
Comment: If it is being more awkward on the colder days make sure the sensors on the back of the handle are dry. I found last winter that made a difference.

Name: epsonix
Comment: maybe place where you keep your key fob is full of other metal items - say like in pocket but with mobile phone, wallet, keys etc. That makes difference. When I got Giulia, I was experiencing issues with ignition - car could not see key. But I kept it in my jeans right pocket with mobile phone and home/office keys. I moved the key into left pocket, where I have only wallet, but key lands below wallet, and no problem since.

Comment: It is not a discussion whether new technologies are better/worse, useful/useless, but they simply have to be available if you wan to matter and be competitive, especially in premium segment.An added bonus would be better looks - Giulia and Stelvio would both benefit a lot from visual perspective with LED headliight - first, their front end would stop apearing dated, and second, they would both loose that bird-like front end.

Name: cue2
Comment: Interesting argument. This week I went to coach cycling and as it became darker the lighting came on as it did at the same time last year. However the lights were not as effective. It was because they have been changed to LED. Useless.Having been a designer in the car industry for over thirty years following my Masters at the RCA I can tell you that the opening between the hood, bumper and fender is the worst case size on all models I.e Tungsten bulb headlight sized with a 110 parabola reflector. Putting an LED lamp in the car as an option will not change the shape unless you have a unique fascia moulding.

Name: lizard
Comment: It is not about the shape of the whole headlight unit, but very noticable xenon projectos, which resemble (in this scenario) eyes, and scudetto beaing the beak/rostrum. With changing the interior of the headlights to full LED technology they could eliminate that resemblance while at the same time making the front end more modern and thus in tune with the rest of the styling - the front end is the weakest part of the design of both Giulia and Stelvio.

Name: cue2
Comment: I think any comment on the subject of aesthetics should be qualified by a statement that it’s one's own opinion. That applies in this case but you only write your opinions as statements. Name: SteveMeggs
Comment: Hi,I have a 6 month old Milano petrol 280BHP model which is great apart from one thing, the throttle delay. This is particularly noticeable when reversing off my drive and then switching to drive. press the throttle and wait, hopefully it kick in before the car coming up the road rear ends me!.Its a bit better in sports/dynamic mode but still hesitates, if you press the throttle to far when it does finally wake up it shoots up the road like a rocket which is not particularly good.Does anyone know of a solution to this delay, should I consider getting the engine chipped?Any suggestions greatly appreciated.

Name: Tjalle
Comment: Since nobody else bothered.....I don`t have experience from that engine, but from other Alfa engine and Alfa engineers. They would not accept behaviour as you describe it.There is a fault - either in engine alone - or if you have AUTO - match between AUTO and engine.Dealer should fix it.Don`t chip it.

Name: wictod
Comment: Defo something not right about that experience and it's not a quirk of car either.. Having said that, I still prefer the feel of the clutch bite of a manual over the auto, pulling away into a corner it feels like a giant bumper car that does lurch a bit.. chipping it isn't something I'd do to rectify the lag, rather have it looked at by the Alfa mechanics..

Name: SteveeGee
Comment: My 2.2 diesel is very similar, sometimes there is a noticeable delay between throttle press and actual go. I thought this was just turbo spool, but I now think it is gearbox programming.Alfa is using the ZF 8hp box, used in a wide variety of other cars, BMW, Jaguar, Audi etc and it is universally praised, but I wonder if the software is universal or if the manufacturers each have their own implementation. Has anyone had good experience of driving say a BMW 330i or Jaguar 2.0d auto? I’ve come from a Lexus CVT which had its own quirks but the advantage was it didn’t have a clutch as such and with elec assistance, pickup was instant.

Name: Tjalle
Comment: I had X4, 3l petrol. Gearbox worked fine - but not near my Stelvio QF. I had to manually downshift at fast overtaking - QF does it better than I can…… Of course engine is part of the equation.I suggest you are both victims of "bad" software. Dealers should fix."Clutch bite of a manual over auto"!!? In QF you get all bite you need - at any speed or circumstances. :blabla:

Name: mchristyuk
Comment: Steve,Out of interest I did a quick Google search for this and forums from Volvo, Audi, Jag, etc.. all threw up people complaining of the same thing.Most of them relate to the gearbox being the culprit, but in our case I'm sure it's engine mapping as the revs don't even rise so there's no chance of the gearbox being able to do anything...Mark

Name: cue2
Comment: The fact that it’s a particular trim level , Milano in this case, has nothing to do with this issue. The engine is more relevant. My 2.2 diesel doesn’t have the issue, unless I accidentally rest the left foot on the brake....

Name: Doric
Comment: Stelvio 2.0 petrol, 22 months old, 12,150 miles. Just spent an anxious week after the low engine oil warning light came on, and the central digital display showed zero oil. Naturally, I quickly topped up, carefully, in increments (1.5 litres in all) and re-checked. No change to the warnings. Had my local garage drain the oil and replace entirely (5.2 litres). Still showed no oil. Was on the point of changing the oil level guage, when realised that the mileage could have something to do with it.My garage tricked the car into thinking it had just been serviced (reset service) and bingo: oil warning light goes out and the digital oil level shows full.Key learning : while the car thinks it's due a service (which was not actually correct, anyway) the oil level indicator will tell you that there's NO oil in the car. Madness. Thought important to share.
I take it has a dipstick to manually check?

Name: Doric
Comment: Alas not. That, clearly, would have helped avoid all the pain.

Name: Pud237
Comment: The sooner someone develops a dipstick retrofit kit for these engines the better.

Name: wictod
Comment: I don't understand the logic behind this oil level system, ok so it doesn't have a dipstick get that, but regardless it has to be a reliable oil or no oil situation.. no secret resets or system frigs to understand exactly what the level is..

Name: Zoo
Comment: Its the way a lot of manufacturers are going with level sensors instead of physical dipsticks!

Name: SteveeGee
Comment: Seems to be designed by the same person who designed the low Ad-Blue warning. Bring the check engine light on first then bring the ad-blue low light on much later. Refilling with Ad-Blue resets both lights. In the meantime a wasted trip to the dealer and a forced DpF Regen tried and failed to reset it!

Comment: Should have said there is no way to check the level of the Adblue tank.........

Name: Top Down
Comment: No one yet mentioned that you MUST not have speed camera alerts on your sat nav in France, big fine, turn them off. Also driving in Switzerland you need a vignette to drive on the Mway, get it from Switzerland Travel Centre £35.50, its a must. Cars were being checked at the boarder in Basel last week when we came through. Speed cameras in France are often no where near as visible as those in the UK and I was surprised how many cameras have popped up in Italy this year.

Name: Top Down
Comment: Andy Bowden said:The Stelvio's and Giulia's maps don't have speed camera locations in France. They just happen to have unspecified danger symbols and warnings near to speed camera locations.The thing not to have in France is a speed trap detector. Those can get you into big trouble even if they are switched off.I always buy my vignettes at the Swiss border. I see no need to buy them beforehand. Major Swiss border crossings have two lanes for those already with and those without vignettes. Petrol stations sell vignettes too if you happen to cross at an unmanned border crossing.AndyClick to expand...Indeed and as a Giulia owner I am quite aware of that, but my post was of a more general nature for anyone looking who might be using alternative GPS.What is the advantage in getting the vignette at the boarder? Some boarders are unmanned, on our recent tour we entered Italy from France, only crossing into Switzerland at the top of the Gd St Bernard an unmanned crossing. No, its just so easy to get it sent to your home, get it on the windscreen before you leave and thats one thing less to do and saving having to stop.

Name: Doric
Comment: In relation to the question about beam deflectors, I asked my servicing garage today to recommend the correct solution (2018 Stelvio Super with Xenon headlamps). They rang Alfa - no idea. My chap said best not to stick anything on the plastic outer casing, but I'm none the wiser about how to fix the headlamps so they'll be legal on the continent. Any ideas?

Name: Andy Bowden
Comment: I drive on the continent very little after dark so my habit is to have a set of Eurolites with me in case a Gendarme gets difficult. I did fit them to my Giulia on one trip. No sign of damage to the lights after having the Eurolites fitted for 10 days.Used them many times on the 156 GTA without ill effect. They come off best if the headlights are warm. It is important to get all the adhesive off. I never needed to use any solvent.I know of no other solution.Andy

Name: mj2k
Comment: Well, many of our 'proper' 4x4s will leave the standard SUVs standing, e.g. my Subaru's drivetrain is virtually the same as the one in those little Brat pickups all the farmers used in the late 70s / 80s so copes far better with the snow on the twisty, uncleared roads round where I live than most; I often laugh at BMWs embedded in hedges, drive gingerly past wheelspinning Touaregs, etc and even the occasional unwary Discovery driver, but I'm under no illusion it'll do anything like the sort of offroader the article writer is namedropping, like this[ame]https://youtu.be/mKEG-uMsHio?t=110[/ame]

Name: dtone
Comment: I was wondering if there any Stelvio owners and get their feedback on how the transition from one car to the other. I am still not sure on the Stelvio or the SUV jump that most manufacturers want everyone to go to.What would you say the pro's and con's owning one.I've owned four 159 Sportwagon Ti in a 1.9 and 2.4 diesel,Qtronic 2.4 diesel and now tbi petrol. Sadly there are no wagon for Alfa in the nearby future so might need to look at other brands. I still own a GT 3.2 so I'm not completely saying goodbye to An Alfa,only for my daily car.My Mrs will be happy for a Stelvio so I don't need to convince her, I just find it hard to convince myself to get one.

Name: cue2
Comment: Have you driven a Stelvio?I drove a 159 back when it was new and found it disappointing then.The Stelvio replaced a Giulietta in our household and was alongside a Kuga for a few months until we downsized it to an IQ. The Stelvio is much bigger than a Kuga but weighs the same. It drives very nicely with quick steering and a fine auto box. It’s the fastest car I’ve had too. 0-60 in 6.5 secs and so easily.

Name: dtone
Comment: No not yet. I'm sure the drive will not disappoint me but it is a big car. I have been in the Alfa showroom about four or five times to see it in terms of space as I have two kids.I think that is my dilemma that its an SUV and sits high. It just feels wrong to sit up high if that makes sense.Which Stelvio did you buy?

Name: cue2
Comment: I am not a big fan of sitting on the floor of a car. The Stelvio I got was a Speciale. The Nero looks good but lacks a few things like full leather etc

Name: wictod
Comment: I've come from a 3.0 GTV which I still own.. which is low... being high is a strange feeling at first, also when you boot it you don't feel like you're going as fast so you have to keep an eye on that.. and you have to breath in a bit on width restrictions etc but there are so many pluses, really happy with the Stelvio (280 petrol).

Name: Alf M.
Comment: Hi, yes we went from a SW TBi to a 280hp petrol Speciale. No complaints apart from the 159 was a stunner to look at.The auto gearbox is a charm, and flappy paddles add fun when you want. It pulls so sweetly, looking and feeling big and solid but with that Italian ‘go kart’ feel at the wheel. The ‘up high’ thing is mitigated by the low down handling the car has. I’m still learning to drive it after a few months, but they’re the kind of lessons I really look forward to!Try a test drive if you’ve not already done so, I think you’ll be convinced.

Name: leraunch
Comment: I moved up from a 159SW to a Stelvio. I have two kids and find the Stelvio much more practical the 159 had a narrow boot lid so struggled to fit things in the Stelvio is more accessible. I have got used to the higher driving position and the way the Stelvio drives is doesnt feel like an SUV more like a large hot hatchback, it really is impressive and a joy on twisty roads with the flappy paddles. That said the 159 was and is a more comfortable cruiser, i used to drive a fair few long distances with work and the 159 would just soak up the motorway miles and the seats were so comfortable. Also agree the looks of the 159 will turn heads, the Stelvio is nice but the 159 was beautiful.

Name: Stelvio20
Comment: I have a Stelvio now, but I am gonna trade it in for a Giulia (if I get a good price from alfa for my Stelvio) or a new BMW 3 serie touring (for the extra cargo space and for the fact I want a descent Nav) . The Stelvio drives very well for a suv, but you couldn't compare it to sedan. It is my first and last suv for me.

Name: PapaSmurf
Comment: It doesn't drive as big as it looks. When I drove it for the first time after a few minutes I didn't feel it was particularly high. Drive it like a hot hatch, Just watch the width to start with.

Name: cue2
Comment: It does seem a bit snug on with restriction pillars, with the sensors beeping like mad!

Name: dtone
Comment: Thank you everyone for all your feedback. I guess I need to drive it just to get a feel for it.It's just a shame they didn't consider a wagon. Now if the Stelvio qv on offer I'll buy one asap but a bit out of my price range.

Name: goram

Having said that I’m sure I ordered the reverse camera option on the Stelvio it’s great plus the tyres aren’t as sensitive to kerbs anyway as they aren’t as low profile.

Name: Enigma95
Comment: Hi peeps, getting my Stelvio QF in a couple of weeks and looking to get another set of wheels for the winter tyres in the UK, don't want to spend a fortune on them but open to any advice/thoughts that can help, thanks

Name: Tjalle
Comment: Since nobody has answered.There are - at least- two problems with rims:-the hughe Brembo front brakes. It is difficult to find rims, which will get you clearence. I failed.-you need- probably - at least - 19" rims - not a major problem.I ended up with installing winters on OEM rims - not a very good solution.

Name: Enigma95
Comment: Thanks Tjalle, thought it was something I'd said :rofl:As you, really wanted to avoid swapping tyres on oem, was looking at these which according to site would fit StelvQFhttps://www.performancealloys.com/carsearch/alloywheels/?pcd=149

Name: Tjalle
Comment: If you have a dealer claiming they will fit - and decent style - I would go for them. Preferrably having dealer/shop. install. You have to decide if you want TPMS. I would go for pirate kit - they are - very often- good - and half price. I would let dealer/shop do the programming to adapt to vehicle.

Name: Enigma95
Comment: Sounds good to me Tjalle, also looking at thesehttps://www.wheelbasealloys.com/all...black/20-inch/alfa-romeo/stelvio/2016-present

Name: Tjalle
Comment: Styling is OK with me, however: I did not see specifically fitment for QF nor anything about TPMS.I would check if there is a shop near you, which can install TPMS - if you want that. They are more likely to cooperate if they can sell you the tyres.

Name: Enigma95
Comment: Will do some research locally also, just to make sure :rotate:

Name: wictod
Comment: Hi,Was wondering, do you have to return to the dealer you purchased the car from for a warranty issue. Problem I have is the dealer I got the car from is quite a way away from me and is about 3.5 hours of travelling on public transport if I leave the car overnight... also when I tried to ask to speak to the Tech about things they were quite resistant to let me speak directly to them saying they were difficult to get hold ofand when relaying the issues through the receptionist who was talking to them on the phone whilst I was standing at the counter they got their wires crossed about what I was trying to explain so don't really want that experience again.. however, the work they did do in replacing the radiator was fine..I think I have a battery or intelligent battery power management problem as the start / stop works very infrequently (a blessing some may say) and the battery rarely gets charged above 12.4 volts even with all the infotainment / aircon and lights off after a long run..Cheers

Name: cue2
Comment: You can go to any dealer for warranty work. My car has only done 4000 miles since I collected it new in mid December. The SS has only not been available after it was left for two weeks while we were on holiday. I’d suggest you try Ancaster in Dartford.

Name: wictod
Comment: Thanks Cue2 ... I take it you've had a positive experience from them?

Name: Sweeney70
Comment: Just remembered that they recently serviced my car under the maintenance plan I pay for and when I got it home I noticed that the oil level wasn;t up to the position it should have been! Only about 66% of the max. which makes me wonder.

Name: wictod
Comment: Sweeney70.. Thanks for the heads up on Ancaster.. regarding the oil change... when I picked mine up from the dealer Lipscomb Maidstone after a service the oil level was just above the middle of the gauge.. I checked in the oil cap and the oil was new and clean so assumed it had been changed, I subsequently bought some top up oil and too heed of the warning to add in small increments.. I put about a third of a litre in and after a 30 minute run out checked the oil level and it was right on the upper mark so didn't need a lot in it. I think the oil gauge only reflects the upper limit of level rather that from empty to full if that makes sense.. Cheers

The car I am looking at is bought in 2018, but appears to be a 2017 model, so perhaps a later 2017 production.The used one I am looking at does not appear to be a 'First Edition', since it has adaptive cruise control.The new car I am looking at is 'just' a 200hp version, whereas the used one I am considering, is a 280hp version.Thanks in advance!

Name: SirRagnar
Comment: Thanks niegowicOf those items you mentioned, I would miss android auto also (not an iphone guy) and possible active suspension. I don't really know how much about active suspension, so don't know if it worth it?

Name: cue2
Comment: Getting the full warranty is a bonus buying a new Stelvio especially with the 5 years in the U.K.Also I think the clever suspension may be expensive to fix otherwise.

Name: jwq
Comment: the electronic dampers are definately worth it, however, I think the stelvio actually has 2 versions....the "budget" version, which uses the Koni FS dampers (seeFS dampers) which are mechanical, stand alone, and the full electronic dampers as available on the giulia (seee-dampers.pdf)

Name: SirRagnar
Comment: Thanks. Is there any way to check which dampers are on a specific car?

Name: SirRagnar
Comment: Seems the Stelvio is not equipped with active suspension in Denmark, except the QV, so none of them probably have it.Warranty is also just 2 years here - sadly, if they provide more it is taxed same as the car itself, which is 150% tax (in addition to 25% VAT), so only Kia really gives more than 2 years.

Name: niegowic
Comment: Well it's sometimes possible to retrofit android auto and Apple car Play.. as it goes for warranty you can't extend it? In poland we can extend warranty before 2 years periodWysłane z mojego SM-N950F przy użyciu Tapatalka

Name: jwq
Comment: electronic dampers are easy to recognise.... There are 2 accelerometers mounted at the front of the engine space (probably hard to recognise if you don't know what they look like), and if you look at the top of the dampers in the engine space you will see an electric wire coming out of each damper (easy to see)......

Name: SirRagnar
Comment: Thanks for all the advice. I ended up getting the new 2019 Stelvio and then I will live with 200hp (at least until warranty is out, then I might go to The Netherlands).For information, I asked the dealer. In Denmark only the QV has electronic dampers. I also asked about warranty, it can be purchased as an extension up to 5 years. Considering that, although it means it will be a long time until I can get it chipped

Name: ciafok
Comment: You don't have to run it at 200hp until the warranty ends (unless you want to...) - there're few well known box manufacturers which provide solutions for Stelvio. I've personally put the RaceChip medium box in my 200hp Stelvio, but you may choose another one. The common thing between all these boxes would be that they require less than 30 minutes to uninstall with no permanent changes in the car left. Obviously - be careful when buying one and stick to the well-known, reputable manufacturers...

Name: wictod
Comment: Hi All,Just popped across from the GTV forum as I've just bought a year old Stelvio Speciale in Montecarlo Blue with red calipers and teardrop wheels which I pick up Saturday..I live in an area where high value cars are being taken from the drives daily but it appears to be organised criminals rather than opportunists. The Stelvio has keyless entry and I want to mitigate the possibility of theft as much as practical.I have been told that a steering wheel lock is a good way to deter this happening as it adds extra hassle for any would be thief.What's the view on this and are there any recommendations as to which one. I won't be going as far adding posts into the drive but want to make sure I covered most of the obvious preventions.Cheers

Name: cue2
Comment: I have a Stelvio Speciale in Monte Carlo Blue and Red Calipers but I didn’t order keyless locking. The original owner of the one you’re buying must have got it as an extra? A steering wheel lock and all the hassle and damage it’ll do to the steering wheel seems to outway any benefits for you but probably a good idea if you think it’ll be targeted. At £1300 or something like that for a headlight it does represent a valuable collection of spares I suppose. When I worked in Essex a colleague was given a theft warning letter from the local constabulary with the handover pack for his Focus RS. Not sure if the Stelvio is in the same situation.

I ran out this morning and put a white micro cloth around the neck of the filler.. stopped after a few minutes and it was wet with fluid? Am not even using the washers or wipers at this point unless they pressurise in the background.. I'll try and get a photo of the neck of the washer bottle at a different angle.. looks like when you add fluid it doesn't go straight down like normal bottles with a long neck, on this it goes straight into a right angle piece and doesn't look to allow gravity to keep it in the tank? however if it's just me i'm obviously talking rubbish or have a weird setup on the particular car.. cheers

Name: jwq
Comment: wictod said:..... Looking at the diagram (the light blue image with all the numbers) it appears that if the bottle is full then fluid will easily make it's way to the filler as the available space in the tank is almost level with the filler?Why it's leaking on mine and nobody else is weird. Maybe most tanks are empty.. or there's some sort of non return valve in the tubing missing..cheersClick to expand...yeah, light blue is same as dark blue, just front and backside view....I also thought about non return valve, but can't find any mention of this..... Name: Kctime
Comment: It is Vesuvio. I have had the springs on for four months now with no issues. Handling dynamics are actually improved with less body roll. Steering is as sharp as ever. Did one track event and it was absolutely incredible! Main issue was not the suspension but the brakes! The stock fitment is totally unsuitable. Front pads were gone after one 20 min. session. And because of the electronic issues a brake pad change initiates, I won’t be taking it to the track again. Pity, because I broke NUMEROUS hearts out there.

Name: GVblue
Comment: Hooligan :rotate:

Name: GVblue
Comment: Tjalle said:Beware - if you did not change shocks! I lowered my X4 35 mm with H&R - and STD shocks. Had - slight - impact from front bumpstops. You are 40mm down (1 1/2") and will - probably - ride on bump stops on and off. Especially if you are in "bad road country" like e.g. Detroit (trees indicates you are not).Apart from that, you have messed with the Torque Vectoring system - which I did not dare to do. In reality it is an Integrated Chassis Control system, with end output regulating - individually - rear wheels rotational speed to create forward or rearward force on either of rear wheels. Very tricky. To my knowledge the very first vehicle to have such a system installed - and it works!! Input from: steering wheel, vehicle speed, lateral acceleration and rotational (yaw) speed.Means of regulation are two clutches and two planetary gears at rear axle.Click to expand...I'd sacrifice a bit of cornering speed to look that cool.

Name: Tjalle
Comment: Then go ahead. Cheapest to buy is from one of large retailers in Germany - they will send to you for a reasonable cost. Preferrably before B-day.

The setup of the suspension is correct accordingly and to lower it would most likely end up wrong. That’s when you go retro and get what they used to call a saloon car. Not practical but a Giorgio platform car set at that height where you leave the spoiler on a speed hump in Dulwich.

Name: Tjalle
Comment: Kctime.There are no reason, why you should have a loss of cornering speed.What one might encounter is:-front shocks touching bump stops and having harsh ride. Worst case scenario: damaging front suspension.-the - probably - sensitive calibration of system, being slightly out of tune, and hence steering precision might suffer somewhat.You are obviously happy, so no sweat.

Name: MikeFish
Comment: Tjalle said:MikeFish.There are different versions of Torque Vectoring. TV is a buzz word and used by some of the upscale manufacturers, using more or less advanced versions of what within industri is called Integrated Chassis Control - using mostly the input described above, but with various means to get TV.Macan has an El Cheapo system, using - individually - rear brakes to create TV. I.e. no forward push - only braking. I seem to remember Audi using planetary gears on front axles, which might work - but I doubt as effectively as on Stelvio QF.Is your Giulia RWD or AWD? I seem to recollect AWD Giulias are not imported into UK.Click to expand...The RS6 has a proper version of torque vectoring in conjunction with the Sport Differential just like you describe for the Stelvio (but was introduced in 2013).My Giulia is RWD. An AWD version would have been very tempting for me; I'd happily sacrifice a little handling ability for all year round drivability. But by the sounds of it, making it AWD like the Stelvio would have still retained its great handling.

Name: Tjalle
Comment: Mike, even if it is a proper TV, I still believe it operates on front wheels - which - from Audi point of view - makes sence, since they claim to be a FWD company.My gut feeling is that the end result will not be as fun nor as effective. I take it though, that you were satisfied - which is what counts. I have never driven a vehicle that comes close to my QF, but has to admit that 60% of that is the engine, including sound. Also the ZF gearbox worked fine in my X4, but has been tuned into perfection in QF.

Name: cue2
Comment: Let’s hope it’s better than the magnetic filings shock absorbers on the RS4 and the sky roof on the A2 that we tolerated for a couple of years. All theoretical features that are built regardless of real tolerances and you wouldn’t want when the warranty runs out.Lamp suppliers I worked with when I worked at Ford told me Audi don’t care if it lasts or works all that well. It just has to look precise. The latest thing is their stupid camera door mirrors. Ergonomically inferior and no cheaper to fix.

Name: MikeFish
Comment: Audi magnetic ride suspension was only ever used on the A3s, TTs and R8s. Good system and pretty reliable from my experience. However, I think you meant the DRC (Dynamic Ride Control) system as used on RS4s, RS6s and RS5s. This has had trouble from the outset in 2002 and Audi continued to use it even up to the latest RS6 although in a much more reliable state (and slightly less effective if you ask me). It is a great system though; the B7 RS4 cornered flatter than an other car I could think of yet had a comfortable ride that didn't shake your fillings out. Just a shame they couldn't nail the reliability. And it was very expensive to fix.

Name: cue2
Comment: A colleague had an RS4 and learned why everybody with any sense replaced the suspension clever bits. His warranty job was incredibly expensive and they extended the warranty when he got it back. He still got rid afterwards. Oh and the battery came loose in the boot because of a bad weld or something. Audi give the impression of quality, mainly because they close up gaps between things. The Skyroof on our A2 didn’t work very well , especially on a hot day when thermal expansion disabled it. I spoke with a Ford engineering manager who said the supplier had approached him and it was not robust enough for use on the C-Max.

Name: MikeFish
Comment: The cheapskates replaced the perfect (but unreliable) suspension with inferior coilovers. New suspension every 4 years was part of RS4 ownership as far as I was concerned.I agree Audi have issues but which manufacturer doesn't? Im sure if you go on any other manufacturer forum you will see people talking about issues with Alfas, BMWs, Volvos etc.

Name: oktopi
Comment: after month of searching of issue in my car a specialists has find out overheated fuse socket for abs in box section undrehood on left side. when you remove this fuse you will get the same issue with lack of braking and really soft braking pedal. it should be hard pedal and brakes should work hard but with strong respond.I will continue later on when I will get more news.

Name: SteveeGee
Comment: I've got a Milano with the std audio, which I believe (according to the brochure/manual) is slightly more speakers and an improved amp, but not the HK full upgrade, which has even more speakers and a more powerful amp.I find the audio is very "muddy" and "woolly", overpowered by mid-range IMO, might be described as very warm sounding. As a result I've been experimenting with settings and seem to have settled on +2 bass, -5 Mid and +4 Treble, which sounds better, but not great. Have also been trying moving the fade towards the back slightly.How are others finding things? Does the audio improve with age? Any other settings or tips? How do those with the HK find it?

I'm not aware of historical issues here, but it is/was a novelty as previous car I don't think I ever ventured near the dipstick and never had an issue!

Name: driver2828
Comment: Hi Guys!as i don't know how to help in Europe, i thought i'd ask you if someone has a solution for my problem.I have a Stelvio Q with theft warning system (which I better would not have ordered :headache: !!) and I often have my dog in the trunk with me.Now the problem is that when i park the car, lock it and he's on board, the alarm goes off practically every time.I looked at it with my dealer and he set the sensitivity of all sensors to a minimum of 30% / 0.8° and the f***ing alarm still goes off again and again.There must be a way how i can deactivate the theft warning system completely. My dealer tells me that this is not possible but I can't believe it. What do you say?Many thanks in advance for your advice!Greetings from Switzerland!driver2828

Name: driver2828
Comment: OMG the solution is so simple. Thanks for the super fast feedback jwq!! I'll try it out tomorrow.

Name: epsonix
Comment: Small info from me. Since 2018 Giulias do not have factory fitted (into BCM) alarm (at least in Poland, but I guess EU or maybe rest of world also applies - guessing due to complaints for the built in alarm?), dealer fitted Mopar alarm to my car (was requirement of FCA Leasing bank to have alarm). With Mopar alarm you can deactivate internal sensors by 2 full cycles of turning on/off car from start/stop button on your steering wheel - you will hear beeps, and then next lock of the car frome either key fob or button at car handle, alarm will ignore internal sensors and so you can leave your dog in the car all right (of course with lowered bit side windows and at safe temperature to keep dog comfortable and safe).

Name: Tilum
Comment: You obviously have good taste in cars.. I've got a Stelvio Qf too, and one of my other cars is a Maserati GranCabrio MC (convertible version of the MC Stradale). I've also owned a Porsche 981, and driven many Porsche 911s (inc. the 991). The Stelvio Qf certainly feels lighter and easier to chuck around than the MC, however you feel closer to the road in the MC than in the Qf (hardly surprising really). Compared with the Porsches... the SQf isn't as agile, but it's incredibly good for an SUV - more like a hot-hatch than a tall 4x4.

Name: Tjalle
Comment: Again: transporting your dogs in rear compartment is not bad - but not the safest. Best is dog with harness attached to rear seat belt anchor - NOT around seatbelt. I have just one dog, which has a dog-cover, which fully covers left part of rear seat up to armrest. Easy to take out and clean.Harness prevents dog from shooting into back of front seat in a severe crash. Some of front seat backs have very hard surfaces.Everyone to his liking - I will not push further.

Name: Tilum
Comment: To be fair, the dogs will barely ever be in the car (perhaps just once a year!) But I wanted to know that they could fit in there okay should they need to!

Name: dcjarvis
Comment: I think anyone in the market reading that would have gathered that there’s not much between the two - apart from brand and all that goes with it. Plus when they look into it the VFM you get from the Steve spec would be a big factor.

Name: hbv
Comment: Yes, I am convinced that the quality comes down although I do not claim that they are bad. All what I say is that Porsche is not any longer 'the company' as they used to be in the past. Porsche had e.g. motor problems with the water cooled 911. 911 up to the model 993 run 200 - 300000 Km without problems. The material quality e.g. of the interior is more or less on Golf / BMW / etc. level. Porsche still think they are exclusive. Yes if you take the price, they are. Porsche build very good cars, but other do the same. For me the Alfa Romeo Stelvio is technically on the same if not even higher level as the Macan, quality wise not far away, price level far lower, exclusivity higher. People turn their head for a Stelvio - not for a Macan.

Name: Tjalle
Comment: PR, thanks.This is not a complete Benchmarking, but just a first - off-hand - try. I know there are more attributes/characteristics to consider, but I just wanted to make it simple.

Name: Tjalle
Comment: PR - second thought. I don`t think people buying a Stelvio QF- or similar - give much thought to cost of running - anyway, I did not.That is, then, interesting: how will Big Boys convince those people to buy an electric performance SUV? And also: how will they be able to match QF handling, with a much heavier vehicle?There is neglibel leaning in curves on QF - thanks to Torque Vectoring and rather stiff shocks. But with 2500 kg?

Name: Tjalle
Comment: I expected one or two contenders to show up in Geneva - at least as concept vehicles - but no - no show.EV-SUV:s might have a slight advantage with - relative - low CG, because of batteries installed at bottom, but will have a problem with heavy load on tyres.Best bet will be new Macan - if they will abandon their El Cheapo Torque Vectoring and go for the QF system - who ever is producing it.

Name: Nex
Comment: I've recently picked up my Vesuvio Grey Milano Edizione (280 petrol) from Adrian at Beechdale. My second car from them and excellent service again. A friend of mine went to the same dealer interested in a Giulia and said he was there for twenty mins without even an acknowledgement so he left. Name: markies
Comment: markiet said:It always interesting to see how the sales experience can vary from rep to rep, i guess what's more important is the consistency of the service experience. My two local garages are Thames Motor in Slough and Palmers in Hemel Hempstead.I drove the other car I have been looking at, the new Honda CRV Hybrid, yesterday. I do really like it; it's top of the range EX so has everything on it, AWD, leather seats, HUD, heated front and rear seats, heated steering wheel, panoramic opening sunroof, remote tailgate , lots of security and sensors, very practical etc . Drove it for an hour and, although the claimed 0-60 for the car is 9.x, it felt faster due to the electric kick when pulling away. It was very quiet and pretty smooth overall. A bit gutless when in normal drive mode with Eco enabled, but livens up in sport mode - problem is then you get a big hit on the MPG! It would be very easy to drive and live with and if I had a young family where practicality is very high up the agenda then it would be a good car to have.As I stated earlier in the thread, I have had at least 10 hondas over the rear, usually as a second practical car and frankly was just going to get the CRV Hybrid. However I felt a little cheesed off that the current CRV diesel I had basically had dropped in value so much (not worth more than i owe on it), they aren't competitive with the interest rate (6.2%), no discount on the new car (guess they think it will be a runaway success), only a 3 year warranty on the car (though more on the batteries), servicing not included (costs 599) that I felt compelled to look at alternatives.Honda is however giving away a free Honda lawnmower if you buy an SUV in Q1, great.I then took the Milano 280 for a spin again, and it was great. Drives better, faster, looks better and give the 5 year warranty and 3 years free servicing and roadside assistance it gives me piece of mind. Residual values look better than the Honda too.The Honda with a couple of options is a 40k car, the Milano with a few bits is 50k, but because of discounts, finance contribution , low interest rates, free servicing it works out a lot cheaper to run over 3 years (even taking into consideration less MPG, higher insurance and tax).So now I need finalise on the best deal and a few add-ons, hopefully ordering rain the next few days!Click to expand...If you love it as much as I love mine - there will be a "lotta luv"Happy ordering

Name: Tjalle
Comment: Sorry, but I could not keep this to myself.There are a lot of cars on the market with- more or less - faked exhausts: thin pipes ending in larger tips/tubes.This is worse: the new Audi SQ5, has 4 nice exhaust tips integrated in body - but not connected to the exhaust pipes. Exhausts pipes are bent downwards before rear body panel.Luckily my QF has the real deal - but with a twist: normally only 2 inner tubes are active, but in RACE mode outer tubes - only - are active.My X4 with BMW M Performance exhausts had two rectangular tips, which were fed by exhausts coming from silencer in Sport andstraight from "engine" in Track.
