Name: cue2
Comment: What a brilliant name for a Stelvio chief engineer; Filippo Epifani.He describes the Giorgio platform handling feature and the Stelvio has more aluminium than the Giulia and the 4WD to make it faster off the line than the 2WD Giulia.

Name: Tjalle
Comment: Whatever his name - he has done an incredible job - that is if he was also responsibel for Quadrifoglio.

Name: horsepower27
Comment: I had one as a courtesy car for 24 hrs the other day while my Giulia was in for a replacement headlight.Was just a boggo diesel Super but the handling is absolutely amazing for an SUV, put an instant grin on, and I have a Giulia QF, not surprised Porsche are benchmarking it.Sent from my SM-G950F using Tapatalk

Name: cue2
Comment: It's pretty astounding , to the point where I try to think of excuses to drive the thing. Not very good ecologically but it means my dad will get more visits from me driving to his nursing home. I even took our Dualit toaster to the HQ in Crawley for a rebuild rather than posting it as it was only a bit further to drive on the way to see my dad.The Stelvio reminds me of my carbon road bike for the lightness and precision. You can feel the road but ,as my daughter said, it's so smooth. It must be the low unsprung weight and rigidity.

Name: cue2
Comment: This is a general PCP question; the deposit is not returned to you as it is effectively used to subsidise the overal payments which cover depreciation over the term and interest.In this case the PCP deposit has more effect as it's over only 24 months. Divide the £6-7k by 24 and you'll see how much it takes of each month. Looks like a good deal. Also , if you exceed 8000 miles you'll pay a "fine" of probably 12pence a mile.

Name: alcooker
Comment: Cheers Cue,I try and soak all the workings of PCP in, but I either just can’t get my head around it or I’m over complicating it.In layman’s terms, if it’s £299 monthly and the value at the end isn’t more than the GFV, there’s then no equity to put towards a new Alfa, so losing the £7k deposit over 24 months (7k\24=£290) means that the car is going to effectively cost me £590 a month?What sort of equity do folk who’ve done PCP’s on their Stelvios expect/hope to have? I have emailed Beechdale by the way.

Name: Pud237
Comment: How long do you think you'd likely keep it for? Presumably it would be replacing the 159?Assuming you get rid at 2 years and have done around 16,000 miles that the contract allows for, how do the 'per mile' costs stack up against the 159 or GT? Obviously going to be higher, otherwise we'd all drive new cars instead of old cars, but is the extra cost (however much that may be) worth it to drive a new car?

Name: Gator1
Comment: An opinion from across the pond. If you want a new car, you will pay ~£14,000 (£7K + £7K payments in 2 years) for it in this deal. If you want to keep it, then you will pay an additional ~£26K at the end of the lease. If you turn it in, then you enjoyed a new car for 2 years. Of course, for this to work, don't go over the 8,000 miles a year, otherwise....It always comes down as to how badly you want a new car and the entry point (£) for it. Cheers.

Name: jellemr
Comment: If you're not thinking of keeping it, and aren't going to go over the 16k miles, then you'd be about £1,500 better off by taking the PCH option on this car on their website. Same 2 year term, same car, same mileage, smaller deposit (£3k) for a slightly higher monthly fee (£377).On the PCH you get GAP insurance, RFL and roadside assistance thrown in, but I think you lose the free servicing option (on 16k miles you'd have to pay for 1 service).

Name: cue2
Comment: The interest rate is pretty amazing then compared to what I just signed up for, about 3.something.I knew I shouldn't have read this! Still I intend to further overpay on the PCP to bring the monthly payment down.

Name: cue2
Comment: Now, bikes..there's a way of spending money!I've had a bit of a capital investment programme on over the last two years too.Just got some Crank Brothers wheels for my Bianchi carbon hard tail. And the Campagnolo wheels for the Pinarello...Now I've got to sort out bike carrying for the Stelvio. Once I've done that I'll have to pay off the car and keep it in three years to justify the rack. Which is where the 5 year warranty comes in.

Name: Pud237
Comment: alcooker said:I’d say this is number 2 reason behind number 1- can I actually afford to spend £300 pm whilst saving another £300 towards the next deposit. £600pm on a car before insurance, tax and fuel, honestly no, my family’s lifestyle would take a hit.I would like a new car simply because the new Alfa’s look great, appear to drive amazingly well and I love the cognac/brown leather.It’d be the 159 that would go, my wife mainly uses this around town and it’s so the wrong car for that. I don’t actually get to drive so much, so I’d be sorting my wife out really and then I’d have a constant worry about scrapes and such. I doubt I could hold back if they brought a Giulia SW out though.2 crazy things, I’ve spent almost £12k in 3 years on my 2 Santa Cruz mountain bikes, I have to stop buying bikes but I love em and I ride em a lot:blabla:I’ve just being trying (in my newly learned knowledge of PCP’s!) to sort one of my staff out with a new PCP deal. Her 2015 Audi Q7 3.0tdi S-line is coming to the end of its deal for which she pays £570pm @10%APR!! She works hard for it and just enjoys having a really nice car for her family, fair do’s. Priorities.Thanks all for your replies, it’s been a real eye opener!Click to expand...What do you expect the 159 to cost you per mile if you were to keep that for another 2 years? You have to deduct that from the cost of the Stelvio to see if it stacks up. If its due timing belt, never had clutch/DMF, subframe going rotten, DPF woes etc etc then there are some costs to be avoided by changing now.

Name: cue2
Comment: My last Giulietta didn't "cost" me anything in servicing , tyres etc in two years and I was two thousand in equity. I lost thousands in depreciation.I put down quite a bit in deposit on the PCP but as the servicing was just routine and it was. free there was none of the hassle that now populates the Giulietta tech section.The reason I got it to replace my first Giulietta was that it'd reached 65000 miles and things were going to need replacing/diagnosing taking time I didn't have from work . Also, it was going to continue to depreciate.

Name: alcooker
Comment: Really hoping neither car will need anything large for another 3 years, but we know how they can bite you in the butt. Last year on both cars was cambelts, clutches and a few other bits, so fairly hefty bills. It’s that situation where either one could be sold fully sorted, but doubtful the 159 would sell for more than I’ve put into it the last year or so, so probably makes more sense to keep running it until next cambelt is due, same as I did with the 156 which then got donated to Autolusso’s courtesy car fleet.Cue, yeah bikes, an enjoyable money pit! Had Alex Colnago in work the other day and have a party with him in a couple of weeks, no free bike though:grumpy:

Name: jwq
Comment: I think it's mostly in conjuction with "remote start", which they have over there (not allowed in Europe)

Name: Gator1
Comment: Exactly. A very minor improvement, but on cold days (anything less than 10 C !), I remote-start my Stelvio from my second floor office. When I get to the car is nice and warm except the seat and steering wheel which I promptly proceed to 'push the buttons'. It sure would be nice to have those On when I get to the car. I wonder why remote-start is not allowed in Europe? It is a nice feature for precisely this reason.

Name: jwq
Comment: The authorities don't want unattended cars with engine running, due to potential danger(s)As an alternative, you can get aftermarket parking heaters though, f.i. from Webasto:webasto-comfort.com/int/car-parking-heater/

Name: Gator1

Comment: 3 weeks into the joy of my new Stelvio and the dreaded windscreen chip (tiny) appeared followed by a 9" crack - National Windscreen duely fitted a replacement BUT as Alfa haven't released the calibration software for the camera to third parties the car has to go back to the dealers for the work to be done and I have the feeling that they haven't done one of these before..... What a farce and one avoidable if Alfa will release the software.While its in the dealers they need to refit the passenger side fog light that seems to have gone into hiding in the bumper -

Name: Rossorichie
Comment: I seem to have got one that by passed quality control :grumpy: - the fog light duly disappeared again and this time the dealer agreed it was manufacturing fault - I think down to missing location bolts - OK that got fixed - now the intercooler has cracked - :grumpy: - the thing is I still like it a lot - drives well and for a fat assed car it can be hustled along easily. The upside is that I'm driving a nice Giulietta and the Stelvio will come back pampered.

Name: Gator1
Comment: You have had your share of issues...Let's hope is all clean sailing from now on!

I assumed I had left the stereo on as it wasn't that long after I had parked up.Some 20mins or so after parking up as we were walking down TO the pub there was a distinct but soft beep of anout 3 seconds coming from the n/s front wheel arch (obviously where certain circuitry is)Anyone experience similar?

Name: hbv
Comment: Could it be that you hear the van running? The electric van runs after stopping the engine for a short time.

Name: markies
Comment: Thanks for the reply and a good suggestion. However, it's def not the fan - it's too quiet for that but my neighbours have said they have heard it too whilst walking by it.Puzzled!

Name: horsepower27
Comment: Quite likely the electronic braking system doing checks. But still sounds a little odd...Sent from my SM-G950F using Tapatalk

Name: markies
Comment: That suggestion makes sense - I thinkIt certainly was a strange noise

Name: Gator1
Comment: It may not be the same thing, but my Stelvio 'sings' for about 30 sec every time I open the front door. It is low key, not very high volume but noticeable. Luckily for me it is 'done' in 30 secs. Still, if the car is self checking, I would think it could do it 'quietly'

Name: hbv
Comment: My Stelvio does it and my Fiat 500X does it. However, the Fiat has no electric breaking system. It must be a kind of self-checking or a warming up of a system. In any kind it is normal and there is no reason to look for defects on your Alfa.

Name: Gator1
Comment: Yes, agree. I think it is normal. Thanks.

Name: hbv
Comment: Aurioles, may I bother you with something else.I am not happy with my blind spot monitor, i.e. there is only an optical signal but no additional accustic signal. Do you know whether the US version has accustic warning e.g. when overtaking an other car.

Name: Gator1
Comment: My understanding is that some newer Stelvios have both but older ones only the visual signal. Perhaps also the audio portion of the blind spot monitor if I do not have it. I do agree that all driving assistance packages are very helpful, especially for us older drivers :hehe:

Name: hbv
Comment: If you order a Stelvio I recommend to add the adaptable suspension including the limited slip differential. I promise you that this will satisfy your expectations: the Stelvio at least with this options has an extremely good street holding and the body moves less. However the car is bigger than your Giulietta and you are seated higher. This needs a couple of days of experience and adaption. I had before a Audi Q5 but the Stelvio is miles better on the road.

Name: Isotope
Comment: Thanks for the reply, have you had to use your car in the snow yet? If so how did you think about the car under those conditions?

Name: PapaSmurf
Comment: I moved from a Giulietta to a Stelvio. Having got used to it I just drive it much the same as I did the Giulietta. It no longer feels a "big" car. Just drive it like a hatchback.

Name: Isotope
Comment: Really? I had most of my time in the car in the dark so I couldn't really push things as far as I can in the G. The technology upgrade is very desirable but does it feel faster? I'm not sure, I know I can't change gear faster than the gearbox in the Stelvio but its a heavier car. I found the suspension too soft on rougher roads. Does it firm up with faster speeds?

Name: hbv
Comment: Sorry no. There is extremely dry and sunny weather in Switzerland. So far no snow on the roads. I am also very much interested to see how the car will perform on winter roads. But again I am very happy with the electronic suspension and the limited slip differential and strongly recommend to order it.

Name: Tjalle
Comment: Swedish car magazine has compared Stelvio (280bhp) with X3 and Volvo XC60. Stelvio came out ahead on all driving/performance tests - including fictive AWD - rollers/no snow -tests.Quadrifoglio with torque vector rear axle - and firmer chassis setting, is better. :rotate:

Name: Neri josephsbeg
Comment: Hi I have a 2017 2L stelvio with wide screen and the iOS CarPlay is not activateI leave in Israel and the cars here don’t have this option.Do you know if and how I can open or upgrade this option in my car?Neri

Name: hbv
Comment: iOS carplay (Apple / Android carplay) can only be ordered e.g. in Switzerland as from very late 2017 production model 2018. As far as I know there is no possibility for an upgrade. However go in contact with your dealer.

Name: jwq
Comment: "old" hardware (infotainment) is not compatible with android auto/carplay (AA/ACP).You can check which version you have by looking at the firmware version, it's a menu item on the infotainment. If you have firmware numbered 001.xxx.xxxor 002.xxx.xxx, it's the old hardware which is not compatibel. If you have versions numbered starting with high number, f.i. 056.xxx.xxx, it's the new hardware.Only new hardware can be enabled by Alfa for carplay.

Comment: I never believed in GAP insurance, but my sister had it, and then her Abarth was stolen - I'd certainly purchase GAP on anything that is likely to have a fair chunk of cash depreciation.Try ALA, found them to be very competitive and they used to not only price match but also beat any rival by 20% - best to give them a call rather than use their online tool for the best prices

Name: stabia
Comment: My vehicle is a 2018 Stevio with 2.4 280HP engine silver in color. I have a question for the forum about the driving. When I put the dial in Dynamic or Normal mode and punch it normally getting it up to around 50MPH, the trans revs up but doesn't seem to rev down fast enough when I take my foot off the gas pedal. If in Dynamic, I have to put it on Normal or even Added Efficiency Mode. The same is true if I'm in normal mode, I have to put it in Added Efficiency Mode to rev it down. It's feels like driving a stick, put it in first and get the speed over 20MPH. The same feel. Is this normal or something I need to have the dealership checkout?

Name: cue2
Comment: Welcome.I'm looking at replacing my Giulietta Speciale and my wife's Ford Kuga (Escape) with a Stelvio in a matter of months. They are still quite rare here and I'd imagine they are in your area too?

Name: stabia
Comment: My opinion is that they are nice SUVs. I had 2 Lincoln MKX before my Stevio and the Stevio is smaller in size but the new MKX is a great vehicle but over $50,000. I love the performance of the Stevio and gas milage gives me over 20MPG and I'm not an easy driver. I would think a Stevio for your wife would be great.A couple of thinks I can add is that I have not seen another Stevio on the road yet and I live in the Philadelphia, PA area and I have gotten tons of compliments on my 2018 Stevio which is the plain silver color. How many comments would I get if I had it in RED.

Name: Biscione1750
Comment: To the OP, I think you'll have better luck with your question on the Stelvio forums. There are not many owners who are active on this forum.

Name: adamcot
Comment: WelcomeIt's entirely normal. The gearbox holds the lower gear (higher revs) to maximise acceleration performance in "D" mode. Sometimes I just flick the "+" shift paddle to override this and get it into a higher gear sooner.

Name: Claytos
Comment: HiIs it normal for the front wheels to "bump" quite a lot when on or near full lock. Ours is 6 months old and has always done this but seems to be getting a lot worse over the last week or so.

Name: PapaSmurf
Comment: It's the tyres skipping. All to do with the Ackerman steering system.https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ackermann_steering_geometryApparently it gets worse as the temperature drops.

Name: Tilum
Comment: Yep, quite normal; especially on cars with a 'quick' steering rack.As you say, it usually occurs most when on or near full lock, and as PapaSmurf says, it usually occurs more frequently during colder temperatures.Nothing to worry about.

Name: Andy Bowden
Comment: Also some manufacturers' tyres are much more prone to it.Whilst it is normal, I do find it very disconcerting particularly in colder weather.On the Giulia Quadrifoglio with the standard PZero Corsas, the effect is very noticeable. With Michelins PS4Ss much less so.Andy

Name: JARstelvio
Comment: A few niggles some still continue. 5,500 miles now, 7 months old. Unnecessary alarm activations continue despite sensitivity being re-set by dealer. Thinking of getting them to re-set my sensitivityAlfa Recall Ref. 8223 has happened and work been done. Now we need lots of rain to see if they have worked. Rear Tailgate seals to prevent water getting in switchgear and activating release lock when moving plus A pillar water ingress onto electrics under bonnet which causes multiple 'warning's on various Lamp Circuits (Indicators etc - false warnings) I continue to love the car, and driving it puts a grin on my face. Forget trying to get any kind of 'good' fuel consumption, well especially if you want to 'drive' it. Nicely thirsty, but I didn't expect anything else. By the way Wheel Bolt Torque (from my supply dealer) 120 Nm. This is not anywhere to be found in any of the 'Handbooks' that came with the car, well I can't find it. Still do not like the 'gear' selector (sharp edges) and I still say it is too fiddly, very awkward to make fast selections between Drive / Park / Reverse and so on. The Audi A4 2017 model I had before was much better. Does not react in an intuitive way...... There....Damn fine Drive I have to say. Don't think the tyres are going to last too long :>)))))

Name: Doric
Comment: 3,500 miles, 5 months old. I agree with all of the above. It's a joy to drive and long journeys become something to look forward to. Had the Rear Tailgate seal recall letter and booked it into the supplying dealer (Snows, Southampton) about three weeks ago. The work took much longer than the 1 hour estimated in the letter because they had a bunch of other things to do (I hadn't been advised of those). This weekend, after the first significant rain in weeks, I opened the boot to watch a steady trickle of water pour out of the corner, so I'm not sure what improvement there was to that detail....

Name: JARstelvio
Comment: Ah Doric, I think that the stream of water you describe is the same stream of water I get upon opening the tailgate after car is washed or heavy rain. That water comes down the inside of the plastic detail down the edge of the tailgate, and is different to the water ingress subject of the recall. It is very annoying, and drips on your head if you forget it! Suppose it doesn't rain that much in Italy :>)) All the plastic / rubber detail and trim around the tailgate is badly designed and serves mainly to attract and hold dirt and damp as far as I can see. Tried telling Alfa in Italy but might as well have just had another pizza for all the good it did me (sadly).Still puts the grin on my face, and turns quite a lot of heads :>)

Comment: recall after saleThanks - I assume though Arnold Clark would've known about this two weeks ago when they sold him it ?He wouldn't have bought it if it was subject to a recall - not matter how minor (he's that generation !)

Name: m100leeds
Comment: adamcot said:Most cars have some sort of recall against them in their lifetime. My old Jaguar XE had a recall for a fuel pipe rubbing against the body.... that's much more alarming!It's a simple change to the wiring/water management in the tailgate area and is only an issue if there is significant amounts of water in the tailgate. The only reason that it is an official "recall" rather than a normal "service bulletin" is that there is a potential for the tailgate to open at speeds up to 3mph without warning. This could cause things to fall onto the road, and cause a crash. It's worth noting that this is a very extreme result of the problem and is very unlikely.The dealers know very little until the recall letters are issued and are given a reference number for the fix. I agree this isn't great, and Alfa UK should forewarn the dealers of anything impending so they can communicate properly to customers.Click to expand...thanksThere is a problem with his boot and memory seats in front - Arnold Clark gave the impression the electrical problem whatever it is is the issue.Nothing mentioned about water issue but again guess they don't know that bit !cheers again

Name: paddypower205
Comment: I am delighted to report that after a break away from Alfa ownership, I have now returned with a Stelvio. Actually, I picked the car up back in January and have now enjoyed 4 months of happy motoring. I have had to change my route home from work. I now use a narrow country road that would make a decent hill climb course. I do this as it's so addictive to put the car in Dynamic mode, gears to manual and flick the paddles. Once at the top of the hill, back to Natural and Automatic and relax once again.There is much talk on here about dealer experiences, so I should report that I got the car from Donnelly's in Mallusk (near Belfast) and was very happy with the treatment I got.Unfortunately, my Stelvio is still the only one I have seen in the wild. I would have hoped to have started meeting a few others on the road before now. It is noticeable how other Alfa drivers stare at the car, which definitely adds to the appeal. No-one ever stared at my Mazda CX-5.

Name: TheGrimJeeper
Comment: Well they've got the right product so enjoy the novelty before (hopefully) others cotton-on tothe fact you can have a non-German SUV.

Name: Rossorichie
Comment: This is probably obvious to a lot of people but was a first for me. If the fuel cap is closed, tight but doesn't reach the "click" position" you may find a "check engine" light appearing. This happened to me - caused a degree of consternation until I figured out the fault - (left the ODB dongle in the GTA - doh!). taking it off and repositioning it properly so it goes click fixed the problem. BTW can anyone tell me where the ODB port of these vehicles lives?

Name: GVblue
Comment: Tbenfit said:Just curious if anybody else has this issue. The day I bought my car I was driving on the freeway with cars stopping in front of me. I was going about 75 when my car was still speeding up. I brakes and the car wanted to keep accelerating. I fought it for about 15-20 seconds as the cruise would not turn off. I tried everything even taking the car out of dynamic to eco mode. It finally turned off...it would not slow down and I almost turned the car off on the freeway. Alfa says they have not had any complaints about this and had my car for 10 days. When I got my car back I took it for a drive with the head tech. We could not replicate the situation but we were driving in the middle lane about 80 when the cars in both outer lanes had slowed to about 25 the cars in front of me were slowing to about 30-35 but my car was not slowing down. I finally hit the break and the tech said that was scary it wasn’t going to stop but the break did turn off the cruise control so he said it worked lol...the tech said he was pretty scared it wasn’t going to stop. Then he tells me the adaptive cruise is suppose to slow down in that situation but then we exited to stopped cars at a light just off the freeway. My car was going to run into the back of the truck at the light so I used the break again as my car never slowed down. He then tells me it’s designed to not read stopped cars. That the adaptive cruise can only read cars that are moving? Has anybody heard of this before? Thanks for any information you might have.Click to expand...Wow! I can't wait for totally autonomous cars. :jester:

Name: Rossorichie
Comment: Picked up my new Stelvio from my local dealer in Exeter - 2.2D 210bhp Milano (Trofeo White). Its the first automatic I've owned - I've driven loads of autos over the years and this implementation has a sporty feel when driven in "D" (DNA) mode - nice. Brings a huge grin to my face. The vehicle feels big when you first get in (looks large from the outside) but it seems to shrink when you drive it and it feels, unlike other SUVs I've driven, like a car. It comes with an HK sound system which is extremely good. The collision dectection system is a hoot especially around the narrow lanes we have here in Devon. I'm looking forward to taking it on a long drive up to Northumberland later in the month and expect to get some pretty amazing fuel consumption figures - the vehicle weighs in at 1660kg compared to my previous workhorse a 210 bhp 159 Q4 Sportwagon which weighed a couple of tonnes so I'm losing the three rugby players who have been living in the boothttp://www.alfaowner.com/Forum/images/smilies/biglaugh.gif

Name: TheGrimJeeper
Comment: Sounds perfect. Pictures please!

Name: Rossorichie
Comment: Just a few images - I'm still wrestling with the sound system!!

Name: markies
Comment: Exactly what I thought at the start too. I do love it and deliberately take the twisty back roads home now. Always tickles me when other drivers esp in SUVs try to follow you into a corner in a similar mannerDid 650 miles up to and around West Yorkshire over half term - insane grin factor - especially over the A59 at Blubberhouses.Hope you enjoy it as much as I enjoy mine - apart from the over sensitive alarm!!

Name: Rossorichie
Comment: Did a return journey from Devon to Northumberland - got 48mpg (brim to brim - agreed with the onboard computer!) on the way up and 45 mpg on the way down - mainly motorway driving using cruise control (busy busy) this compares to 40 mpg I got previously in the 159 Q4 - have yet to do any real hustling in it. I'm impressed with the turning circle - my old 159 had a turning circle similar to the Titanic but this one turns on a sixpence.

Name: adamcot
Comment: Your MPG is similar to mine - I get mid to high 40's on motorway runs. In town it drops below 40mpg. The thing I found disconcerting is that in "A" mode, if you lift off the throttle at motorway speeds, the car goes into what seems to be a "lift and coast" mode, where the revs fall to idle and there is no engine braking - that took some getting used to!Glad you're enjoying the car - I'm 2,300 miles in and love it.

Name: hbv
Comment: My Stelvio (bought in Switzerland) has the blind spot monitoring option. The warning is an optical sign in the outside back mirror, but there is no additional accustic warning. This is poor especially when the sun is shining, the warning lamp can hardly be seen. I wonder wether there is an other country specification, e.g. us etc, where beside the optical warning there is also the accustic warning.Does anybody know about this?At the same time I am also not very much happy with the size of the back camera screen. Is there a possibility to enlarge the screen by an update.

Name: lizard

The car is much more capable then any other SUV out there, but if you're not interested in playing, leave the gearbox in D and relax.Research Garage at Nuneaton did a great job, kept me informed and were helpful all the way the process. I still think Alfa Romeo have a lot to do in terms of the "experience" when selling to people buying a premium car. The dealership environment is no where near as shiny and special as that of the competition, I think the buying experience is important at this level and does genuinely make a difference.Anyway, looking forward to doing many miles behind that steering wheel!Click to expand...I also bought from Nuneaton too. It seems they are one of the few dealerships that make any effort what so ever. One simple phone call from Oliver following up and the deal was done.

Name: Sir Baloney
Comment: My Giulia Veloce arrived for 1st September 2017. I drove to Italy that month. Sensational, faultless performance. Three thousand miles later, no problems whatsoever. My 159 went to Italy twenty nine times with only one steering rack end replacement in 90,000 miles. In 1978 my second Alfa, an Alfasud took my wife and me on an alpine trip over the Bernina to Caspoggio and I was bitten. The Giulia is my fourteenth Alfa. In the last forty years I have driven over 240,000 miles across Europe in Suds, 33s, 116 Giulietta, 155, 146ti, 156, 147 and Giulietta . I have found them all loyal companions and look forward to taking the Giulia to the Mille Miglia again in May. That's my safe option.

Name: spitfire
Comment: djsveloce said:Hello All...I know this is repeated in Giulia forum, but tbh I was dreading it...The great news is that it's actually really simple* Register car withhttps://maps.mopar.eu/en/home* Download License* Download Map (Make a cuppa - takes a while!)* Format your Flash Drive to NTFS* Drag License & Map to Flash drive to copy onto it (...wait some more!)* Take out to car & update your map via settings - Simples!Engine MUST be running & mine took around 1hr10mins...Interested to know what software updates are available for the car itself...? Bought on 19th December.Happy to report I have had no issues at all with Stelvio Milano Diesel thus far, but the horror stories/experiences others post on here re: Giulia & Stelvio are frankly quite scaryDo hope it all settles down over coming months with the updated software tweaks - Both are really great cars, BUT niggles regarding reliability really could be their downfallIf I had visited the forums pre-sale I think I'd have thought twice about it & gone with a safer? option...?DarrenClick to expand...HiSorry, I don't really follow what you mean about 'quite scary' stories?

Name: jwq
Comment: 1006 available, see alsohttp://www.alfaowner.com/Forum/alfa-giulia/1144162-new-map-version-1006-a.html

Name: Sir Baloney
Comment: After many aborted attempts with my Veloce, updated to 1006 today. The 16GB stick USB I was using was not as empty as I thought but once cleared, it downloaded the update on the fourth attempt. I then set off on a one and a half hour trip while it loaded- rather than sit on the drive polluting the world and doing the engine no good at all. It was within minutes of completing when I hit a traffic jam and the fuel light came on, so I had to stop for petrol. On restart it had to resume from the beginning! By the time it was loaded I had completed over eighty miles. The message is- turn off stop/start, don't turn off the engine or radio or it's go back to start-mad!

Name: GVblue
Comment: Clay19 said:I think when it comes to UK marketing with the 4x4 its hard. They're bought for safety for the kids on the school run, room for caring all the family in comfort, and superiority, never to off road as their purpose originally was. The market leaders are the Germans. The upper class buy the Range Rover. The middle class buy the Macan, Q7, X5, GLA & F-Pace. Maybe the Maserati Levante. Then the working class buy the Toyota C-HR, Mazda CX-5. Then you have all the in between ones still on sale - Q5, Q3, X3, X1. There's just too many to list. It's hard where the Stelvio fits in really, or who to market the car to. I've only seen two Giulia's as it is. Alfa have arrived too late to the partySent from my iPhone using TapatalkClick to expand...Wow! I'm "upper class" :speechless:

Name: willars
Comment: I have ordered a STELVIO Milano Edizione with the Harman Kardon upgrade and the roofbars for December/January delivery from my local dealer, Desire, Southgate (London). When ordering, I neglected to ask about whether the sound system includes Apple CarPlay which I would be keen to use as my current 159 Sportwagon had the Alfa radio unit upgraded to a superb Pioneer system which integrates well and has the useful Apple CarPlay function.My question is: Can anyone who has recently taken delivery of a new Stelvio confirm if Apple CarPlay is functional or will it be added as a software upgrade?I see that the 2018 American Stelvios have the function mentioned on page 50 of the Radio Owner's Manual Supplement supplied with their cars:https://www.alfaromeousa.com/owners/owners-service-manual

When ordering, I neglected to ask about whether the sound system includes Apple CarPlay which I would be keen to use as my current 159 Sportwagon had the Alfa radio unit upgraded to a superb Pioneer system which integrates well and has the useful Apple CarPlay function.My question is: Can anyone who has recently taken delivery of a new Stelvio confirm if Apple CarPlay is functional or will it be added as a software upgrade?I see that the 2018 American Stelvios have the function mentioned on page 50 of the Radio Owner's Manual Supplement supplied with their cars:https://www.alfaromeousa.com/owners/owners-service-manualClick to expand...There is no CarPlay on my Milano Edizione delivered at the end of Nov.However I noticed recently that the online configurator has been updated (e.g. now shows Misano Blue, and has adaptive dampers as an option which were not recently) so maybe that signifies they are now building cars that might also have CarPlay as standard?

Will see!!!From my point of view apple carplay needs a different hardware on the base of the top navi set. If this new hardware is not installed an upgrade will hardly be possible. If your car (by chance) should have the new hardware: maybe. Experience with BMW has learned, that even with the correct hardware it was not be possibel.My Consequence: My Stelvio is ordered with my dealer, but we are still waiting with the sending the order ti Italy.

Name: osney
Comment: JTD_Liam said:The prices for the Stelvio already seem competitive, so I think the initial discounts should just help ensure Alfa get plenty on the roads early on. Once they achieve this they can always lower the discounts as the cars on the road are the best advertising.What they can't surely afford is a repeat of the Giulia where they have a really competitive car that you can go one week to another without seeing anywhere.Manufacturers often do introductory offers, so I don't see this as a negative move by Alfa - it's simply what they need to do in the current market in the UK. If they reduce the discounts later, it should have a positive effect on residuals, much like the periodic price increases on the Fiat 500 positively impacted its residuals.Click to expand...It occurred to me recently that I've not yet seen a Giulia in the metal. That's perhaps not helped by our nearest dealer being over 80 miles away, but I recently drove from Fife to Suffolk and back, M6/A14 down and A1 back, and didn't see one in all of that driving. I did see three McLarens, but they're as common as muck these days I guess.

Name: goldmax
Comment: In today's Times and he really likes it.It takes time to learn to think your way round corners, but when you get there, I must say this is a genuinely exciting car to drive. It doesn’t feel as cumbersome as all the other SUVs, and you get the impression it was engineered by people who were involved because they wanted to be. Not because they’d done something wrong.And because of that — because it’s a big, practical car with a huge boot and folding seats and lots of cubbyholes that’s also an Alfa Romeo — it’s the only SUV that’s quite tempting. It may even be irresistible when Alfa launches the version with the 500-horsepower petrol engine.

Name: Scotital
Comment: It seems that the 2.0 T4 MAir engine is at least as advanced as any; MAir (v. low NOx), twin scroll turbo, secondary (separate) engine cooling circuit (for intercooler / turbo) with run-on electric circulator. Why would it need to go to 6,000 RPM anyway with a torque curve such as it has and an 8 speed transmission?AND it appears that this is the engine likely to undergo most ongoing development...200 HP to begin, now 280 HP, soon 350 HP with more highly developed turbo tech (electric ?). Diesel may not yet be dead but who needs it; USA doesn't want it, Japan doesn't want it...and if it wasn't for know-nothing-about-anything-technical political interference, we would never have wanted it either!

Name: Biscione1750
Comment: StelvioForum.com - The Largest Alfa Romeo Stelvio Forum And Community!2018 Alfa Romeo Stelvio Prototype Drive | Automobile Magazine...The Stelvio would drive circles round the soon-to-be-replaced X3, is a more emotional piece of kit than the nicely balanced Q5, and feels a bit more refined than Jaguar’s F-Pace. But the Macan is a tough nut to crack. Dynamically, the Alfa comes close; in terms of ride comfort, even the Stelvio’s optional bigfoot 19-inch wheel/tire package is more spine-friendly than the corresponding Macan footwear. Value for money is another strong point: the Veloce is expected to undercut the X3 by 20 percent and the all-in QV is said to cost 15 percent less than the Macan Turbo. In the high-tech department, however, the Italian contender falls short of its German rivals. Missing from the options list are several assistance systems, LED headlights, head-up display, and an air suspension. But who else offers rosso competizione in an executive car park dominated by depressing black, snore white, and yawn gray?...Click to expand...

Name: Guvernator
Comment: I can think of 3 advantages of an SUV over an estate off the top of my head.1) Better visibility. The higher driving position lets you see over other traffic and better judge the corners of the car, especially since the largely female target demographic are shorter on average. My missus rates this as one of the most important advantages of an SUV.2) Easier to get small kids in and out of the back and shopping in an out of the boot. Both my missus and I have suffered from back issues from having to stick heavy toddlers in the back seat. This problem is greatly reduced in an SUV as you are at the right height to plop them straight even rather than bending over.3) Ride comfort, the bigger tires and larger suspension travel often mean they have a comfier ride, much more important in a family wagon then whether it will corner on it's mirrors. Also the urban suv's might not be so great at going off-road but they are certainly capable enough to handle our pot whole ridden, crap roads and better than a long, low estate.

Name: Dale487
Comment: I think the pricing is going to be key to its success - the petrol needs to be £35-37.5K in my opinion to have enough clear air between it and the 4 cylinder Macan and the diesel needs to still under cut the base Macan.

Name: Kitchski
Comment: Guvernator said:I'm not a fan of SUV's either but for the purposes of getting an average family from A to B they really are one of the best options due to stuff already stated above, well it's either that or an MPV! So all the scorn on PH, either the majority of PH'ers are rich bachelor singletons or powerfully built company directors who pack the kids off to boarding school or let the nanny kart the kids around so don't have to worry about the practicalities of moving kids around.The SUV is still no-where near as good as an MPV at carting the brood around. You'd struggle to get three decent kids car seats across the back of that, so unless you've got two kids or less, you'd still be better off in an MPV. And if you've got two kids or less, a normal saloon or estate would do the job fine. We've only got an S-Max because one of our kids split into two before they were born, the cheeky feckers.Some people who care too much how others perceive them might insist on trying to cram everything into a tool less-suited to the job, but the MPV is just made for families, pure and simple. They're brilliant at it. Guvernator said:

Name: _Neal_
Comment: All sounds very promising, and as you say, a must for Alfa to have a good product in this sector. I hope this sells well, as that should (hopefully) mean the continued return to form for Alfa across the board.PS - Isn't it "envelop" rather than "envelope"?

Name: Kitchski
Comment: It's probably one of the best-proportioned cars on the market, in my opinion. That picture of the two of them side-by-side (grey one and red one) could easily be of two Focus-sized hatchbacks. They don't look big at all. Quite impressive stuff, though I don't like the SUV 'thing' myself.

Name: Motormatt
Comment: nickfrog said:TurboHatchback said:nickfrog said:wemorgan said:TurboHatchback said:Woop, yet another ugly jacked up uncomfortable 4cyl diesel hatchback. I know they have to build one as the market gets what the market wants and it sounds like they've done the best job they could given the stupid requirements but why people want this sort of rubbish mystifies me.Because not every one is the same as you. It's quite simple.I agree - I really wouldn't want a Jeep Grand Cherokee CRD Overland but I have no issues with anyone wanting one.People are welcome to buy whatever they want, I just don't understand the thought process that leads to buying one of these nor the set of requirements for which this sort of vehicle is the logical answer. I understand why people buy most sorts of cars, even highly undesireable ones as there is a set of requirements for which most vehicles might be optimal but not these faux-fashion-4x4 things.Clearly lots of people want them now though as they're astoundingly popular.The thought process is simple. They tend to be a better functional alternative for transport than traditional estates or saloons for many people. They're slightly shorter than an "equivalent" estate yet offer similar interior space ; they offer a higher driving position which is brilliant for visibility, touring, ease of access. They tend to have taller sidewalls and longer travel suspension which is a good combo for comfort.They are dynamically superb despite the high COG but won't quite match a lower car, which is no big deal as they're not track cars. They use a little more fuel which is offset by better residuals. No downsides IME. I am sure they are also bought for fashion but that shouldn't come into it objectively ; many buy them despite the image as they don't really care about what others think.Quite right, they are incredibly popular because most people outside of PH value daily ease of use and function above driving dynamics, and don't tend to over analyse the image.Having said that, whilst I'm still able bodied with good eyesignt, I'll take an estate over an quasi-SUV. I'm not prepared to sacrifice the lower COG, reduced weight, increased performance and efficiency, better handling and in many cases better refinement that an estate offers over its SUV equivalent in order to get a high seating position and marginally easier access, but I can understand why some people would. nickfrog said: TurboHatchback said: nickfrog said: wemorgan said: TurboHatchback said:

Name: jamespink
Comment: PhantomPH said:Article said:Still, the vast majority of UK buyers will be having the diesel anywayWill we, tho? Whilst that might have been true even last week, the fact that there is massive 'diesel bad' rhetoric ATM and increased charges in London and potential bans elsewhere, I am not so sure.To me (I know it's an Alfa...), the petrol engine might be the right option. It's fast enough without being intrusive. Remember that this car is unlikely to be revved out to the max all the time. In this sector (non-halo model) I would imagine the petrol engine's key playing card is it's refinement. Can I go fast without loads of noise and fuss and....I too question this slavish UK diesel leaning. The Nox emissions in many UK cities are still at EU "fine-able" levels and according to the last report I read, show no improvement since the late 80's (take a look at the exhaust of any London taxi) whereas petrol engine emissions, aside from being less toxic to start with, have improved by 20% to 30%. Aside from being a mainly lack-luster alternative to petrol or petrol hibrid, has diesel not had its day on emissions alone? PhantomPH said: Article said:

Name: Guvernator
Comment: I'm interested in this car for the OH but do have a few concerns1) "UK buyers will mostly buy the diesel"? Why make statements like this when diesel is obviously on the way out, in fact why are manufacturers making new diesels at all when the political tide is obviously changing? I know this applies to other manufacturers too but they at least seem to be releasing hybrid versions of their popular ranges now.2) What size is this? The article compares it from everything from an F-pace (pretty huge) to an X3 (pretty small). I wasn't sure what size segment this SUV was aimed at previously and after this article, I'm still non the wiser.3) Great point made above on residuals, Alfa need to back these with proper finance deals so the monthly figures are attractive. If they don't prop up the usually woeful Alfa depreciation somehow or make the list price cheaper than it's rivals, people will just go and buy the Macan or the Evoque instead, both of which have outstanding residuals in their class.

Name: jhonn
Comment: Hhmmm.. this Alfa and the PH article demonstrate how far removed modern SUV's now are from their predecessors - not a mention of it's ability to handle off-road terrain or the features that facilitate that (ability to raise ride-height; low-box; enhanced traction-control; towing capability; wading depth; underbody protection, etc).Yes, yes - I know that it's now a 'lifestyle' vehicle. However, I see this as a further example of 'style over substance'; in my opinion it further tarnishes the image of similar looking vehicles bought to service specific utility needs.It's pretty though, I'll give it that.

Name: Guvernator
Comment: big_rob_sydney said:I recently read from someone on PH who works designing car parks, and he stated that there is a standard size parking space.Instead of thinking spaces are getting smaller, maybe you should stop buying vehicles the size of beached whales?Or maybe car park designers should take a note of the fact that ALL cars, not just SUV's have been getting steadily bigger over the last 3 decades and design them accordingly. The standard car park size hasn't changed in that period as it would mean less spaces and eat into revenue. My current car isn't an SUV, it's just a mid sized saloon but even I struggle to get out in car parks without going through Houdini like contortions to avoid bashing other peoples cars. Some people don't even bother, preferring to use my car as door stop. big_rob_sydney said:

Name: big_rob_sydney
Comment: PhantomPH said:filski666 said:nickfrog said:One of the benefits of SUVs is that they usually have a smaller footprint than the "equivalent" estate and crucially they're shorter, hence easier to park in particular (compare the length of a Golf estate vs a Tiguan for instance).You have a point on the likelihood of rollover though but what you call "significantly more likely" I would call "almost as unlikely" for the intended purpose.I guess I was thinking primarily of height and width when talking about parking and in particular multi-storeys which seem to be getting lower and lower roofs.From my own experience, I don't think it's much of an issue. I had a Range Rover Sport on order and was talking to my wife about being worried that it was going to be a bit too big etc. as we were driving her Q5 into a multi-storey. At that moment I clocked that the car a few in front of me was a Full Fat Range Rover merrily wandering into the same multi-storey.I have found that it's parking spaces in general that seem to be getting smaller these days. Getting into a multi is not the issue.Personal note: I notice the size of spaces more in my CGTS than in the Q5. The Porsche is a compact car, but the length of the doors and the low seating position makes parking an absolute laugh. The Q5 on the other hand, has shorter doors and less of a required contortion to get out of. Name: nickfrog
Comment: filski666 said:nickfrog said:Yes that's the problem with women, they don't realise how much apex speed you're losing by having a shockingly high COG in the supermarket car park or picking the kids up.you do realise the issue with high CofG is not to do with apex speed - but it means SUVs are significantly more likely to roll over in an accident which involves them receiving a side strike - ie hitting a kerb, a small ditch or even just running off into soft ground with steering applied.The electronics they all carry might stop them tipping from violent driver inputs (moose test) but the high CofG makes them more dangerous - in point of any rollover puts chances of serious injury much higher.Plus, SUVs are generally bigger and harder to park in multi-storey carparks - hence why I would stick to estates as long as I can.One of the benefits of SUVs is that they usually have a smaller footprint than the "equivalent" estate and crucially they're shorter, hence easier to park in particular (compare the length of a Golf estate vs a Tiguan for instance).You have a point on the likelihood of rollover though but what you call "significantly more likely" I would call "almost as unlikely" for the intended purpose. filski666 said: nickfrog said:

From my SUV I can see over hedges, roundabout shrubbery, junction clutter, etc, etc. much better than in my other cars. Name: modeller
Comment: Guvernator said:I can think of 3 advantages of an SUV over an estate off the top of my head.1) Better visibility. The higher driving position lets you see over other traffic and better judge the corners of the car, especially since the largely female target demographic are shorter on average. My missus rates this as one of the most important advantages of an SUV.2) Easier to get small kids in and out of the back and shopping in an out of the boot. Both my missus and I have suffered from back issues from having to stick heavy toddlers in the back seat. This problem is greatly reduced in an SUV as you are at the right height to plop them straight even rather than bending over.3) Ride comfort, the bigger tires and larger suspension travel often mean they have a comfier ride, much more important in a family wagon then whether it will corner on it's mirrors. Also the urban suv's might not be so great at going off-road but they are certainly capable enough to handle our pot whole ridden, crap roads and better than a long, low estate.4. 4WD with no transmission tunnel.OK, only the X5 , Discovery and Range Rovers do this .. but gives loads more interior space Guvernator said:

Comment: Guvernator said:big_rob_sydney said:I recently read from someone on PH who works designing car parks, and he stated that there is a standard size parking space.Instead of thinking spaces are getting smaller, maybe you should stop buying vehicles the size of beached whales?Or maybe car park designers should take a note of the fact that ALL cars, not just SUV's have been getting steadily bigger over the last 3 decades and design them accordingly. The standard car park size hasn't changed in that period as it would mean less spaces and eat into revenue. My current car isn't an SUV, it's just a mid sized saloon but even I struggle to get out in car parks without going through Houdini like contortions to avoid bashing other peoples cars. Some people don't even bother, preferring to use my car as door stop.You do realise how illogical that is, right?There are god knows how many thousand parking stations already built around the country. Not to mention the various country lanes that are the width they are and wont get rebuilt with an extra few inches every time the population "up-sizes" due to the latest fashion-victim trend.Quite frankly, the whole door bashing thing is only going to get worse due to selfish people continually engaging in the beached whale arms race.Next thing you know, idiots will complain their car doesn't fit into ANY space. Name: Kolbenkopp
Comment: nickfrog said:So zero real world downsides and loads of real world benefits (comfy ride, easier access, better visibility, smaller physical footprint). For family use, the choice is simple, despite the ghastly image and the PH scienceI'm a convicted SUV disbeliever, but over time I've come to accept them. With the current things your practical points are just the truth. Despite the non ideal formula to start with, enough development has been thrown at them, and in the real world they work nicely. I drive one as rental every so often and mostly come out impressed (grudgingly).What IMO is unfortunate is the way marketing/demand steered manufacturers. The 4x4 image is popular, perhaps because of the active life style it portrays. So they worked hard at making tough, heavy and tall 4x4s work for families. Getting efficiency out of the formula a big challenge. End result after ~ 20 years of fettling -- cars that are basically big hatchbacks with pretty heavy suspension and inexplicably large wheels.The alternative to get the same real-world benefits could have been to fettle with the MPV formula a bit more. I think we would have gotten to better results at least decade quicker. But the MPV image? So uncool. So not much development or demand. Good thing I don't need a compact people carrier at the moment, or I would be moaning about the lack of a B-Max ST, Scenic RS or Sportsvan GTI/GTD .Or to put it another way, a 33 year old car like this one:Hypothetically updated to current levels of reliability and crash safety. IMO, nothing a current SUV would be better at for the family man. Comfy ride, easy access, visibility, small physical footprint? All available from 1984. nickfrog said:

Name: marks148
Comment: I couldn't wait for this to come and 70k for an alfa is a bit steep anyway. So i bought the wife a new 2.0 super 280ps petrol in April and it is not too shoddy at all.I am biased having owned 9 alfas since being a student so it was a no brainer for me. Performance is great and it looks different for a soft roader (from the front at least). Wind noise on the door seals is pretty high though due to the odd seal design and way louder than her previous Range Rover. Economy on short runs is tragic though - c. 20mpg and on a long run to France i scraped 29mpg - no idea where the 46 comes from in the test docs.i have only seen one other on the road and that is a pleasant change.

Name: MarkJS
Comment: I have a Giulia Veloce with the same 280bhp unit. Best bits are the steering & gearbox - both excellent. Overall build quality is iffy, but not horrendous - I've read people say that it is on a par with the Germans. It really isn't. There's very little room in the rear (doesn't bother me but might be a problem for you considering your usage). Infotainment is poor in comparison to its rivals but it does the basic job.Engine - pretty gutsy but with zero drama in the noise department. Economy isn't good for what is basically a 2.0 4 pot turbo - especially in comparison to BMW's 3.0 6 cylinder which gives a lot more power. I think I get around 27mpg overall but I don't imagine the Stelvio will reach that with the 4x4 drivetrain being dragged around - but could be wrong.Also, bear in mind the pretty short 9000 mile (or annual) l service intervals which add to the overall cost. And also, trying to find a decent dealer for aftersales care is no mean feat.If you'd like to know anything more specific, just let me know.

Name: aspender
Comment: Practicality:Boot is a very reasonable size, nice and square and with no loading lip. We can pretty much everything we need for a 5-day trip to center parcs into it (e.g. buggy, large suitcase, trunki, then stuff packed around them. Back seats are fine for car seats and the isofix points are very well done (small plastic flap to lift up, no hunting around to find them) rear space isn't amazing. I have the drivers seat fairly far back and there's still room for an adult behind me, but it isn't expansive. Headroom in the back is fine. I have the pano sunroof which makes it quite airy back there too. However without pano, with privacy glass and the swooping line of the roof I can image that it might feel a bit more claustrophobic than it actually is. There are two USB charging points for the back seats but they don't connect to the infotainment.In the front things are all good. Seats (Milano Edizione ones) are good and well adjustable with memory. A nice touch is if the drivers seat is set forward of the B pillar it will automatically move back to allow easy ingress/egress when the engine is switched off. There's USB on the center console and in the glovebox. I have a mini-USB stick of the daughters music in the glovebox permanently attached and still use the console one for charging my phone. The climate control feeds directly into the glovebox but tbh I've never found a use for this. Two good cupholders (concealable) in the centre console along with a useful phone slot between them. Glovebox is very small. Door storage is fine.We cycle a lot. I didn't spec the roof rails but do have Whispbar roof bars and a couple of bike carriers which fit fine and actually look pretty good. It's not such a high car that getting bikes on/off the top is too difficult.Driving:All very subjective... but for an SUV it is definitely fast enough! If you want to drive it spiritedly it will play ball. Of course if really pushed then the laws of physics come into play, it is still a high vehicle with a bit more weight, but overally the reviews rightly laud the drive dynamics. Steering is fast but I've not found that it is too fidgety like some reviews say. Conversely when you just want to get from A-B the car is just a nice place to trundle along in. The gearbox never misses a beat in full auto mode. DNA selector is 95% of the time in 'N' for me with occassional 'D' and never 'A' unless there's snow. There is a marked difference in throttle responsiveness and gear selection between 'N' and 'D' but for everyday driving with 'N' you can just downshift with the paddles to execute an overtake etc. Engine noise is what you might expect from a 4-pot turbo but after a while it has got a bit more tuneful.MPG is... well thirsty. In 12k miles I've averaged around 24mpg. A long motorway drive might get 30 or so.Other stuff:Had a few niggles covered by warranty - filler cap tends to warp and stick out a bit. Alarm can be over-sensitive and needs adjusting. I've only had one significant mechanical that required the ABS pump to be replaced. AEB can be a bit over-keen in warning you of impending doom e.g. when turning near oncoming traffic (but doesn't kick in)Mostly though, it is still a very unusual car to see around and 18 months in I still get a kick every time I look at it or drive it

Name: Yidwann
Comment: I'm glad it's not just mine on the fuel.... was starting to wonder, it is indeed thirsty, but I love mine, in a sea of German tin, its nice to have something a bit different, and the cabin is still a very nice place to sit. The infotainment sits in CarPlay most of the time. Its certainly not lacking pace and the engine not is a bit more raspy and tuneful the VAG 4 pot I came from.I have had mine for about a month... genuinely not seen another one on my travels yet.

Name: TheDrBrian
Comment: What trickery do they have to pull to get a 2 ton SUV only create 210g of co2 per mile?

Name: The rapid detailer
Comment: Hey all. Mega car. We love ours. Fast, sounds great and drives like a coupe. Can be very nervous in the wet in race mode but this all adds to its charm. The Alfa badge is very well received within the public domain and we would find it hard not to have an Alfa Romeo in our line up. They are a very much overlooked brand and deserve a lot more credit than they currently receive.

Name: stuckmojo
Comment: I'd love one of these in Blue

Name: 3yardy3
Comment: Wills2 said:samoht said:I wonder if this is part of Alfa's problem. The Stelvio is "the most popular SUV among people who don't buy SUVs" - which is great for their reputation, but possibly not so good for their sales numbers.Meanwhile BMW make SUVs such as the X6 and 7 that SUV-buyers like, but non-SUV-buyers love to hate. Unpopular, but profitable.I also think the dealer network or lack of it and the overall low level of sales in the UK gives the Germans with their network and massive existing customer base a real advantage.It's just easier to buy an X3M or GLC63s, Macan turbo etc...I have no idea where my local Alfa garage is can't remember the last time I saw one, hence I'd never look to get one and often the decision is a snap one with me, last December I got a X3M never even thought about the Stevlio or the Giulia when I had M3s.The other issue is I don't think I'm missing out either as all these cars are much of a muchness with pros and cons but no real difference for me to want to make the effort especially as I like M cars.Not looking to get one because you don't know where the dealer is, is the most caveman thing I've heard in a while. Imagine only buying a car based on what dealers are on the high street near you... Wills2 said: samoht said:

Name: Ares
Comment: 3yardy3 said:Not looking to get one because you don't know where the dealer is, is the most caveman thing I've heard in a while. Imagine only buying a car based on what dealers are on the high street near you...It is a very valid issue. Its not about knowing where the dealer is in your town, it's about knowing which town has a dealer.I own a Giulia QF. I do have a dealer 10 miles away, but they are corrupt as well as being utterly ste. The next two have been closed down/lost franchise, so my next dealer is an hour and 15mins away, and I have 10 cities closer. It'll stop me owning another.There are plenty of people that don't have a dealer within an hour. A friend on mine on the North side of Manchester (but still within the M60), doesn't have a dealer within an hour. Imagine, a car company wanting to gain market share that doesn't have a dealer the England's second city.So not caveman at all... 3yardy3 said:

Name: Unlucky
Comment: Ive had Alfas for years, going back to the mid 8os, and the dealers here in Ireland have always been an afterthought, badly trained, poor service, mad prices, result being not many buy two Alfas.The fashion for SUVs is well, just that, a fashion, with Yummy Mummys using them for the school run and Flash bds plonking them in the supermarket parking lot. Where four wheel drive is so essential.And they are all hideous, plus if you want to argue greenery, they all guzzle fuel. The Stelvio too is hideous.Plenty of toys no doubt, and a hoot to hammer about in, but you would fit more in a van, and a sports car handles better.So good luck to those who enthuse about such beasts, each to their own.My own is a 82 GTV6, rusty and rattly, but I love it and care not a damn what others think.

Name: Ares

Name: aspender
Comment: peld said:any general experience feedback from a few years living with a Stelvio?I've had mine three years and done 24k miles in it (Petrol 280 Milano Edizione). I still catch myself glancing back at it, or looking out of a window at it and every drive is a pleasure. All that aside, the best way of answering is to say that on Friday I'm picking up my new MY20 Stelvio Quadrifoglio!Aside from that, overall it has bee na great car. Performed family duties admirably, fun to drive and returns a long term average of about 25MPG.peld said:how has build quality held up? any major issues? how bad will it look compared to years of VAG and Volvo?I've only had one issue in three years, which was a faulty IBS system which was replaced under warranty. After 24k miles it's still got 4mm all round on the original tyres, original front pads are down to 20% left, and there's a bit of pitting on the rear discs so it's basically just been oil & filters up to now. It's just been serviced hence knowing the exact detail above but they can sort those out after p/xInterior and exterior have held up well - the leather still looks like new, even on the bolsters. Mine is pre Apple Carplay/Android Auto so the infotainment is showing it's age, but to be honest it's never bothered me. Just press the loud pedal a bit more instead.peld said:I dont have a local Alfa garage - will servicing at my local garage be ok? (rather not use Arnold Clark).I'm lucky that I have two Alfa dealers within 10 miles of me. No idea about what you'd need during the warranty period. Might be worth checking if there is a local FCA brand dealer who is capable of servicing them.peld said:what sort of depreciation are people expecting? i can buy an 18 plate for under £25k at the moment which presumably cost £38k-ish. Reckon i'd get £16k in 3 years with low miles/good condition?I'll give you a good idea when my existing one appears on autotrader presumably next week, but looking at the private sale value that autotrader suggests puts it at around 42% so far. peld said: peld said: peld said: peld said:

Name: peld
Comment: Hi, didnt want to start a new thread so thought i'd bump this.As we are a year on from the OP - how have things been Stelvio owners? Any more issues or have things been all good?If the lease market doesn't improve, I am looking at buying a Stelvio next year when my lease goes expires. Probably thinking a Milano or Speciale, with the 210hp diesel for about £25k. I admit I havent even sat in one yet however. Ideally i'd like a Porsche (macan, cayenne or panamera), but either they are too old, or its more than I'm willing to pay for a car that probably only does 6-8k p.a (would need 35k for a suitable porsche). FYI typical family with 2 kids (who'll be 7 by the time we buy)After several years or VAG group or Volvo leases, i had a few questions:- any general experience feedback from a few years living with a Stelvio?- how has build quality held up? any major issues? how bad will it look compared to years of VAG and Volvo?- I dont have a local Alfa garage - will servicing at my local garage be ok? (rather not use Arnold Clark).- what sort of depreciation are people expecting? i can buy an 18 plate for under £25k at the moment which presumably cost £38k-ish. Reckon i'd get £16k in 3 years with low miles/good condition?thanks!!

Name: Van Dessel
Comment: Hi Aspender congrats on the upgrade! I'm also deciding on 280HP vs.QF (both used). Are you looking for more power per se or really just more sound, fury and occasion?Are you looking used or new? The new list prices are so high (you can't really stay under £50k for a nice 280HP) that a used QF with 3000-5000 miles on the clock looks like a good deal....Thanks for your thoughts

Name: Kawasicki
Comment: Van Dessel said:For any current Selvio owners, are there any key considerations (engine power or sonics, handling, interior space etc.) that the competitors like XC60 or Tiguan would slam-dunk do better? I really like it, but wonder if there's a big elephant that doesn't often get mentioned (finance aside, that's a private thing).Not in the market for the QF version, I subscribe to the 'top model - 1' school of thought. I have 2 small kids (6 and under) to move around and want to use it for longer distance escapades.Cheers for any additional thoughts. I'm attracted by the looks, handling, badge, size. I have a 24 hour test drive appointment in the works but have yet to step into one.From a ride and handling point of view I think the Stelvio is in another league from the Volvo. The Volvo drives like it has cheap suspension, the Stelvio is the opposite. The VW is also much better than the Volvo, but it is less characterful than the Alfa. Van Dessel said:

Name: Yidwann
Comment: I’d be really interested to hear your thoughts of the QF after you have had it a while. I too have the 280 on what seems like now a really cheap lease compared to with what else is out there. But it goes back in March, I think its a good steer, but its never leaves me just wanting to take it for a drive somewhere, I wonder if the QF would do that, or whether its in the “Incredibly good for an SUV” category, which is my conundrum really, I don’t want to commit to one and then still be yearning for a 2 car setup again! They do look stunning though, congrats on your purchase!

Name: aspender
Comment: Yidwann said:I’d be really interested to hear your thoughts of the QF after you have had it a while. I too have the 280 on what seems like now a really cheap lease compared to with what else is out there. But it goes back in March, I think its a good steer, but its never leaves me just wanting to take it for a drive somewhere, I wonder if the QF would do that, or whether its in the “Incredibly good for an SUV” category, which is my conundrum really, I don’t want to commit to one and then still be yearning for a 2 car setup again! They do look stunning though, congrats on your purchase!Will be happy to report back. I've only done 200 miles of fairly gentle driving so far as the run-in period says to keep under 5k rpm until 300 miles and under 70mph, plus it isn't going in for detailing/ceramic coating until next week.One other consideration on 280 vs QF is a really quite significant different in insurance groups. The Stelvio QF is group 50 (by comparison the Giulia QF is "only" 46). Tax is also a jump from £540 per year to £2,175 per year (plus the first 5 years surcharge which is applicable to both) Yidwann said:

Name: aspender
Comment: Van Dessel said:Hi Aspender congrats on the upgrade! I'm also deciding on 280HP vs.QF (both used). Are you looking for more power per se or really just more sound, fury and occasion?Sound and occasion hits the nail on the head. The 280 is plenty powerful and fast enough for any day to day activity. I can't say I ever found it wanting. The QF for me is ticking off a few boxes on the bucket list. I've had a V6 before but not one like this - I just wanted that 500+ HP, sound, delivery, Ferrari connotations etc and it was a case of just being very fortunate enough to be able to do so. Of course general wisdom would say I should have gone with the Giulia QF but for our family needs the Stelvio is a better match.Van Dessel said:Are you looking used or new? The new list prices are so high (you can't really stay under £50k for a nice 280HP) that a used QF with 3000-5000 miles on the clock looks like a good deal....Thanks for your thoughtsHaving owned an early one without the inital round of improvements (most notably Carplay/Android Auto) and now a MY20 I wouldn't say that the MY20 updates transform the car. Yes the infotainment is better (the performance pages are actually quite useful) the driver assistance stuff works well etc, but fundamentally it's the same overall driving and cabin experience and the mechanicals are not really much different (on the Stelvio QF there are engine changes, notably the introduction of both direct and port injection to avoid the need for a GPF. There's also a rumour of a 1.5cm lower ride height)If you can get second hand with Carplay/Android Auto, I'd say that would be a great car regardless. You may also benefit from the remainder of a 5 year warranty which is no longer offered. Van Dessel said: Van Dessel said:

Name: Yidwann
Comment: What was the list? Price, mine has just gone back and but didn't enquire about owning it. But I had a Stelvio Milano 280 and the list was £48k be intrigued for what it went for at Auction. To be honest though I have moved to a Macan S and its night and day better than the Stelvio, but at least I have ticked that Alfa box.Most of the Leasys cars end up at Manhiem to be auctioned, so you could see what something similar goes for there.https://www.manheim.co.uk/search?Make%5B0%5D=ALFA%...

Name: saintsteve
Comment: It was £48k approximately. It has the sports interior in red, tinted Windows, rear camera and 19 inch wheels, metallic paint as options. £23k seems cheap but unsure on future depreciation. If we do buy it, it would be our second car so will be keeping it for at least 3 to 4 years.

Name: chopper602
Comment: I've had my Giulia Veloce for 2½ years now and that was joined by a MY20 Stelvio Veloce in December for my wife (to replace the horrendous Jag E-Pace). Loads of boot space and it rides really well as we didn't spec up the wheels. The Stelvio is almost as quick as the Giulia and you have the AWD too. Really happy with them both, nothing has broken and we are a little spoiled as we have independent dealer, Alexanders of Teesside almost adjacent to where I work. Sales and service is top notch - not that we've had need to use them, other than servicing.
